https://www.smws.com/a-barley-harvest-an.description: The nose spoke fondly of a July barley harvest, raw cereal notes, hay, cut grass, with zingy sherbet and lemon sorbet. There was also a wholesome earthy oakiness (potting table in a greenhouse?), very sweet oranges, soft leather and tobacco. The neat taste had lots of lemon bitterness moving into intense orange barley sugar sweetness, finishing with crème caramel pots, grapefruit and light vanilla. With water we entered a florist’s in summer, and were served lemon syrup cocktails. There was an intriguing “fizzy buzz” about it (Cremola foam), eucalyptus oil and the sweetness of orange with the sour edge of fresh lime.
https://www.smws.com/a-barley-harvest-an.drinking_tip: Instead of champagne on the winners podium.
https://www.smws.com/a-barley-harvest-an.name: A Barley Harvest and a "Fizzy Buzz"

https://www.smws.com/a-celebration-of-li.description: The nose brought to mind a refectory table in a cottage kitchen – dessert wine, brioche, honey on buttery toast, plus creamy desserts with mandarin, apple, vanilla, butterscotch and caramel – a layer-cake of a dram to explore slowly. Adding water, took us into a delightful countryside of sunlit barley fields, heather, gorse and flower meadows. The neat palate was lively and vibrant, with flavours pineapple humps, sweet toasted coconut, honey and light tobacco. The reduced palate was gentle, but spritzy, intense but easy – a perfect balance and ‘real class’ – honey lemon drizzle cake, flowers and vintage champagne – like a celebration of life!
https://www.smws.com/a-celebration-of-li.drinking_tip: Who needs champagne for special moments?
https://www.smws.com/a-celebration-of-li.name: A celebration of life!

https://www.smws.com/a-cheese-board-in-a.description: A tired bowl of fruit (including bruised apples and ripe peaches), backed by polished wood panelling, leather books and faded roses, then a scent of mild cheeses (Caboc, unripe brie, white stilton) and Melba toast. The taste reflects some of these scents: sweet, then ‘cheese on a Cream Cracker’. With water the cheese note shifts to full-fat creamy (Laughing Cow), with melon, green banana, peach skin and a hint of Badedas chestnut bath oil. Soft and sweet to taste, then faintly fizzy/peppery (Flying Saucers, spicy), with a long warming finish and a hint of banana yoghurt in the aftertaste. This distillery supplies the heart malt for Ballantine’s, so is uncommon.
https://www.smws.com/a-cheese-board-in-a.drinking_tip: With cheese and grapes after informal supper
https://www.smws.com/a-cheese-board-in-a.name: A cheese-board in a library

https://www.smws.com/a-christmas-wreath.cask_type: First Fill Toasted American Oak Hogshead
https://www.smws.com/a-christmas-wreath.description: A mild nose, with fruit salad (banana, apples, maraschino cherries, condensed milk) on a base of leather books in a highly polished book-case; sandalwood and scented hand cream; “a Christmas wreath, with cinnamon and dried oranges”. A mature taste: light sweetness, drying to a box of pencils. The latter comes through with the addition of water, also macadamia nuts and fresh floral-scented laundry. The taste is sweet (baked apples), dry and fragrant (a pomander – dried orange with woody spices. Drinks particularly well at natural strength.
https://www.smws.com/a-christmas-wreath.name: A Christmas wreath

https://www.smws.com/a-clean-green-flyin.description: The panel found the nose sweet at first with baked biscuits, pineapple, strawberry and summer florals. A curious but good note of airfix glue and balsa wood emerged with a fizzy bicarbonate of soda freshness. At full strength it packed a punch: they found bitter green gages, grapefruit, quinine and tinned pineapple. A slug of water sweetened up proceedings exceedingly well. Our panelists embraced the juicy sweetness of fruity strawberry daiquiri with vanilla cookie dough. Green notes of pine sap and peppermint, laced with hints of aniseed. More of the same deliciousness with spicy wood shavings and orris root.
https://www.smws.com/a-clean-green-flyin.name: A clean green flying machine

https://www.smws.com/a-cornucopia-of-com.description: The panel found bagfuls of vibrant aromas: pastry case filled with waxy apple, wine soaked pear and rhubarb cheesecake. Fresh hay, crisp lemon and laundered washing on the nose. To taste they found welcoming clove and mace, followed by fresh marzipan on cherry Bakewell tart. Fresher flavours of lychee, kiwi and peach skins became tempered with water, more stewed and pulpy in texture. A couple of panelists identified warm wool tweediness, others warm baking from the oven: both homely. The finish had an edginess of quinine, juniper and pickled ginger and was tooth coating to the end.
https://www.smws.com/a-cornucopia-of-com.drinking_tip: Book club when discussion is required
https://www.smws.com/a-cornucopia-of-com.name: A cornucopia of complexity

https://www.smws.com/a-couple-of-classic.description: Oven roasted potato chips with malt vinegar, flamed grilled crisps and chutney next to toffee waffles and dark Jamaican gingerbread made this a real talking point on the nose neat. Big and spicy on the palate; Bloody Mary with Worcester sauce, Tabasco, salt and pepper and garnished with a celery stalk, smoked almonds on the side. Diluted the celery was now thinly sliced, add chopped apples, red grapes, slightly toasted walnuts served on a bed of fresh lettuce and we had a Waldorf salad. The taste was now sweet and refreshing like ice cold sugar cane juice with a dash of lime.
https://www.smws.com/a-couple-of-classic.drinking_tip: Undust that vinyl from Fred Astaire
https://www.smws.com/a-couple-of-classic.name: A couple of classic icons

https://www.smws.com/a-fickle-date-in-no.description: The panel had to tease out peach, apricot with lychee and kiwi fruit. It fluttered with sweet sponge cake topped with cherries and lemon drizzle before turning all monastic in a dusty library. Mexican hot chocolate laced with white pepper found temperatures rising, then indulgent pecan pie, old calvados and orange chocolate cocoa bean. Water tickled it under the chin and coaxed warm wooden decking and a posh shop selling waxed jackets. It flirted shamelessly with rich prunes soaked in rum and dripping in maple syrup. A final flash of cool mint and a whiff of perfume left them standing.
https://www.smws.com/a-fickle-date-in-no.name: A fickle date in no haste

https://www.smws.com/a-good-place-to-be.description: Nosing neat it felt like listening to an overture and realizing that life is better when you slow down, relax and pay full attention to what is to come. Be rest assured, you will be rewarded. Aromas were intense but subtle; exotic spices, tropical fruits, perfumed leather, tobacco and wood. The taste had at first the almost overwhelming spiciness of cloves, aniseed and cinnamon but the balance with sweet rhubarb and custard and dark cherry chocolate delivered total harmony. Water added a powerful combination of dark rum in black tea and spiced orange Madeira cake with a hint of smoked burnt lavender.
https://www.smws.com/a-good-place-to-be.name: A good place to be

https://www.smws.com/a-joy-to-savour.description: Polished and waxed furniture and lino suggested a vestibule which led into a fruit emporium (lemons, raspberries, mango, peaches) – a few chocolate-coated mint crisps, barley sugars and Dolly Mixtures completed the picture. The neat palate made a very favourable impression – oaky spice, vanilla and coconut; juicy dried fruits (papaya, mango, pineapple) and some tasty pastries with lemon and almond paste. The reduced nose reminded us of trail mix, sugared almonds and a patisserie (vanilla custard slices, lemon meringue pie, crepes). The taste was now a joy to savour with lasting, lip-smacking flavours of syrup sponge, lemon zest and waxy honey.
https://www.smws.com/a-joy-to-savour.drinking_tip: Could be a good picnic dram – fun, fresh and flavourful.
https://www.smws.com/a-joy-to-savour.name: A joy to savour

https://www.smws.com/a-juicy-jamboree.description: The whisky leapt from the glass with a refreshing vibrancy and greeted the panellists with sweet tones of honey, ginger cake and bakewell tart. It invited us into its house made of fresh oak, recently furbished with new carpets and curtains where we received a very warm, going on hot welcome. A softer side now joined the party of pear, mango and tinned mandarins. Sitting down to a cup of green tea we were treated to a mouth-watering selection of lemon drizzle cake, Turkish delight and Key lime pie. After a zesty farewell we made our way home feeling invigorated and full of sweet memories.
https://www.smws.com/a-juicy-jamboree.drinking_tip: Sip whilst planning you next challenge.
https://www.smws.com/a-juicy-jamboree.name: A juicy jamboree

https://www.smws.com/a-library-of-spices.description: Rich spice and elegant wood tantalised our senses as we strolled through an old library of spices, the air filled with cloves, fresh ginger, fennel, black pepper and mandarin marmalade. The smell of espresso dregs and sweet demerara sugar led our noses into the cafe that was finely adorned with hand-made maple wood furniture. The tempting menu included clootie dumpling, tart cherry flan, blackcurrant chews, creme brulee and an enviable chocolate biscuit selection. We could not resist and settled on tasting the surprisingly spicy ginger cake with chilli honey and orange chocolate washed down with a nip of Danish schnapps.
https://www.smws.com/a-library-of-spices.drinking_tip: A welcome home after a cold day on the hills.
https://www.smws.com/a-library-of-spices.name: A library of spices

https://www.smws.com/a-memory-of-summer.description: Barnacles, brine and hemp rope in the foreground – although the distillery is nowhere near the sea – becoming “elegantly medicinal” (aromatherapy oils), with a trace of singed wool. The taste at natural strength is sweet and salty, with lime juice and scented herbs. Water returned us to the beach: hot sand, dry beach towels, fresh laundry, plastic buckets, bonfire ash and light tar . The taste is light and pleasant; sweet to start, with salty lime, a shake of white pepper and a trace of Savlon antiseptic cream, finishing with a suggestion of warm tar.
https://www.smws.com/a-memory-of-summer.name: A memory of summer

https://www.smws.com/a-nippy-sweetie-54-.description: Superlicious sweet notes of peach, ripe apple and juicy pears sprinkled with icing sugar and topped with buttercream. The aromas of delicate cherry and apple blossom blended with freshly baked biscuits and warm balsa wood. The panel found the palate zingy with lemon zest, then tinned pears in syrup laced with chilli flakes and a dusting of cinnamon. Water opened up fresh apple and custard, lime basil and mandarin candle, mirabelle plum and wild flowers. Fresh pencil shavings and dusty chalk added depth with clean grapefruit giving in to fizzy sherbet and rich dark chocolate for a pleasing dry finish.
https://www.smws.com/a-nippy-sweetie-54-.drinking_tip: For those cheeky wee whisky moments
https://www.smws.com/a-nippy-sweetie-54-.name: A nippy sweetie! - 54.37

https://www.smws.com/a-pure-stoater.description: We sniffed and found it luscious and fascinating – Russian caramels, treacle toffee, plum crumble and rum Baba – plus a bountiful harvest of redness – red apple, red laces, red leather shoes, port wine and Campari. With water the nose developed black pepper, Peshwari naan, Turkish coffee and Turkish Delight – sheer entertainment. The neat palate was exotically fruity (cherry, figs, dates, pomegranate) with some almonds and hints of anise, liquorice and menthol in the background. With water, we got candied fruits and dark chocolate with salted caramel; traces of chilli, ginger and pepper in the finish – according to one panellist – ‘A pure stoater!’
https://www.smws.com/a-pure-stoater.drinking_tip: When in the mood for something different – this will prove endlessly entertaining.
https://www.smws.com/a-pure-stoater.name: A pure stoater!

https://www.smws.com/a-real-charmer.description: A real charmer on the nose neat; vanilla slices, apricot yoghurt fool, Peach Melba smoothie, dark honey, toasted coconut chocolate chunk cookies and chicken satays with peanut sauce. The taste started off surprisingly dry; dry roasted peanuts, chewing on the end of your pencil and a cinnamon stick but the midpalate revealed pumpernickel rye bread, digestive biscuits, mincemeat pie and brandy snaps. A drop of water and orange blossom, vanilla scented candles, peaches, melon and crushed mint leaves appeared. The flavour was now an intriguing balance of gentle wood spice and the soft juicy sweetness of peach jam ice cream.
https://www.smws.com/a-real-charmer.drinking_tip: To greet the first warm rays of sun
https://www.smws.com/a-real-charmer.name: A real charmer

https://www.smws.com/a-refined-cocktail.description: A dusty desk drawer to start with, delicate and fragile, then complex notes of frangipane with apricots, stewed apples and Calvados (the latter lending a slight prickle) – all refined and subdued. The taste at natural strength is soft and sweet; creamy (walnut oil, linseed oil) with some pepper in the finish. Water opens it somewhat, introducing burnt orange peel, snuffed candles, a hint of cloves and maraschino cherries. The taste is now sweet (orange icing sugar), mouth cooling (eucalyptus) and perfumed (rose petals, Turkish Delight), with pistachio nuts in the medium-length finish. Aristocratic and stylish; might replace a cocktail in the American Bar at the Savoy.
https://www.smws.com/a-refined-cocktail.name: A refined cocktail

https://www.smws.com/a-regency-pomander.description: From the word go this one was oozing quality. The aromas were intoxicating, baked apple with crème Anglaise, Banana Brulee using Ambrosia custard, clove studded oranges, a very chocolaty mousse and always in the background, the fragrant glow of a Jo Malone incense and embers candle. The taste neat was that of thick, sweet and waxy goodness, deep fried corn fritters served with honey and cream, blueberry pancakes with maple syrup and chocolate tofu pudding. A drop of water and the luxurious fragrance of a rosewater poured candle appeared along with a heavenly dessert of macadamia praline and Frangelico parfait.
https://www.smws.com/a-regency-pomander.name: A Regency Pomander

https://www.smws.com/a-rollercoasterboas.description: This was one that got the panel scratching their heads. At first they found raspberry, damson and cherry followed aniseed and menthol tea. Heavier aromas of hessian cloth and linseed oil hinted at the blast of Mexican chilli chocolate on the tongue. Water replaced the heat with cedar wood shavings and polished rosewood. Polo mints, pine scented candles and pear drops refreshed while sweeter stroopwafel and muscovado sugar emerged. With time, they were reminded of picnic baskets and leather satchels. The texture was a roller coaster of sweet soy, then drying and grainy. One to get you thinking!
https://www.smws.com/a-rollercoasterboas.drinking_tip: To get you up and at’em!
https://www.smws.com/a-rollercoasterboas.name: A Rollercoaster Boaster!

https://www.smws.com/a-skinny-dipping-dr.description: The panel jumped straight in and found treacle tart, baked prunes, smoked paprika, cinnamon and plums. Bubbles of aroma popped on the nose with heather, toasted brioche, walnut oil and fragrant bergamot. One felt it bracing like sea air after a dip. The taste was curiously herbaceous with bamboo shoots and wicker cane. A bracing picnic of jacket potatoes, sultana cake, coffee chocolate fudge and black tea from a billy can. Old fashioned canvas tents and camphor reminded one of Scottish holidays. A good dram to have once you had bagged a Munro. Not complicated but ticked all the boxes.
https://www.smws.com/a-skinny-dipping-dr.drinking_tip: When you are out and about in the great outdoors!
https://www.smws.com/a-skinny-dipping-dr.name: A skinny dipping dram

https://www.smws.com/a-symphony-of-oak.description: Nosing this one neat was an awe-inspiring moment, like stepping into a grand house standing in the entrance hall with open eyes and mouth. Aromas of polished wood and shiny marble mixed with luxurious leather and the sensual fresh scent of orange blossom. The taste was like a symphony of oak played in perfect harmony with spicy notes of ginger and clove and the bittersweet finish of a Turkish coffee. Water transported us into an antique woollen mill still using the old fashioned spinning jenny and the flavours dry, bitter, oaky, sweet and fruity, all beautifully interwoven like in a Persian oriental rug.
https://www.smws.com/a-symphony-of-oak.name: A symphony of oak

https://www.smws.com/a-toast-to-tim-peak.description: Finishing in a second-fill Sauternes hogshead has created a dram that's out of this world. The nose – elegant and sophisticated – hints at things you would miss while in space – flower markets, old-fashioned ice-cream parlours and perfumed ladies in vintage cars. The palate’s silky mango mouth-feel, with mandarin, raspberry tart and lemon cream is pure nectar – perfumed honey sweetness laced with angels’ tears – enough to inspire romantic, other-worldly thoughts. With water, the nose defies description the way some people defy gravity – as tempting as a perfumed apple in the Garden of Eden. The palate’s exquisite balance might be the most alluring thing this side of the stratosphere.
https://www.smws.com/a-toast-to-tim-peak.drinking_tip: A perfect Welcome Home dram – especially after a long absence.
https://www.smws.com/a-toast-to-tim-peak.name: A toast to Tim Peake’s return

https://www.smws.com/a-well-mannered-dra.description: Considering the provenance, this struck our noses as a gentle, attractive and well-mannered dram – lemon bonbons, golden syrup, rhubarb rock, stewed apples and vanilla custard – fresh, fruity and floral – an evocation of Spring. The palate was a lively, intense, ‘tap-dancing on the tongue’ experience, tart apple skins, orange zest, light spices and salt balanced by butterscotch, caramel and peanut brittle sweetness. On the reduced nose, the freshness was now floral perfumes and pebble beaches, with soft toffee, orange oil and cough mixture. The palate now found and displayed its natural barley sweetness, improving the balanced and making it moreishly drinkable.
https://www.smws.com/a-well-mannered-dra.drinking_tip: With your sweetheart in the spring-time – park bench or pebble beach picnic.
https://www.smws.com/a-well-mannered-dra.name: A well-mannered dram

https://www.smws.com/after-hours.description: We all got very hungry nosing this one. Aromas of lamb tagine spiced with cinnamon and cumin and served on couscous with dates, next to rosemary braised red cabbage accompanied by kabanos and for pudding butter pecan almond milk frozen dessert. The taste was hot, sweet and spicy like a Garam masala mix with cloves, cassia bark, nutmeg, cardamom and white peppercorns. Water added salt to the menu, saltpetre cured ham with roasted carrots and a tangy Tzatziki pasta salad. Still not hungry? The flavour was that of a pork souvlaki with fried garlic bread and lemons.
https://www.smws.com/after-hours.name: After hours

https://www.smws.com/after-the-rain.description: We all agreed that a very strong perfumed aroma was the dominant factor on the nose neat. However the way we described the scent varied considerably; wood glue, spring meadow furniture polish, mango incense sticks, damp wine cellar and last, but certainly not least a coconut shea butter aromatic candle. Fiery and flavoursome on the palate; apricot and ginger frangipane tart, raspberry pepper jam and macadamia nut, coconut & white chocolate blondies made this a real experience. Diluted, like an aromatic rose garden in full bloom after the rain and on the palate lush, creamy and mouth-watering – an absolute delight!
https://www.smws.com/after-the-rain.name: After the rain

https://www.smws.com/alfresco-brunch.description: We were having a Picnic Brunch in a meadow; the sun had almost burnt off the morning dew and we were looking forward to a glorious day outside. Out of the basket came smoked salmon, gravlax and a bowl of fresh watermelon and Cantaloupe salad with mint and basil vinaigrette. The taste was satisfyingly sweet, like dipping a wooden spoon into a jar of heather honey or a glass of delicious viscous mead. Just a drop of water and meaty aromas appeared; eggs Benedict with bacon, gingerbread pancakes with Parma ham and the taste turned into a spicy salami pizza.
https://www.smws.com/alfresco-brunch.name: Alfresco brunch

https://www.smws.com/all-the-fun-of-the-.description: Alluring fairground aromas captivated us right from the start. The scent of buttered popcorn, candy floss, toffee apples, marshmallows, honeycomb lollipops as well as fudge and Turkish delight got us all very excited and we moved on to the food stalls. We ordered a hot dog in a bun with cream cheese and a piquant sweet chili sauce with fresh horseradish coleslaw on the side. After a drop of water we bought caramel custard doughnuts and waffles with hot chocolate sauce and a cinnamon dusting washing it all down with a fizzy refreshing rose mint green iced tea.
https://www.smws.com/all-the-fun-of-the-.name: All the fun of the fair

https://www.smws.com/an-amazing-technico.description: We had, from the word go, the colour pink in our heads; homemade pink lemonade, pink wafer biscuits, pink party rings, ‘Pink Charm’ mountain laurel in a privy hedge and a ‘Touch of Pink’ ladies Eau de Toilette. That pink became red hot chili pepper on the palate neat with the addition of golden yellow spicy Jamaican banana fritters and freshly squeezed lime juice. Water added aromas of brown sugar vanilla ice cream, lemon puffs and red cherry flapjacks. The taste turned into blueberry and lemon millefeuille and red raspberry jam, with the refreshing finish of green sugar coated fennel seeds.
https://www.smws.com/an-amazing-technico.drinking_tip: Life is not black and white
https://www.smws.com/an-amazing-technico.name: An amazing technicolour dram

https://www.smws.com/an-apothecary-on-a-.description: A curious dram – the unreduced nose had sanded wood and light, clean smoke suggesting first aid boxes and apothecaries, menthol-suffused saunas, liquorice, porridge and smokehouse timber – even some ocean spray and light engine oil. With water we got beach barbeques and cooked fish, pineapple on gammon, pan-drops, hospital laundries and motorcycle workshops. The initial taste found travel sweets, menthol cigarettes, burnt sticks, spicy fennel seed sausages and smoked mussels – served by a swimming pool or in a hospital emergency room. Adding water brought about a satisfying mix of sweetness and light smoke, with hints of salt, embers and bicycle repair kits.
https://www.smws.com/an-apothecary-on-a-.drinking_tip: In a tasting, this would ease the transition from non-smoky to smoky drams – or whenever a lightly peated whisky is desired.
https://www.smws.com/an-apothecary-on-a-.name: An apothecary on a motorcycle

https://www.smws.com/an-apothecary-shop-.description: Our medical man had set up shop with gauze, elastoplast, witch-hazel, Tiger balm and hippy shop essential oils for good measure. Sooty bacon sandwiches, lemon curd and ginger cake on the nose before an intense blast of peat, dried rosemary and thyme. Medical shampoo (in a bizarrely pleasing way), BBQ sauce on burnt bacon rind dusted with ash, cardamom pods in cream cheese frosting and chilli chocolate. Water opened up a seaside hospital with plimsolls, freshly ironed linen and coal tar soap. Engine stoker's wellies and sizzling steak on distant campfires before lingering iodine, dusty hedgehog crisps and fennel seeds.
https://www.smws.com/an-apothecary-shop-.name: An apothecary shop on the shore

https://www.smws.com/an-explosion-of-pla.description: The nose was light and mild – fruity, sweet aromas of flying saucers, sherbet, Edinburgh Rock, vanilla, limoncello, grapefruit and talc were prevented from wafting away on the breeze by a ballast of pine, tree bark, basketry and cinnamon spice. The palate was youthful and lively; fizzy sherbet and ‘popping candy mixed with gunpowder’ exploded on our tongues – flavours included lemon, orange zest and yellow jelly babies – maybe a hint of perfumed bath bombs. With water, the nose found flowers, wood sap, lipstick and tea. The palate, now more playful than lively, suggested yellow coconut Liquorice Allsorts and cakes in waxed paper.
https://www.smws.com/an-explosion-of-pla.drinking_tip: As a palate cleanser – or in place of sparkling wine at a celebration.
https://www.smws.com/an-explosion-of-pla.name: An explosion of playfulness

https://www.smws.com/an-old-sea-dog.description: A gentle, mature nose, with only light prickle. Carbolic and coal tar soap, and only a suggestion of smoke to begin with: crispy smoked bacon, prawns on a barbeque, fried onions. Sweet and soft to taste, slightly salty and lightly smoky in the finish (“a tweed jacket, after standing close to a bonfire”), with hemp ropes in the aftertaste. The latter scent emerges clearly with a dash of water - dry hessian, bung cloth – then a clutch of ‘natural’ scents – bog myrtle, dried herbs, moorland, putty – backed by “soapy washing in an Islay burn”, pork scratchings, roast shallots and an old sea-chest. A faintly waxy texture, lightly cooling; a sweet taste with a trace of smoke. Seems older than it is.
https://www.smws.com/an-old-sea-dog.name: An old sea-dog

https://www.smws.com/an-old-tar.description: Once you get past the nose-prickle, the scent is reminiscent of the rubber-bands inside a golf ball but quickly becomes medicinal (Germoline cream), with tinned fruit cocktail, waxed jacket and lactic cows. The taste starts sweet and finishes like bitter Colombian coffee, with ‘a warm hot water bottle’ in the middle and coal dust in the aftertaste. Water increases the water-bottle note slightly, then introduces Bavarian smoked cheese, smoked sausage and synthetic ham wrapped in linen, with lingering coal dust. The taste is very sweet, lightly salty and vinegary, with smoked dulse and sweetened hot milk, finishing with ‘Finnish Tar Syrup’
https://www.smws.com/an-old-tar.drinking_tip: To accompany a plate of smoked meats
https://www.smws.com/an-old-tar.name: An old tar

https://www.smws.com/apples-in-the-cella.description: Peering behind the flimsy curtain of lively, spirity alcohol, we found caramel wafers and coconut biscuits, honey on wood, tarte tatin, apple, peach, vanilla ice-cream and some fresh floral perfumes. The unreduced palate had attractive, perfumed apples and brown sugar on peaches, with some nice, mouth-numbing woody spices (nutmeg, clove and liquorice). The reduced nose had candied angelica, melon and custard creams; one panellist imagined an apple store in a musty cold cellar. We thought water improved the palate, by managing to balance the bright, slightly bitter apple strudel fruitiness with drier woody notes of cinnamon and coltsfoot rock.
https://www.smws.com/apples-in-the-cella.drinking_tip: Before and after having to visit the spooky cellar.
https://www.smws.com/apples-in-the-cella.name: Apples in the cellar

https://www.smws.com/arabian-nights.description: A fragile nose, delicately scented with rose petals, face cream, expensive soap and after-shave balm. Soon were transported (by magic carpet) to a Persian garden at night, with musk, jasmine and sandalwood. The taste is drier than the nose suggests - traces of hemp ('soap-on-a rope'?) after the sweetish start, with hessian in the lingering aftertaste. A couple of drops of water open up the perfume (joined by green cloves) as and re-awaken the Arabian nights fantasy - now we were in an evening oasis with canvas tents and, yes, Turkish Delight. The diluted taste is flatter, however: the whisky is too delicate for water. The distillery was bought by a French spirits company in 2008.
https://www.smws.com/arabian-nights.name: Arabian Nights

https://www.smws.com/aristocratic-preten.description: The nose balanced brown sugar and syrupy sweetness with pear-drops, green apple, lime in a beer bottle and lemon drizzle cake; one panellist remembered polishing furniture and ‘cleaning the family silver’ (no doubt in his stately home). Also clean on the palate – washing up liquid and sweet green tea – then Maltesers and ‘lucky tatties’ (sweet cinnamon) – ginger and pepper to finish. The reduced nose continued sweet (syrup sponge, tray-bake in a church hall) and fruity (bitter lemon, peach-flavoured iced tea, grilled pineapple). The palate was now gentle and relaxing, with sweet and tart suggestions of lemon curd and upside-down pineapple cake.
https://www.smws.com/aristocratic-preten.drinking_tip: Gently uplifting – could be a reward for minor to middling achievements (like polishing the family silver).
https://www.smws.com/aristocratic-preten.name: Aristocratic pretensions

https://www.smws.com/around-the-world.description: The mellow, inviting, sugary sweetness of Scottish tablet and Russian toffee combined with a decadent American white chocolate milkshake and a black bun filled with raisins, currants, sultanas soaked in Caribbean rum; it felt like being around the world in 80 seconds. The taste had a lot to offer; cinnamon vanilla sponge cake, Bourbon and custard cream biscuits as well as Mexican wedding cakes (vanilla, powdered sugar, finely chopped almonds and pecans). Diluted; toffee fudge bananas with toasted nuts whilst on the palate, vanilla bean Belgium waffles with whipped cream and two classic cocktails; Mai Tai and Blue Hawaiian.
https://www.smws.com/around-the-world.drinking_tip: Sitting in a wing back chair planning your holiday in the sun
https://www.smws.com/around-the-world.name: Around the world

https://www.smws.com/artists-and-antique.description: Imagine an old shop full of well-polished antique furniture and cigar boxes muddled in with emulsion paint and starch. There were baked apples and pears in a basement then warm sponge cake, jammy dodgers, extra strong mints and ripe melon. The taste was delicate with coconut orange macaroons, mango coulis and expensive dark chocolate, then treacle tart, butter toffee and walnuts. Water revealed more elegance with ink stained leather desks, old sandal wood pencil cases, animal pelts and dusty books in the attic. Our artist paused for hot orange juice with jaffa cakes, cream buns and rye bread with apricot jam.
https://www.smws.com/artists-and-antique.name: Artists and antique shops

https://www.smws.com/attractive-rounded-.description: The nose was impressive – rich, attractive, rounded and comforting – clear toffee, cinder toffee, orange jelly, orange peel, tangerine, honey on crumpets, popcorn, blackcurrant concentrate, polished wood, leather, hessian and straw. The palate had seductive sweetness – orange fondants, Battenberg cake, dark marmalade and Werthers, with clove, ginger and chilli warmth and notes of oak, pine and old books. The reduced nose was mellower and sweeter, with crème de cassis, apricot Danish, physalis, baked apple, pink wafers and Fablon. The palate became tropical, juicy, fruity and delicious – dark toffee, Terry’s dark chocolate orange and Black Jack chews, with subtle spiciness to finish.
https://www.smws.com/attractive-rounded-.drinking_tip: A sunset dram for out of doors or a slipper dram inside
https://www.smws.com/attractive-rounded-.name: Attractive, rounded and comforting

https://www.smws.com/autumn-feelings.description: This dram evoked autumnal feelings in us all, even though slightly different ones. From walking in woodland searching for blackberries and mushrooms to grape harvesting on a warm afternoon and picking apples in an orchard; eventually we all celebrated harvest festival. For that we were eating plum, orange and almond cobbler, toffee apples, caramelised pears and pumpkin pie. With water the first signs of winter appeared, the cool wind and the comforting aromas of spiced hot apple cider and vanilla scented candles drew us inside enjoying a cherry pie with a nutty crumb crust and real whipped cream.
https://www.smws.com/autumn-feelings.name: Autumn feelings

https://www.smws.com/avuncular-intrigue.description: Mmm – an intriguing nose – dusty tobacco, menthol, smouldering garden bonfires, bee smokers, cricket pavilions, candle wax, scampi in a basket... the oily, coastal nature came through with water – swimming pools, salted fish, coal fires, matches, salt and vinegar crisps and a watch-maker’s workshop. It is on the palate that we found evidence of its age – sweet tobacco, cigar boxes, vanilla, chips wrapped in magazine pages, wood ash and liquorice – we found it comforting in an avuncular way. The reduced palate discovered sweet chocolate biscuits, burnt caramel, toffee and milky tea, with hints of malt, salt and vinegar keeping the intrigue going.
https://www.smws.com/avuncular-intrigue.name: Avuncular intrigue

https://www.smws.com/back-to-primary-sch.description: The nose was light, bright, citric, lively and youthful – evoking primary school scenes for some of us – felt-tip pens, poster paints, Flumps, drumstick lollies, fruit salad chews and Jammie Dodgers. The neat palate had some distinctive confectionery notes – Oddfellows, summer creams, sherbet lemons – also pink wafers, peach cordial and hints of vanilla – more adult themes included Buck’s Fizz and mojitos. The reduced nose had peach schnapps, travel sweets, vanilla custard slice, perfumed hand lotion and chopped up kindling sticks. The reduced palate was simple and straightforward – peaches and cream and vanilla sweetness with a wee fizzy tingle in the tail
https://www.smws.com/back-to-primary-sch.drinking_tip: A bit of a garden party dram – lazy, laid-back summer time fun.
https://www.smws.com/back-to-primary-sch.name: Back to primary school - EXCLUSIVE TO OFFERS

https://www.smws.com/baked-alaska.description:
Limited Preview Release 29 Feb
Mail Order Exclusive 
The nose neat was fresh and fizzy with a sweet/fruity dominance which led us to a Buck’s Fizz cocktail using one part pink champagne and two parts freshly squeezed orange juice. Another cocktail comparison was a New Orleans Fizz containing gin, lemon and lime juice, orange flower water, sugar, cream, egg white and soda water. The mouthfeel followed along the same theme; fizzy, bubbly, sparkling pineapple flavoured soda water and dried fruits in a cream sauce. With water a classic vanilla slice, mango ice cream and chocolate covered marshmallows whilst the taste was that of a baked Alaska with chocolate ice cream.
https://www.smws.com/baked-alaska.name: Baked Alaska - Available Online Only

https://www.smws.com/banana-walnut-cornb.description: The nose neat was clean and fresh, but at the same time invitingly rich, like a newly, well-polished wooden bar top. In time, a seductive sweetness developed; candied almonds, toffee apples, fondant fancies and a quality ice wine. Given its age the taste was surprisingly vibrant with a ginger, chilli heat but again the attractive sweetness of caramel apple cake and lemon blossom honey. Water released honey porridge, scones with clotted cream and toasted flaked almonds. On the palate now a dry spiciness of banana walnut cornbread and cinnamon rolls, all washed down with a sparkling elderflower fizz.
https://www.smws.com/banana-walnut-cornb.drinking_tip: After dinner playing snooker or pool
https://www.smws.com/banana-walnut-cornb.name: Banana walnut cornbread

https://www.smws.com/barbeque-glaze.description: Pungent with sulphur and smoke to start, then develops a meaty/gamey scent – ‘beef flavoured Monster Munch’, said one panellist; barbequed steak glazed with HP Sauce. The taste is sweet, with tar and struck matches; the barbeque glazed is now treacle, the HP Sauce now Branston Pickle. Water increases the intensity of sulphur (struck matches) and smoke (coal smoke, starting a fire). At reduced strength it has a thick texture, a sweet start, charred sausage in the middle and the smoke now limited to the finish. A surprising mentholic coolness is apparent in the aftertaste. Simple but powerful.
https://www.smws.com/barbeque-glaze.drinking_tip: Tail-gating at an American football game
https://www.smws.com/barbeque-glaze.name: Barbeque glaze

https://www.smws.com/barnacles-and-bath-.description: The panel imagined a pork roast scented with lavender and sun dried tomatoes with balsamic. Then warm leather, sticky molasses and tamarind paste before salt crusted barnacles emerged with fragrant peaty smoke. Time teased out toffee caramel and heather honey. To taste, they found layers of flavour: pickled ginger with pink grapefruit, lavender bath bombs, chocolate, peat and warm leather saddle. Water livened up proceedings with mint, blackcurrant pastille, kaffir limes leaves and damp seaweed. More pork and lavender tangled with a whiff of match smoke with fish wrapped in nori, and perfumed wood, mint and basil in the finale.
https://www.smws.com/barnacles-and-bath-.drinking_tip: The panel preferred it at full strength
https://www.smws.com/barnacles-and-bath-.name: Barnacles and bath bombs

https://www.smws.com/beach-bonfires-cree.description: The nose offered some biscuity sweetness, Victory V’s, apple, lemon and ginger, but the main event was a landscape of bonfires on stony beaches, creels, boats, fried fish, teriyaki mackerel, smoky bacon and marine mechanic’s overalls. The palate was more complex and sophisticated – Parma violets, liquorice and dried fruits; florally perfumed smoke and lemon and salt beside a feast of langoustines, oysters and adobo style marinated fish. The reduced nose had tarry driftwood, pencil leads, Lapsang Souchong, orange zest, sugared almonds and cigarillos, while the palate now presented a joyous balance of sweetness and smoke, alongside tasty fruits and seafood.
https://www.smws.com/beach-bonfires-cree.drinking_tip: This could inspire imaginative and creative recipes and food pairings.
https://www.smws.com/beach-bonfires-cree.name: Beach bonfires, creels and boats

https://www.smws.com/beach-huts-boatyard.description: On the nose we found some sweetness (donuts, chocolate-coated nuts, fondant creams) but it was really all about smoke, Savlon, muscle rub, dried seaweed, tarry driftwood and new tarmac roads. The palate was a sweetness and smoke sensation – ‘Takes no prisoners!’ said one panellist, but we agreed it was mouth-drawing and delicious – spicy smoke, charcoal, hot ash, sugar-coated fennel seeds, liquorice, absinth and dark chocolate. The reduced nose evoked creosoted beach huts, boatyards and Calmac ferries. The palate was now gum-smackingly salty, sweet, smoky and sharp – industrial smoke, aniseed gobstoppers and lavender, with rosemary, sea-salt and coal on the finish.
https://www.smws.com/beach-huts-boatyard.drinking_tip: Hip flask on a ferry to Islay – essence of the Hebrides.
https://www.smws.com/beach-huts-boatyard.name: Beach huts, boatyards and ferries - Exclusive to August Peaty Trio

https://www.smws.com/beachcomber-s-dram.description: The unreduced nose evoked various suggestions from the panel – warm hay bales, rum-soaked sultanas, ginger cake, honey drizzled on fried bananas, Thai prawns and a new car. The palate was robust, sinewy and youthful, but we had no trouble enjoying its hot, sweet flavours neat – dark chocolate, pineapple, mango and gooseberry; Liquorice Allsorts ice-cream (is there such a thing?); bacon rolls and balsamic reduction. The reduced nose found light smoke, quite a bit of vanilla, burnt toast and wood and plastic gathered on a pebble beach. The reduced palate suggested scorched rhubarb, dark sugar and pepper and salt on fried food.
https://www.smws.com/beachcomber-s-dram.drinking_tip: One to take wild camping – on the coast
https://www.smws.com/beachcomber-s-dram.name: Beachcomber’s dram

https://www.smws.com/beauty-and-the-beas.description: A variety, as well as degrees in intensity, of smoke; smoky bacon, honey glazed chicken breasts barbequed over hickory wood chips, stone hearth with a whole pig on a spit turning, pan-fried pancetta, smoked salted caramels and a Bavarian smoked beer. The taste was like entering the smoke engulfed living room of a blackhouse on the Outer Hebrides cooking a not very regional dish of chipotle, beef and bean chilli. With a drop of water aromas of creosote soap, Tiger Balm red ointment, wood glue and slightly singed wellie boots appeared and the taste was ‘gamey’ venison and pheasant stew in red wine.
https://www.smws.com/beauty-and-the-beas.name: Beauty and the Beast

https://www.smws.com/bee-smoker-on-a-peb.description: We detected something of the sea on the nose – fresh oysters, a pebble beach, boat-decks and rush matting in a fisherman’s cottage. Beyond that we got gooseberry and lemon, salted caramel and bubble-gum bonbons – maybe also some bacon crisps. The palate was deliciously smoky, salty and floral – violets, lavender and sherbet straws, with dry earthy spices and an almost coal-dust minerality. The reduced nose evoked swimming pools in exotic parks or gardens, scented candles, dried seaweed and burnt paper in a bee-smoker. The palate had become a sweet, smoky, floral delight, with burnt flower bouquets and honey on charred staves.
https://www.smws.com/bee-smoker-on-a-peb.name: Bee-smoker on a pebble beach

https://www.smws.com/big-personality-no-.description: The nose was deep and rich (like a millionaire’s pockets), with tarry ropes and wet-suits on a pier, a night-club bouncer’s leather trousers and sneakers, struck match, Germolene, syrup of figs, Branston pickle, balsamic and embers from a seafood barbeque. The neat palate was salty, smoky and sweet – a big personality of a dram delivering sweet pickled onions, anchovies, burnt raisins, treacle, bonfire ash, sherry and biltong. The reduced nose found mussels, sea water and wet sand with a hint of new leather. The palate became softer and sweeter (but still no pussy-cat) – raisins and lemon peel in a fruit cake.
https://www.smws.com/big-personality-no-.drinking_tip: With food – even a fish and chip shop takeaway
https://www.smws.com/big-personality-no-.name: Big personality (no pussy-cat)

https://www.smws.com/bon-appetit.description: Aromas of smoky bacon crisps, bacon frazzles, pork cracklings and freshly grilled streaky bacon immediately sprang to mind nosing neat. Once the hunger pains receded we also detected lemon zest, new pine and a hint of lavender. The taste did not disappoint; a well-made double bacon butty with lots of butter and seasoned with ketchup and mustard, but at the same time a remarkably sweet smooth maple syrup finish. Water released fresh, minty, slightly salty and oily aromas now nicely balanced with a slightly more apparent floral scent of lavender. In the taste now incredibly sweet; like ‘La galette des rois’– Bon Appétit.
https://www.smws.com/bon-appetit.name: Bon Appétit

https://www.smws.com/booze-soaked-fruits.description: We all agreed at the first nosing that something was soaked in booze; rum-soaked raisin biscotti, crème brulee with whisky soaked sultanas or dried fruits soaked in Pedro Ximenez Sherry for a Christmas pudding. There were fresher notes appearing as well; cider ice lollies and Granny Smith apple sorbet. The taste came as a bit of a surprise; chips wrapped in yesterday’s newspaper with plenty of salt, vinegar and brown sauce sprinkled all over. Water added an earthy fruitiness like picking strawberries, drinking Champagne and green apples wrapped in waxed paper. The taste now thick, sweet and moreish - a well-made honey and plum brandy.
https://www.smws.com/booze-soaked-fruits.name: Booze soaked fruits

https://www.smws.com/booze-up-in-a-baker.description: Big, bold aromas of brandy soaked sponge and rum baba jostled with anise and muscovado sugar. Shiny red apples dipped in hard toffee and honey roasted pecan nuts, then buttery gingerbread and marmalade on toast. The panel found the taste curious with juicy scrumpy cider then spicy whisky sours with hints of peppermint. Water opened a wooden box of bruised apples for one, oranges and sultanas in a school desk, for another. They found lemon cheesecake, buttercream icing and root ginger beer. This continued with crystalised ginger in syrup and Jamaica cake with hints of tingling eucalyptus and marzipan.
https://www.smws.com/booze-up-in-a-baker.name: Booze up in a bakery

https://www.smws.com/brave-the-elements.description: We were transported to a gun deck aboard a ship during a naval battle in the Napoleonic Wars. It was hot, dirty and oily; canons constantly loaded and fired, the ship got hit by a broadside, seamen received some emergency medical attention. The scene was one of blood, sweat and tears with salt, gun powder and burning wood, filling the entire core of your body. Eventually the engagement ended and with a drop of water we started to clean the deck, the ship’s doctors could deal with the wounded from the battle and we enjoyed that sweet taste of victory.
https://www.smws.com/brave-the-elements.name: Brave the elements

https://www.smws.com/brunch-with-a-diffe.description: We all got very hungry nosing neat. From salt and vinegar crisps, spiced rice with smoked kippers and Peshwari naan, to salmon fishcake and glazed gammon steak with pineapple, finishing with a zesty lemon cheesecake. The taste was like chocolates filled with a nutty cream ganache infused with peat smoke, followed by a vanilla ice-cream sundae with hot fudge and caramel sauce whilst in the long finish, surprisingly, grilled bacon. Water did not help, aromas of damp Barbour jackets, liquid colours for airbrushing models and burnt apple tart appeared. The taste now of hot dogs in brine and cheese straws with smoked Dunlop.
https://www.smws.com/brunch-with-a-diffe.name: Brunch with a difference

https://www.smws.com/builders-at-breakti.description: There wasn’t anything delicate about this, and the panel were in conflict. Chips wrapped in warm newspaper, meaty broth and malty drink tangled with turpentine and oily engines. Tea break continued with sweet dough balls covered in dark chocolate sauce, then espresso with cinnamon sprinkles. The bad boys broke off their cement mixing to have a cheeky shot of tequila with the salt and lime. They nibbled twiggy crisps, crunchy peanut brittle and garibaldi biscuits and put their tools down for the day. The panel couldn’t agree if the builders went wild camping or to a coal cellar.
https://www.smws.com/builders-at-breakti.name: Builders at breaktime

https://www.smws.com/burnt-buttered-bann.description: We were camping on a sandy beach waking up with memories of rosemary lamb cooked over a peat fired barbeque the night before (still in the air), but soon replaced by aromas of freshly brewed coffee. The coffee, plus the explosion of sweet, floral heather peat smoke on the palate, surely woke us up! – “the taste was just like salted buttered burnt Bannock bread”. With a drop of water we went on a coastal walk along chalk cliffs and enjoyed, at lunch time, a mouth coating smoky tropical fruit salad as well as a glass of refreshing crisp Riesling wine.
https://www.smws.com/burnt-buttered-bann.name: Burnt buttered bannock bread

https://www.smws.com/bursting-with-inter.description: A lovely nose, bursting with interest and imaginings – one panellist found a perfumed leather handbag, while another detected a French polisher’s after-shave; also rum and raisin toffee, vanilla slice, acacia blossom honey, Sandalwood, sherry-soaked sultanas and Calvados. The palate’s first impression was exotic, perfumed fruits (ripe mango, monstera, rhubarb rock) but the hinterland was equally exciting – Christmas pudding, leather and flowers, with integrated tannins from a solid backbone of oak. The reduced nose delivered Haribo Tangfastics, rose Turkish Delight, Pineau de Charentes and a Caribbean fruit punch you could dive into. The palate now suggested contented jelly babies guzzling dessert wine.
https://www.smws.com/bursting-with-inter.drinking_tip: One to sip while watching ladies beach volleyball in the Caribbean
https://www.smws.com/bursting-with-inter.name: Bursting with interest and imaginings

https://www.smws.com/busy-buzzing-bees.description: A light, sweet and floral aroma greeted the Panel. Sugar dusted fruit flavoured bonbons and candy corn were mentioned before a picture full of promise emerged; sitting in the garden sipping on a Lemon Drop Martini and listening to the bees buzzing in the laurel hedge. The taste had honey-roasted peaches with lavender ice cream whilst the overall impression was one of an almost perfect balance between delicate, perfumed sweetness and dry wood spice. A drop of water and a plate of seafood pasta in a creamy marinara sauce and a glass of chilled, slightly mineralic, Riesling Auslese was being served.
https://www.smws.com/busy-buzzing-bees.drinking_tip: Perfect to replace a dessert wine
https://www.smws.com/busy-buzzing-bees.name: Busy buzzing bees

https://www.smws.com/c-est-magnifique.description: What an amazing myriad of aromas, too many to mention them all, let’s give it a bash! Marzipan, nutmeg, orange oil, old vintage Armagnac, parmesan shavings, salty creamy blue cheese, buttery shortbread and Chinese crispy sugary and salty seaweed. On the palate, we stay in Asia; sesame Teriyaki chicken salad and vegetable tempura with a soya dipping sauce. With water, we enjoyed a salad Nicoise with a perfect vinaigrette dressing on a yacht off the south of France – c’est magnifique! After 34 years in an ex-bourbon hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/c-est-magnifique.name: C’est Magnifique! - Free Usige Water Triple Pack with this bottle

https://www.smws.com/cheerful-childhood-.description: The nose offered marshmallows, bubble-gum, toffee, chocolate Turkish Delight and colourful fruity ice-lollies – full of cheerful childhood memories; it also had mashed banana, bread and butter pudding and daffodils lying on sawdust. The palate was vibrant, intense and tasty – sweetness (honeycomb crunch chocolate, sweet porridge, rhubarb rock) tempered by sherbet, gooseberry, lemon and lime sorbet and hints of leather. The reduced nose had brown sugar on grapefruit, glacé cherries and preserved lemons in a tagine. The palate was now enticing and attractive – pineapple, pear, Swizzels double lollies and Moffat toffees with traces of wood and tobacco in the finish.
https://www.smws.com/cheerful-childhood-.drinking_tip: A pleasant aperitif – or when in a Kojak, lolly sucking mood
https://www.smws.com/cheerful-childhood-.name: Cheerful childhood memories

https://www.smws.com/cherries-chocolate-.description: The neat nose intrigued with ever-changing aromas - from dark cherries, PVA glue, baked apples and cinnamon, to melted crayons, dates, foamy bananas and leather armchairs, but no kitchen sink! Sweet, bitter, oily and waxy notes all graced the palate, bringing taste sensations of Grand Marnier liqueur and hazelnut wine followed by a parsley stalk aftertaste. The reduced nose welcomed us with dark chocolate (most notably Terry's Chocolate Orange) then offered an array of Indian flavours - chai tea at first then cumin and spicy scented wood. Samosas and curry powder adorned the palate with hints of lavender and an effervescent fizz, all culminating in a sweet, satisfying finish.
https://www.smws.com/cherries-chocolate-.drinking_tip: Try pairing with rich and spicy foods for some great flavour combinations
https://www.smws.com/cherries-chocolate-.name: Cherries, chocolate and chai

https://www.smws.com/chim-chim-cher-ee.description: All sorts of liquorice on the nose neat to start before we moved on, walking along a road where new asphalt was being laid down and you received a ‘lucky kiss’ from a chimney sweep! The taste was thick, sticky and smoky with plenty of dark fruits and a powerful cough syrup in the finish. That medicinal side appeared more pronounced when adding water and even diluted on the palate still big, massive and dark, like a moonless night sky. After 9 years in an ex-bourbon refill hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a white wine cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/chim-chim-cher-ee.drinking_tip: In a dark and stormy night
https://www.smws.com/chim-chim-cher-ee.name: ‘Chim, chim, cher-ee’

https://www.smws.com/choc-a-l-orange.description: “It’s like being in an orange grove at Christmas”, one panellist suggested. Sweet and warm fruits of pineapple and dried orange skin mingled with crystalized ginger, cloves, nutmeg and allspice. Then heady notes of fresh roses, honeysuckle and sweet peas with parsnips, perhaps roasted with sticky honey. The underlying heat of fresh ginger continued but now alongside fennel, aniseed and a sweet mouth-coating oiliness of duck a l’orange whilst both milk and dark chocolate combined. After 14 years in an ex-bourbon hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/choc-a-l-orange.drinking_tip: Whilst having a midsummer Christmas in the tropics
https://www.smws.com/choc-a-l-orange.name: Choc a l’orange

https://www.smws.com/coconut-oil-and-can.description: The Panel found lots of lemon zest on sliced cooking apples, gentle vanilla and freshly sanded oak planks. Summer sizzled with coconut oil sun cream as candy floss vans did a roaring trade at a funfair. Chalky, dusty notes followed; dry ice, “beating a rug in a spring garden” and lemon sherbet powder. To taste; the intense sweetness of pink wafers, Ready Brek with red jam, warm buttered crumpets and stewed pears with soft and rich vanilla. “Totally tropical!” with water. Mandarin, nectarine, rich mango coulis and vanilla macerated strawberries. Milk lollies, rainbow drops and fruit pavlova to finish.
https://www.smws.com/coconut-oil-and-can.drinking_tip: At a sunny funfair, but avoid the waltzers…
https://www.smws.com/coconut-oil-and-can.name: Coconut oil and candy floss

https://www.smws.com/coconut-panna-cotta.description: An array of fruity aromas came to mind; passion fruit, freshly sliced mango, pineapple juice, raspberry coulis as well as lemon, orange, and cherry flavoured hard candies called Campino. It was a truly mouth filling experience neat with flavours of candied lemon peel and spiced wood next to blackcurrant jam and spiced persimmon frozen yoghurt, whilst in the finish a Crème de Menthe on the rocks. Diluted, we found ourselves sitting on a newly varnished wooden bench in the sunshine drinking a ‘Five Alive’ fruit juice whilst eating fresh fruit salad with cream and a coconut panna cotta with pineapple salsa.
https://www.smws.com/coconut-panna-cotta.drinking_tip: Will take you to a sunny place
https://www.smws.com/coconut-panna-cotta.name: Coconut panna cotta

https://www.smws.com/comfort-and-emotion.description: We found a very interesting nose – elderflower and milky dandelion, manuka honey, ripe peaches and ‘picking strawberries on a warm day’ – another panellist got ‘milk chocolate smeared on chewed cot bars’. The palate was sweet, fruity and spicy – bramble jelly, passion fruit and a well-known tropical fruit drink – but with sustained oaky, spicy warmth coming through – cinnamon, pepper and chocolate ginger biscuits. The reduced nose suggested comfort and emotional warmth – apple pie in a basket and coconut sun-tan lotion on a sun-warmed wooden jetty. The palate was deliciously sweet and tart and juicy – sherbet straws, apple strudel, wine gums and pomegranate.
https://www.smws.com/comfort-and-emotion.drinking_tip: A perfect escape dram for the dark days of winter.
https://www.smws.com/comfort-and-emotion.name: Comfort and emotional warmth

https://www.smws.com/comfortable-in-the-.description: This invited the panel into an old house with evocative aromas of persian rugs and a spice cupboard. It coaxed them to sink into the Chesterfield with a hot toddy laced with orange oil. It had a reassuring warmth of camphor and Tiger balm. Delicate floral notes mingled with pine resin and pastry notes. The spice level at full strength was like licking sandalwood polished with linseed oil. With water, plum sauce and more exotic spiciness developed. Pomegranate seeds and pencil boxes. It had a velvety toffee texture and finished with pressed flowers and white pepper in the finish.
https://www.smws.com/comfortable-in-the-.drinking_tip: Treat with kid gloves and careful with water
https://www.smws.com/comfortable-in-the-.name: Comfortable in the Chesterfield

https://www.smws.com/comfortably-smoky.description: Uncompromisingly phenolic: coal tar soap, carbolic, Germoline, faded creosote – becoming more caramelised in time, and more mellow with water – musty and smoky (an old-fashioned steam engine came to mind, a remote coal fire), also a ‘cocktail cabinet’ note, which combined old wine and orange liqueurs. At natural strength the taste is very sweet and very smoky, with traces of seaweed: big and powerful. At reduced strength it has an attractive buttery mouthfeel – still sweet, now salty, with a smoky finish: ‘sweet and salty Butterkist popcorn’. A full-on Islay, heavy, peaty, comforting.
https://www.smws.com/comfortably-smoky.drinking_tip: While watching the Islay lifeboat return safely
https://www.smws.com/comfortably-smoky.name: Comfortably smoky

https://www.smws.com/comfy-slippers-o-cl.description: The panellists sat back and relaxed to the calming aromas of cherry blossom, tea tree oil, ylang-ylang and nutmeg whilst in the dunnage warehouse. Then soft fruits of strawberry, raspberry and mandarin segments laced with cooling menthol. Donning our favourite slippers it was time for plum tarts sprinkled with desiccated coconut, strawberry laces and a choice of either peach liquor with champagne, iced fruit tea or a Bloody Mary with its layers of lemon zest and spice, perhaps red peppercorns giving a tingly effervescence. To finish, a delightful liquorice note along with juicy wood spice.
https://www.smws.com/comfy-slippers-o-cl.drinking_tip: A reward at the end of a hard day at work.
https://www.smws.com/comfy-slippers-o-cl.name: Comfy slippers o’clock

https://www.smws.com/concerto-zenzero.description: The nose opened with a fanfare – trumpets of biscuits (ginger biscuits, iced gems) and drum-rolls of cake (lemon drizzle cake, iced gingerbread) – the celebratory theme continued with cinder toffee, pineapple chunks and Cadbury Roses strawberry creams. The unreduced palate offered vanilla, chocolate and lemon but the tongue-nipping heat was much more demanding of attention – chilli, cinnamon, lots of ginger and some dry, bitter woody notes at the end. The reduced nose was a concerto, with ginger the solo instrument, supported by marshmallows, toffee and stewed apple and rhubarb. The reduced palate balanced its sweetness much better with the wood and spice.
https://www.smws.com/concerto-zenzero.drinking_tip: A fireside dram – or to warm you up after being out in the cold.
https://www.smws.com/concerto-zenzero.name: Concerto zenzero

https://www.smws.com/confident-understat.description: The panel found hints of many things on the nose – sugared buns and honey, apples, pears and bananas, lemon bonbons and vanilla panna cotta; even rose petals, straw and wine. The neat taste was a real ‘Wow!’ of spritzy effervescence and sweet and perfumed fruits (melon, sour apple, banana smoothie. grape and elderflower Shloer). The reduced nose found pear and nectarine flan served with custard in a beautiful garden with honeysuckle, rose and laurel growing all around. On the reduced palate – refined oak, wood sap and light leather from a confident but understated cask balanced the fruity and perfumed sweetness wonderfully.
https://www.smws.com/confident-understat.drinking_tip: A good time party dram to enliven the senses, the way good Champagne does.
https://www.smws.com/confident-understat.name: Confident, understated cask

https://www.smws.com/continental-breakfa.description: Light nose-prickle, but not too sharp. Apple tart, pineapple and Danish pastries; almond praline; ground pecan nuts; a base of fresh wood (flat-pack furniture). Then tablet – buttery and sweet, before it sets hard. The taste is sweet but surprisingly spicy – chilli, cinnamon, ginger – like ‘garish-coloured Indian sweeties’. At first a drop of water introduces a waxy note (furniture polish), then the sweetness returns – lemon honey (from the centre of a Lockett throat sweet), Turkish baklava (honey, nuts, buttery filo pastry), sticky tea-cake with an apricot glaze, hot cross bun. At reduced strength, it tastes as it noses, although not so sweet and spicy.
https://www.smws.com/continental-breakfa.drinking_tip: Breakfast in the sun, with strong coffee
https://www.smws.com/continental-breakfa.name: Continental breakfast

https://www.smws.com/cowboy-beans.description: Have you ever tried sweet, spicy and smoky cowboy beans made with bacon, garlic, fried onions, ketchup, balsamic vinegar and smoked paprika, all in a pot simmering over a barbeque fire in the wild west (on a Hebridean island)? Someone needed medical attention with antiseptic, but then we all tucked in with thick slices of ciabatta. If you are into sweet and salty flavours you will enjoy this. If not, can I tempt you with a drop of water as it turned into a lamb, black pudding and mustard hotpot and how about finishing with pickled herring in a sour crème sauce.
https://www.smws.com/cowboy-beans.drinking_tip: With a loaded hot dog by the sea
https://www.smws.com/cowboy-beans.name: Cowboy Beans - SOLD OUT

https://www.smws.com/cream-teas-and-wood.description: The nose evoked a fruit bowl of painted wood, containing pineapple, guava, mango and custard apple; we also imagined cream cakes and raspberry and blackberry pie, accompanied by Chablis – delicate and dignified. The palate was warm and relaxing, yet opulent – ‘Polo Fruits in a lady’s handbag’, declared one panellist; others found sherbet dib-dabs, lemon and lime sorbet, sultana cake and trail mix (dried fruits and coconut) – this time washed down with vintage champagne. The reduced nose was lively, fresh and tropical (sherbet straws, old-fashioned lemonade, Danish pastries). The palate provided a fascinating balance of gentle wood influence with intense fruity sweetness.
https://www.smws.com/cream-teas-and-wood.drinking_tip: Summer time – maybe instead of champagne at some fancy garden party.
https://www.smws.com/cream-teas-and-wood.name: Cream teas and wooden fruit bowls - Renewal Bottle

https://www.smws.com/creamy-peppermint-p.description: Sweet notes dominated right from the start; banana vanilla custard, baked rhubarb pudding, apple pie but then, surprisingly, a bowl of field salad with warm bacon apple cider vinaigrette arrived. The taste neat had a nice kick of wasabi peas mixed with dry roasted peanuts to start, followed by baked aubergine pasta in the sweet juices from roasted vegetables. With water, we got a Greek falafel wrap filled with shredded lettuce, roasted zucchini, red onions and of course, tzatziki sauce. On the palate now creamy and fresh like Jersey full cream milk, strawberry crème fraiche ice cream and peppermint punch.
https://www.smws.com/creamy-peppermint-p.name: Creamy peppermint punch

https://www.smws.com/curious-and-enigmat.description: The nose had definite declarations of oak – sawdust, charred wood, dunnage, vanilla and coconut marshmallow biscuits. The fruity spirit survived its long wooden imprisonment (plums, peaches, mandarins, poached pears, dried fruits). The palate also had oaky reverberations – warm, woody, spicy and dry, with liquorice and cough sweets and a sharp fruit core – bitter lemon, acid drops, soor plooms and vanilla icing on dried fruits. The reduced nose was curious – clootie dumpling, exotic fruits (dried pineapple and papaya), wine gums, watermelon-scented nail polish and paint. The palate now mellowed, but still with mouth-drawing, lip-smacking, enigmatically tickling woody warmth and sharp, bitter fruits.
https://www.smws.com/curious-and-enigmat.drinking_tip: After a walk in the woods – or when a debate-provoking, conversational dram is required.
https://www.smws.com/curious-and-enigmat.name: Curious and enigmatic

https://www.smws.com/curious-and-intrigu.description: A curious and intriguing nose – we found spiced toffee apples, roasted chestnuts, figs, fudge and old wood (cigarette boxes?); a mixture of treacle and Olbas Oil, some rich sherry and a matchbox. The neat taste had tongue-numbing menthol and eucalyptus and made us think of figs, sherry, burnt toffee, honey-roast parsnips and beetroot crisps; old tea chests and erasers. The reduced nose got dried flowers on a lavender polished table, old leather chests, hazelnuts and menthol cigarettes. The reduced palate had pleasant woodiness, some acceptable earthiness (roasted sweet potato, walnuts, hay) and candy floss sweetness (including chewing the stick).
https://www.smws.com/curious-and-intrigu.drinking_tip: A dram for debating with friends, or as a reward after walking over burning coals.
https://www.smws.com/curious-and-intrigu.name: Curious and intriguing

https://www.smws.com/dainty-measured-and.description: Light, perfumed, dainty, measured and delicate. We were met with the heady scents of a lemon syrup sponge served in a garden centre, with iced tea and Toffee Dodger biscuits on the side. On further exploration it was sweet and peachy, with lychees, vanilla, white pepper zing and burnt orange syrup. Water brought apple scented soap, distant potpourri, rose petals, cut flower stems and white lilies. On the taste we found apple juice jelly, condensed milk and icing sugar with vanilla and dried cranberries to finish. Gentle, yes, but give this time and you will find that it is no shrinking violet!
https://www.smws.com/dainty-measured-and.drinking_tip: We enjoyed this most without adding water
https://www.smws.com/dainty-measured-and.name: Dainty, measured and delicate

https://www.smws.com/dancing-round-the-c.description: The nose gave us clean nutty smoke, bonfire embers, light jasmine and lots of sticky sweet stuff (treacle, barbeque ribs, Chinese chicken wings). The palate had big, sharp, spicy flavours – wood smoke and embers, liquorice, pink peppercorns, lime pickle, mango chutney and wasabi, with a softening hint of honey. The reduced nose offered salty pretzels, fried sage leaf, bergamot, polished leather and Eastern rugs infused with incense smoke. The palate had become drier, but still pleasant in a lively, dancing way – we thought of charred sticks, burnt bracken and hot stones from a hillside campfire; fruit chutney and black jack chews.
https://www.smws.com/dancing-round-the-c.drinking_tip: While eating Chinese chicken wings on an Eastern rug by a hillside campfire.
https://www.smws.com/dancing-round-the-c.name: Dancing round the campfire

https://www.smws.com/deep-dark-and-pleas.description: The nose was deep and dark, but pleasantly attractive – we found dates, Demerara, mocha, rum truffles and candy floss; a lady’s wooden dressing table and a French polisher’s tool-bag. The neat palate was very sweet – treacle toffee, rum cake, Dr Peppers, and Calypso coffee, but with hints of perfume and Benylin linctus offering intrigue and interest. The reduced nose suggested cinder toffee, fly cemeteries (fruit slice) and sherry trifle with lady finger biscuits in the bottom. The palate had moist ginger cake and sugary espresso dregs, with black tea, dry wood and gentle spices giving a satisfying shimmer to the finish.
https://www.smws.com/deep-dark-and-pleas.name: Deep, dark and pleasantly attractive

https://www.smws.com/delicate-perfumed-s.description: The panel were not unanimous, but those who loved it praised the clean smoke and delicate perfumed sweetness of the nose (Turkish Delight, mandarins in syrup, preserved lemons and lavender soap); also the subtle maritime murmuring of old ship’s ropes and shellfish. Water brought out some nuttiness and a strange combination of fresh laundry flapping with a steam train going by. The palate was astonishingly sweet and perfumed – hints of parma violets, sherbet straws and purple wine gums, some woody, nutty elements (nougat, pistachios) and a dry, salty insinuation of the sea in the form of Tabasco oysters and manzanilla sherry.
https://www.smws.com/delicate-perfumed-s.drinking_tip: To accompany a good maritime tale – book or film.
https://www.smws.com/delicate-perfumed-s.name: Delicate perfumed sweetness

https://www.smws.com/deliciously-dark-an.description: The nose delighted us with honey flapjacks, barley sugars, Demerara and treacle tart – pumpkin pie and blackberry bushes gave it an almost autumnal air. The palate was deliciously dark and sweet – scorched meringues, orange liqueur, black bun, treacle on a welly boot and a tannic twist of oak in the tail. The reduced nose found burnt wood and leaves, singed fruit cake, stroop waffles and old tennis racket handles. The reduced palate achieved a balance between treacle toffee and muscovado sweetness and the mighty oak, while some elusive suggestions of red wine and stock reduction added a savoury complexity.
https://www.smws.com/deliciously-dark-an.drinking_tip: After dinner – or at least in an armchair by a log fire – first cold nights of autumn.
https://www.smws.com/deliciously-dark-an.name: Deliciously dark and sweet

https://www.smws.com/deliciously-sweet-b.description: The nose brightened our mood with notes of vanilla, crème brûlée, rainbow drops, tutti-frutti, limoncello, tangy orange and fresh laundry; it also had a youthful, feisty, ‘wha daur meddle wi’ me’ presence (white pepper, aniseed balls, ginger, something mineralic, like a salt scrub). The palate – bitter-sweet, herbal, citric and spicy – whizzed around our mouths like a pin-ball whacking up a high score – candied lemon peel, cough sweets, lemon sherbet and salty Tequila slammers, followed by a dry, spicy finish. Combining that with delicious sweetness (blossom honey, apricot Danish, Crunchy Nut Cornflakes) the end result was a very attractive, moreish, entertaining dram.
https://www.smws.com/deliciously-sweet-b.name: Deliciously sweet but feisty

https://www.smws.com/delightful-evocatio.description: This dram had delicious and delightful sharp fragrances of perfumed fruits (cherries, damson jam, plum wine), flowers, Crunchie bars, orange liqueur, vanilla ice-cream and banana custard – all made more complex by hints of nail parlours and old libraries. The palate had exotic fruits, barley sugars, chocolate marzipan logs, caramel, honey and playful Christmas spices. The reduced nose retained tremendous character – caipirinha cocktails, basil and apple sorbet and chocolate oranges, all served in a boudoir (perfume, nails, flowers). The reduced palate boasted waxy fruits, honeycomb, stoop waffles, hints of oak shavings and tarry ropes, with ginger snap biscuits dunked in rose-petal tea.
https://www.smws.com/delightful-evocatio.drinking_tip: Definitely something to intensify the sensual energy of the boudoir.
https://www.smws.com/delightful-evocatio.name: Delightful evocation of the boudoir

https://www.smws.com/dirty-martinis-in-t.description: The nose suggested candy floss, lemon cheesecake, heather, oyster shells, woolly socks drying over a wood-burning stove and sea breezes over the springtime machair. The palate had light smoke (distant heather moor-burn), peppercorn heat and a definite sticky, honey glaze barbeque thing going on, but the main thing was the floral, lavender nature of the smoke. The reduced nose found boat sheds, peat-fire chimney soot, rosemary, thyme and liquorice root and salad Niçoise with lemon mayo. The palate had now become a mix of perfumed smoke and sweet heather honey, with lemon-pepper and a salty ‘dirty martini’ zing in the finish.
https://www.smws.com/dirty-martinis-in-t.drinking_tip: Beach barbeque – or any lazy day – or looking at holiday snaps.
https://www.smws.com/dirty-martinis-in-t.name: Dirty martinis in the boat shed

https://www.smws.com/divas-do-disco.description: The panel donned their dancing pants and came over all seventies style. The nose was heavy with sandalwood and heavy oak laced with the tropical warmth of baked banana and rum soaked sponge. Pineapple with butterscotch, marzipan, carrot cake and Fry’s chocolate cream fuelled our divas. They were slick with saffron and citrus scented shaving cream and old fashioned Ambre Solaire. They guzzled dark chocolate with salted lime and rum and raisin ice cream. A heady line up of creamy cocktails: White Russian, brandy Alexander and milkshake sprinkled with nutmeg washed down with a box of liqueur chocolates. Go tiger!
https://www.smws.com/divas-do-disco.drinking_tip: Get you in the mood for some Saturday Night fever
https://www.smws.com/divas-do-disco.name: Divas Do Disco!

https://www.smws.com/eccentricity-at-its.description: We found this an eccentric and incredibly enjoyable whisky. Aromas of dough, pine wood, rock pools, salted limes, seaweed, fish boxes, lavender bath salts, prawn cocktail, tuna sushi roll, Paddington Bear marmalade, … do I need to continue? In the taste we found seared scallops in a herb-butter sauce, grilled king prawns and eggs Benedict on a charred muffin. In reduction; salty sea spray, steamed mussels and sea salted chocolate, with flavours of oysters in lime juice and a glass of Prosecco in the finish. After 23 years in an ex-bourbon barrel, we transferred this whisky directly into an Oloroso Sherry butt for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/eccentricity-at-its.drinking_tip: At the end of a pier
https://www.smws.com/eccentricity-at-its.name: Eccentricity at its best!

https://www.smws.com/elementary-my-dear-.description: This sample presented interesting challenges to our Sherlock noses – we were all over the place, from a hunting lodge (wellies, tweed jackets, rifles, log fire) to an amateur beach bonfire barbeque (jacket potatoes, toasted marshmallows, grilled pork – all slightly overdone). The unreduced palate had ash, wood smoke, peat smoke, singed lime, porridge with brown sugar, caramelised apple and donuts. The reduced nose seemed fresher, with laundry flapping vigorously on a washing-line down-wind of chimney smoke; also sou’westers and pork crackling with apple. The reduced palate re-discovered its sweetness (white jelly babies, icing sugar, vanilla) – but with curious hints of smoked fish.
https://www.smws.com/elementary-my-dear-.drinking_tip: A west coast holiday dram – or to provide warmth and calmness on a blustery day.
https://www.smws.com/elementary-my-dear-.name: ‘Elementary, my dear Watson’

https://www.smws.com/engineer-s-work-ben.description: The nose had reasonable sweetness (toffee, golden syrup, marzipan, sugared almonds) some savoury suggestions (cooked crab, roast duck with plum sauce) and ‘an engineer’s work-bench in a boatyard’. The palate, at natural strength, conveyed burnt sticks and over-done fruit cake, sticky gingerbread, teasing smoke and hints of soot and ash. The reduced nose leaped about from crushed shells and coal sacks to spiced stewed plums, figs and orange fruit cake, with a slight suggestion of rubber (those old tyres that dangle from harbour walls). Water improved the taste, in our opinion – Terry’s chocolate orange, sticky toffee pudding, butterscotch, Demerara and clove.
https://www.smws.com/engineer-s-work-ben.drinking_tip: To enjoy, while sitting in the sun, watching scenes of harbour life.
https://www.smws.com/engineer-s-work-ben.name: Engineer’s work-bench in a boatyard

https://www.smws.com/enjoy-the-moment.description: This was a real dichotomy of young and old on the nose neat. Aromas started off with pink grapefruit, lychees, chilled Thai carrot and rhubarb soup but then moved on to marzipan, fruit cake, a vintage leather Chesterfield sofa and an empty Cuban cigar tube. The taste was a harmonious and luxurious combination of sweetness with an intriguing pinch of oriental spice but still that freshness of luscious fleshy peaches and apricots. With just a drop of water aromas of stewed rhubarb and apple crumble appeared and to taste a mixed Asian salad with macadamia nuts, leaving us all very relaxed and satisfied.
https://www.smws.com/enjoy-the-moment.name: Enjoy the moment

https://www.smws.com/evokes-van-gogh-s-p.description: The nose shifted from its underlying sweetness (clover honey, Toffifees) to Chinese ribs and honey-cured bacon and finally to gravadlax, clams and salty sea air – but subtle heather moor-burn smoke suffused the whole thing. The palate had dark toffee and lavender honey sweetness, plus perfumed smoke – ‘More lavender than Van Gogh’s Provence’ said one panellist – chalky Extra strong mints teased the finish. The reduced nose was fresh, fragrant and unusual – swimming pools, flowering herb gardens and talc on a dressing table. The palate was now sweet and perfumed, with Edinburgh Rock dryness in the finish – it could hardly be anything else.
https://www.smws.com/evokes-van-gogh-s-p.drinking_tip: To accompany films with perfumed old ladies – Mrs Palfrey, Best Marigold Hotel, Psycho etc.
https://www.smws.com/evokes-van-gogh-s-p.name: Evokes Van Gogh’s Provence - Exclusive to August Peaty Trio

https://www.smws.com/exotic-fruits-and-p.description: Exotic fruits flattered our noses (mango, rhubarb tarts, cherry pies, sherbet lemons, jellied fruits) but it had interest and weight too – brown sugar, craft workshops, sandalwood and perfume samples in women’s magazines. Even more fruits arrived on the palate – strawberry, blackcurrant, kiwi, fig and plum – all held down to earth by deeper notes of fortified wine, dark chocolate, Strepsils and sugar-coated fennel seeds. The reduced nose was simply delightful – perfumed pear and elderflower sorbet and flowers in polytunnels. Lots to discover on the palate now too – honey sweetness balancing fruit and floral perfumed bitterness – we agreed it was elegant and rounded.
https://www.smws.com/exotic-fruits-and-p.drinking_tip: A summer’s day in the garden, bees humming in the flowers.
https://www.smws.com/exotic-fruits-and-p.name: Exotic fruits and polytunnel flowers

https://www.smws.com/exploding-flower.description: The nose started with linoleum and green leaf, but slowly opened like a flower – vanilla sponge, Danish pastries, toffee, some fruit (strawberry, banana) and floral notes (gentian, rosewater, gorse). The neat palate was assertive, but complex and unusually bitter-sweet – ‘biting an orange’, tutti-frutti, jelly beans – one panellist found a honey, vodka and gunpowder mixture, but he self-combusted and didn’t trouble us anymore. With water, the nose became freshly intriguing, with tinned fruit salad, old-fashioned lemonade, tree-bark, liquorice and menthol. The palate was now really rather pleasant – juicy, sweet and refreshing, with peach and pear balancing clove and aniseed spice.
https://www.smws.com/exploding-flower.drinking_tip: Improves with water – would be a suitable conversational dram – or maybe with dessert.
https://www.smws.com/exploding-flower.name: Exploding flower
