https://www.smws.com/fade-to-black.description: This epic tale began with evocative smoke sweeping through a glen, whilst a mysterious figure sipped “cure-all” tincture from a leather hipflask.  There was a silent acknowledgement of the balanced nature of this peaty beast.  Strong and assured, yet elegant and majestic, the dragon did soar.  To taste, refreshing menthol, scorched walnut whips and some serious sweetness to boot.  The addition of water brought out a cereal backbone of hay in the sunshine, whilst a perplexing opposite appeared in the form of a damp peat fire.  Herbal elements teased from afar.  The taste was cooling and soothing with a creamy texture.  A bellow of smoke from the dragon preceded a long, thoughtful fade to black.
https://www.smws.com/fade-to-black.name: Fade to black

https://www.smws.com/film-noir.description: The nose wafted blackjack chews, pipe tobacco, cigar boxes, honey smoked ham, dates, liquorice, patent leather shoes and smokehouse fish – fifty shades of black, smell-wise at least . The palate continued the black attack, with smoke, ash and chimney soot, coal cellars, charcoal logs, burning peats, tarry roads in high summer and pine log barbecues in high mountains. The reduced nose evoked a scene from Harry Potter, with steam trains, antique bookshops and an old-fashioned apothecary – as well as creosoted fences and fishing nets drying on the beach. The palate now suggested aniseed, roast pork, tarry ropes, seaweed and old puffers.
https://www.smws.com/film-noir.drinking_tip: With an appropriate film – Harry Potter (Goblet of Fire), Para Handy, Fifty Shades of Whatever, Drambusters, etc. Etc.
https://www.smws.com/film-noir.name: Film noir

https://www.smws.com/fireman-s-gloves-on.description: Our noses found nutty, leathery, woody smoke – bonfires from first touch to dying embers – fireman’s gloves after a hard shift; then we got medicinal stuff (first-aid box, bandages, Savlon) and finally fish boxes, shellfish, citrus and celery salt. The palate was a Wowee! hit of wood extract, tar, salted treacle scones and smoke (puffing a big cigar) – hints of fried bacon and salted cashews. The reduced nose was ‘salty as a mermaid in a rock-pool’ – salt-encrusted boat decks were also mentioned – and some savoury notes. The palate remained chewy and substantial – a candy floss of smoke and tar on a stick.
https://www.smws.com/fireman-s-gloves-on.drinking_tip: To impress your friends, or just as a nightcap for any salty old dog, reading himself to sleep with an Irvine Welsh novel.
https://www.smws.com/fireman-s-gloves-on.name: Fireman’s gloves on a mermaid

https://www.smws.com/floral-perfumes-in-.description: We found the nose straightforward but attractive, with vanilla, lemon puffs, green apple, rhubarb and chalky sweets (Edinburgh Rock) but one panellist was in a Chinese restaurant (five-spice, fragrant rice, fortune cookies). With water the floral, citric perfumes edged forward and it became more buttery (popcorn, shortbread, caramel). The palate had good viscosity and body, with sweet and tart flavours of stewed rhubarb, gooseberry, plums, red grape Shloer, Haribos and Astro Belts; it even seemed fizzy and lively at times. Water emphasised different aspects – pistachios, almonds and salty bread, with lemon rind, white pepper and aniseed bringing dryness to the finish.
https://www.smws.com/floral-perfumes-in-.name: Floral perfumes in a Chinese restaurant

https://www.smws.com/folly-from-france.description: The nose neat had an enticing combination of lemon sweetness; syrup and lemon sponge pudding, lemon icing, lemon sorbet, lemon sherbet and lemon bonbons. One Panel member was also reminded of his childhood favourite French boiled sweets called ‘Bêtises de Cambrai’. Sweet and citric on the palate at first with white grapefruit but soon cedar aromatic wooden incense gave it a long pleasant lengthy aftertaste. Water adds freshness to the sweetness like linen being dried on a warm breezy sunny morning in a daisy meadow. The taste was now sweet and creamy like a satisfying honey and vanilla yoghurt drink.
https://www.smws.com/folly-from-france.name: Folly from France

https://www.smws.com/fresh-as-a-daisy.description: The panel found a delightful melange of clean, green aromas bursting with Julep freshness: cucumber, mint and gomme syrup. Grapefruit, lime and green apple was balanced by creamy set yoghurt, pan drop mints and white pepper. With water the panel came over all period drama: they frolicked in white linen and stretched out on warm summer lawns scented with camomile. They sipped old fashioned lemonade and licked mint chocolate ice cream. Fresh apple pie and lashings of soda water refreshed the revellers. As with all beautiful people they merely glowed, cheeks flushed with soft vanilla and expensive shaving soap.
https://www.smws.com/fresh-as-a-daisy.name: Fresh as a daisy

https://www.smws.com/fresh-as-a-winter-w.description: The nose was fresh, leafy and herbal (sorrel, nettle, melissa) with nice fruity aromas (sour apple sweets, lemon puffs, unripe mango) and some floral perfumes (honeysuckle, elderflower) –we also got light suggestions of new books and marker pens. The palate was mainly sweet, citric and juicy, reminding us of Haribo Tangfastics, wine gums, jelly babies and apple snow – hints of clove and some herbal elements completed the picture. The reduced nose had pleasantly invigorating fruit salad freshness, some buttery pastry and chilled muscadet or Eiswein. The palate now settled into a mouth-watering blackcurrant and lemon sorbet – fresh as a winter waterfall.
https://www.smws.com/fresh-as-a-winter-w.drinking_tip: Something to enjoy in the shade of a summer garden.
https://www.smws.com/fresh-as-a-winter-w.name: Fresh as a winter waterfall

https://www.smws.com/fresh-fluffy.description: On the nose neat; new towels smelling fresh and feeling fluffy as well as opening a box of brand new quality leather shoes. The taste was like a strawberry Daiquiri, fresh, fruity, sweet and mellow garnished with a lime twist. Adding water, and we imagined ourselves sitting in a wicker chair arranging a dry flower basket in the garden whilst enjoying a toasted bagel with strawberry jam and drinking warm honey lemon water; sweet, delicate, satisfying and very moreish! After 17 years in an ex-bourbon barrel, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/fresh-fluffy.name: Fresh & fluffy

https://www.smws.com/fruit-fruit-fruit.description: The nose was fruit, fruit, fruit! Sorbet served in a half pineapple shell, lemon, mango, passion-fruit, peach, strawberry and apple were all mentioned; also vanilla, beeswax, pencil shavings, old books, perfume and Ladyfinger biscuits (also called ‘boudoir biscuits’ apparently). The palate was quite ‘cakey’ – Jamaican ginger cake, Madeira cake and lemon sponge – and the fruit (tinned peach, green apple) was now competing with liquorice, leather and light smoke. The reduced nose – still myriad fruits – but also marzipan, bubble-gum, linseed oil and nasturtium flowers. The palate was now perfumed, fruity, floral and waxy. The distillery is about three miles south-west of Elgin.
https://www.smws.com/fruit-fruit-fruit.drinking_tip: With afternoon tea – or in the boudoir, perhaps
https://www.smws.com/fruit-fruit-fruit.name: Fruit, fruit, fruit!

https://www.smws.com/fruitilicious.description: The panel found bountiful fruits: peach, apricot, strawberry and apple. Sweetness of custard creams, creme anglaise, almond croissants and pancakes sprinkled with lemon and sugar. They detected a pleasant hint of earthy forest floor and green leaves. Their tongues tingled with aniseed, orange and licorice. The mouthfeel had a tightness of herbal digestif which relaxed considerably with water. Banoffee pie, more apple and fizzy lemon, then Tiger Balm, rooibos tea and nutmeg adding interest. Curious green notes of damp moss, vetiver and baobab bark developed. The finish was like a cleansing cocktail, smashed holy basil, quinine and citrus.
https://www.smws.com/fruitilicious.name: Fruitilicious!

https://www.smws.com/fun-to-chase.description: With its combination of exotic fruits (dragon-fruit, strawberry, orange sherbet) intense sweetness (candy floss, Skittles) and pleasant toasted oak, the nose was immediately appealing. With water we found it intriguing and enigmatic but fun to chase – tobacco, foamy bananas, vanilla, mango, coconut and flowers rewarded our efforts. The palate was sweetly succulent, velvety, perfumed and mouth-watering – Turkish Delight, watermelon, gooseberry, lemon and cherry drops with iced gingerbread and cinnamon adding to the sherbety tingles. Water made it juicily tropical (fruit cocktail, pineapple) but with perfumed lavender and a lovely subtle, spicy, woody depth. From the only working distillery at Carron.
https://www.smws.com/fun-to-chase.drinking_tip: Whenever you feel the need for a tropical holiday – but can’t afford it.
https://www.smws.com/fun-to-chase.name: Fun to chase

https://www.smws.com/fun-without-firewor.description: Our first impressions were of a mature, sophisticated nose – with pleasing aromas of sponge cake, golden syrup, vanilla, marzipan and abundant aromatic fruits (blood orange, pineapple, banana, apple, lemon). Familiarity and a drop of water brought out some woody notes (IKEA furniture, cinnamon, almonds). The palate was mouth-filling, gum-tingling and fun – the panel’s suggestions included chewing twigs, dolly mixtures, vanilla, toffee, honey on crumpets and Bucks Fizz; pink peppercorn heat and oaky tannins formed a solid but unobtrusive infrastructure and gentle perfume bitterness complicated the finish. An urbane and subtle dram with many facets to provide quiet entertainment – fun without fireworks.
https://www.smws.com/fun-without-firewor.name: Fun without fireworks

https://www.smws.com/genie-in-a-bottle.description: This was like a genie in a glass, from clean perfumed smoke and a well-used wooden pipe rack to sun scorched hay and heather, moving on to stem and crystallised ginger and finishing with seared scallops. We finally let the genie out and had a sip – it was a puff of glittering, well rounded, perfumed smoke. Sweet and floral at first, but then salted caramel arrived and in the finish, a pleasant dryness. With water, crunchy ginger and coffee iced biscuits as well as almond slices and the taste of lavender honey on burnt toast making this a very relaxed laid back experience.
https://www.smws.com/genie-in-a-bottle.drinking_tip: Close your eyes and make a wish
https://www.smws.com/genie-in-a-bottle.name: Genie in a bottle

https://www.smws.com/getting-steamy-in-t.description: A peppery bite softens into blood orange, pear, peach and banana bread with honey. A steamy aroma reminiscent of saunas meshed with sunny orchards and freshly cut daffodils. Cheek clenching at first with some black tea and lime pickle but dissolved into tinned peach and pineapple. It had oily black olives that morphed into pine resin and Ambre Solaire when watered. Then bountiful sugared almonds, on iced fairy cakes, shortcrust pastry, blackcurrant cordial and cherry Bakewell tart bounced from the glass. The finale was of flapjacks and Digestives with dates, prunes and hazelnuts. Pine nuts had the final shout.
https://www.smws.com/getting-steamy-in-t.drinking_tip: A perky wee dram and needs the water
https://www.smws.com/getting-steamy-in-t.name: Getting steamy in the sauna

https://www.smws.com/ginger-passionfruit.description: The nose neat had a very homely feel, a bouquet of brightly coloured flowers, autumn berry crumble with citrus cream, coffee walnut whips, fruity caramels, hessian potpourri hanging bags and clean wood ash. The taste had a sweet, gingery, citric balance like a well-made flavoured IPA accompanied by dry roasted nuts, coconut almonds and homemade bourbon biscuits. With a drop of water it became very aromatic and exotic as if walking down the fruit aisle of a supermarket with the flower display at the end and. The flavours were that of lemon & ginger tea and a ginger passionfruit trifle.
https://www.smws.com/ginger-passionfruit.drinking_tip: Lazy Sunday afternoon in the garden
https://www.smws.com/ginger-passionfruit.name: Ginger passionfruit trifle

https://www.smws.com/godzilla-vanilla.description: The nose set the tone – a triumphant triumvirate of fruit (orange, mango, pear, peach, strawberries), sweetness (chocolate, caramelised sugar) and cask-wood influence (oak, turmeric, pepper). The palate followed through – mouth-watering tropical fruits, including apricots and banana smoothie got our taste-buds doing the tarantella and the cask supplied nutmeg and vanilla – not just a scintilla of vanilla but enough to fill a villa. Similar story on the reduced nose – honey flirted with passion-fruit and minty mohitos – a bitter-sweet romance, while oak stung the tongue with Japanese mustard. The reduced palate – pineapple, kiwi, toffee apple and lemon with full-on bourbon spice – proper lush!
https://www.smws.com/godzilla-vanilla.drinking_tip: A good digestif – but actually, any time at all.
https://www.smws.com/godzilla-vanilla.name: Godzilla vanilla

https://www.smws.com/going-dutch.description: This one took us to old Amsterdam; first stop was a cobbler’s shop selling traditionally handmade clogs. Next we entered an antiquarian bookshop with a coal burning fire in the back room and finally we went into an old fashioned apothecary. Then we stopped and had a bite to eat - a plate of cured meat with Jenever followed by a black cherry and kirsch truffle dessert. A drop of water and we happily headed to an Amsterdam coffee shop famous for its ‘cannabis cups’, the ideal place to relax and reminisce over the day’s events and to plan the next adventure.
https://www.smws.com/going-dutch.name: Going Dutch

https://www.smws.com/golden-delicious.description: Sweet aromas of chocolate chip cookie dough greeted the Panel followed by caramel apple crumble pie and gingersnap biscuits all washed down with a glass of Goldschläger, a Swiss cinnamon liqueur. The taste was that of a fresh fruit salad and elderflower relish with the attractive fizzy dry finish of a ‘zero-dosage’ Champagne. With water the aroma opened up like a bunch of flowers and on the palate, now a banana milkshake or an American cream soda. After 14 years in an ex-bourbon refill hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/golden-delicious.name: Golden Delicious

https://www.smws.com/good-old-days.description: Moist, sticky and spicy aromas were immediately apparent; syrup sponge pudding, toasted crumpets with gooey fruits, honey and yoghurt as well as scones with plum jam and cream and candied fruit marzipan. The taste did not disappoint, dark chocolate peanut butter candies and Dominosteine –gingerbread with layers of apricot jelly and marzipan all covered with a thin icing of dark chocolate. Diluted, the comforting homely scent of spiced apple mulled wine and creamy sweet eggnog using plenty of brandy. The flavours were as enticing, Snowball cocktails (advocaat, brandy, sweet cream Sherry, fresh lime juice and lemonade) and profiteroles with a hot chocolate sauce.
https://www.smws.com/good-old-days.drinking_tip: Thinking about the good old days
https://www.smws.com/good-old-days.name: Good old days

https://www.smws.com/gravitas-in-a-glass.description: The very first sniff drew positive impressions; ‘gravitas in a glass’ someone said – aromas of marmalade, toffee, syrup, coconut and exotic fruits (melon, lychee, Gewürztraminer) with some gentle hints of wood sap, shrubberies and rose gardens. The palate certainly didn’t disappoint but it had a surprisingly strong Armagnac character – we found it juicy, mouth-watering and mellow, with sandalwood, tropical fruits and mixed spices (pepper, ginger, chilli). The reduced nose was a beehive (beeswax, honey, wood) in a garden – also dark fruits, velvety chocolate pots and lavender. The palate now suggested raisins soaked in brandy, dried flowers, sultanas, dates and warming spices.
https://www.smws.com/gravitas-in-a-glass.drinking_tip: This would be great dram to cradle, appreciate and muse over after dinner.
https://www.smws.com/gravitas-in-a-glass.name: Gravitas in a glass

https://www.smws.com/gritty-turned-prett.description: This smells like a heavily Sherry-fed fruit cake, a strong cholate Porter matured in Sherry casks, a roast leg of lamb with rosemary jus and burnt honey, orange and clove glazed ham, those were just some of the remarks. A unique nose neat was followed by God’s wrath in the form of smoke, embers and brimstone on the palate sweetened by melted hot dark chocolate and spiced Brazil nuts. With water, aromas of loaf cake and mulled cider with mince pies and the taste still massive, “pull down your pants, as this one will kick you’re …” – don’t say we didn’t warn you!
https://www.smws.com/gritty-turned-prett.drinking_tip: Just before a rugby match whilst the opponent team perform the haka
https://www.smws.com/gritty-turned-prett.name: Gritty-turned-pretty

https://www.smws.com/gun-cabinets-and-fl.description: Our noses picked up attractive wood (pine needles sprinkled in polished gun cabinets) – also orange, apricot, elderflower, coconut, honey and lemongrass – lovely things, and all improving with time. But wait! The palate was even better – orange zest, pineapple and papaya kicked it off, but slowly the lip-smacking, wood-derived delights of cinnamon, vanilla, coconut and brown sugar in espresso cups took it to a higher register. The reduced nose had sherbety, flying saucer fizz, apple crumble, cedar and mahogany. On the palate – lots of exotic fruits emerged (honeydew melon, pink grapefruit, mango), with barley sugar sweetness and spicy wood – ‘Proper Lush!
https://www.smws.com/gun-cabinets-and-fl.drinking_tip: Immediately after a hard day at work.
https://www.smws.com/gun-cabinets-and-fl.name: Gun cabinets and flying saucers

https://www.smws.com/ham-gobblin-ghoul.description: Without water, the panel got a mixed array of Autumnal scents. Honey glazed ham served alongside bitter apple cider. An old desk varnished containing a packet of pecan nuts. One panellist noted feint hints of watermelon scented soap. To taste, intense chilli heat mixed with buttered popcorn, oriental spice and honeyed ham heavily charred on the skin. Once water was added the panel got a mixed fruit medley on the nose- pineapple upside down cake and bounty bars washed down with white grape juice and rock shandy. To taste coconut creams covered in margarine with hints of tea tree.
https://www.smws.com/ham-gobblin-ghoul.name: Ham Gobblin’ Ghoul

https://www.smws.com/happy-frivolous-smo.description: The nose had us smiling and happy – quite fruity (mandarin, green melon, fruit crumble) with Victoria sponge, biscuits (jammy dodgers, garibaldis, shortbread) and light wood shavings. The palate was sweet and lively – millionaire shortbread, buttery biscuits and toffee, with honeydew melon and subtle hints of cocoa and coffee-flavoured fudge. The reduced nose made us even more happy – garlanded by candy necklaces, smooched by coffee kisses and frivolised by fresh freesias; we also got Edinburgh Rock, macaroon bars and vanilla. In this mood, the palate now danced on our tongues – chocolate M&Ms, raspberries on shortbread and tiny tannic tingles of toasted oak.
https://www.smws.com/happy-frivolous-smo.drinking_tip: To start a party, or as a reward for climbing a mountain (real or metaphorical)
https://www.smws.com/happy-frivolous-smo.name: Happy, frivolous, smoochy dram

https://www.smws.com/hazelnut-iced-coffe.description: On the nose neat a fascinating combination of warm and refreshing aromas like sweet mint leaves rubbed between your fingers, the fresh ‘green’ scent of a recently mowed lawn on a sunny day, olive oil wood polish and slightly melted honeycomb candy ice cream. On the palate, a minty cool and refreshing start which then quickly became flavours of spicy hot cross buns as well as fruity cinnamon apple pies. Water added aromas of rosewater Turkish delight candy, coconut panna cotta with a pineapple salsa and the mouthfeel was now fresh, cooling creamy with a hint of spice like a hazelnut iced coffee.
https://www.smws.com/hazelnut-iced-coffe.drinking_tip: On a warm Saturday late afternoon in the garden
https://www.smws.com/hazelnut-iced-coffe.name: Hazelnut iced coffee

https://www.smws.com/heady-zingy-and-fiz.description: A strong exhilarating aroma greeted the Panel and got us all very excited. It was an array of different heady aromas; sweet-smelling scented flower bouquets, poached pears in white wine, rose water as well as freshly polished new leather. Refreshing, slightly minty on the palate like a cool and green fruit salad with honeydew melon, grapes and kiwi accompanied by a glass of ice cold apple cinnamon water. With water, white chocolate covered peanuts, pecans and almonds arrived and the herbal aroma of sage rubbed between one’s fingers. Fizzy with a minty, slightly salty mouthfeel and a zingy finish of herbal iced tea.
https://www.smws.com/heady-zingy-and-fiz.name: Heady, Zingy and Fizzy

https://www.smws.com/heavenly-fragrance.description: We started off by rummaging a ladies well perfumed leather handbag and we found patchouli musk body oil, rose water cologne, mini foam bananas sweets and a packet of menthol cigarettes. After that most of us sat round a table and enjoyed a chocolate fondue, dipping segments of oranges and ruby red grapefruit as well as strawberries and marshmallows. However, others enjoyed apple, pear & fig stilton tarts garnished with rich walnut chutney. Diluted, sun-dried raisins and grapes with aromas of steaming saffron basmati rice and in the taste, moist chocolate, ginger and date cakes with a spoonful of silky caramel sauce.
https://www.smws.com/heavenly-fragrance.name: Heavenly fragrance

https://www.smws.com/herbal-enough-to-pl.description: We enjoyed delicate herbal and floral fragrances on the nose (Melissa, camomile, sweet basil, jasmine, rose, eucalyptus) – beyond that we caught pleasant hints of vanilla, lemonade, orange and new furniture. The palate was mainly bitter-sweet –watermelon and agave syrup sweetness rubbed along with lemon barley water, mint humbugs and various leafy, herbal flavours (menthol, tarragon, fennel, peppery nasturtium). The reduced nose was better, now incorporating definite waxiness (candles, waxed canvas, lipstick) plus marmalade and floral freshness. The palate also improved with water – sponge cake, limoncello, chocolate, candied angelica and orange sherbet fizz all danced around in a mouth-watering sensual delight.
https://www.smws.com/herbal-enough-to-pl.drinking_tip: Perfect dram for a sunny afternoon in the garden; if you don’t have a garden, dress up like Titania.
https://www.smws.com/herbal-enough-to-pl.name: Herbal enough to please a gerbil

https://www.smws.com/high-on-the-hills-w.description: Yodelay, woohoo! Maria gathered goodies for a hillside picnic with ripe tropical fruits: guava, peach and mango all melded together as rumtopf. She packed crystalline ginger, cranberries and vanilla toffee fudge with flasks of Calypso coffee and cherry punch. One panelist described the taste ‘very jammy’ with cherry ice cream. Another described it as Austrian germknödel (steamed dumplings) filled with plum or damson powidl - either way truly scrumptious! Water teased out cinnamon buns and then juicy blackcurrant, licorice and maple syrup. Our bakery flavours became more exotic with cassia, anise, incense and hot chocolate sprinkled with paprika. Marvelous Maria!
https://www.smws.com/high-on-the-hills-w.name: High on the hills with a lonely goatherd

https://www.smws.com/high-tea-in-a-cotta.description: The nose’s initial paint became fruit – apple, pear, raspberry, melon, gooseberry, lemon and Key lime pie – beyond that, teasing, tantalising, light floral drifts of rosebuds, lavender and shrubberies after rain – all cuddled close in creamy vanilla oak. The delicate side of the palate produced raspberry ripple ice-cream, Pavlova, tangy citric zing and vanilla sponge, but it also had a full-on, mouth-filling heat with flavours of chilli, ginger, liquorice imps, humbugs and tannic oak. The reduced nose had honey on wood, cottage garden perfumes and high tea cake selections. The reduced palate was a satisfying combination of citrus, flowers and willow sprigs.
https://www.smws.com/high-tea-in-a-cotta.drinking_tip: We thought this would be a good kitchen dram –supervising that is, not actually working.
https://www.smws.com/high-tea-in-a-cotta.name: High tea in a cottage garden

https://www.smws.com/holiday-in-a-heaven.description: On the nose, initial nail polish remover quickly gave way to dried fruit compote (raisins, figs, prunes), mango, dark chocolate Bounty bars and something straight from the oven (upside-down pineapple cake, baked Alaska with rum and raisin ice-cream). The neat palate had good texture and fascinating complexity –the cask had bestowed crushed nuts and intense toasted oak, plus mellow honey sweetness and a fabulous assortment of mouth-watering tropical fruits. The reduced nose took us pool-side in a heavenly hotel in the Caribbean – cocktails, manicure, fresh towels, trade winds… The palate was now sugar-coated pastries, exquisite fruit salad, Demerara and tobacco strands.
https://www.smws.com/holiday-in-a-heaven.name: Holiday in a heavenly hotel

https://www.smws.com/holidays-and-honeym.description: The nose started off with thistles, nettles, white pepper, laundry powder and lemon and blackcurrant pastilles, but it quickly softened and mellowed to milk chews, vanilla slices, pineapple humps and warm holiday air. The palate was sweet, tart and fruity – rhubarb jam, lime jellies, astro belts, lemon peel and pineapple – with warm spicy wood and humbugs on the finish. The reduced nose found a lot more wood (pine, oak, sawdust) but considerately balanced by nougat, butterscotch and vanilla ice-cream sweetness. The reduced palate had sweet wedding cake icing and buttered gingerbread facing up to fizzy acidity (soda and lime, refreshers, margarita).
https://www.smws.com/holidays-and-honeym.name: Holidays and honeymoons

https://www.smws.com/honey-in-a-sunny-ga.description: The nose was delicately and deliciously perfumed with flowers (dried flower pot-pourri) and fruits (pear, pineapple, cherry, rhubarb) with additional layers of vanilla, bread and butter pudding and gorgeous heather honey. The palate had a dynamic oomph but also oodles of deep, rich honey flavours – creamy and sweet, with a salty something, like honey spread on croissants or crumpets with salted butter. The reduced nose evoked a sunny garden – honeysuckle and sunflowers supported by canes; coconut and leather tobacco pouches emerged later. The palate maintained its presence and dignity – lively (but far from aggressive) spices mingled alluringly with Crunchie bar sweetness.
https://www.smws.com/honey-in-a-sunny-ga.drinking_tip: In a garden or after bee-keeping, or to soothe emotional stings.
https://www.smws.com/honey-in-a-sunny-ga.name: Honey in a sunny garden

https://www.smws.com/hubba-bubba-mango-a.description: Early nose suggestions of balsa models, linseed and elastoplasts turned more tropical (grapefruit, cherry, pineapple, orange blossom, muscovado, crystallised ginger, rose petals, hubba-bubba gum). The palate had an amusing, mouth-tickling effect like tiny leprechauns River-dancing on our tongues; sherbet, Monstera, mango, rhubarb and blackcurrant jam on toast – a sunny, honeyed, Sunday afternoon feel. The reduced nose found traces of mint, lemon balm, apple tart and angelica, but still sweet (toffee, trifle). The palate was sweetly perfumed – sherbet straws, Rainbow drops and black jack chews with hints of peach sorbet and fine leather – tasty and decidedly drinkable.
https://www.smws.com/hubba-bubba-mango-a.drinking_tip: Frivolous and frothy enough for a carnival, party mood – or just a lazy Sunday dram.
https://www.smws.com/hubba-bubba-mango-a.name: Hubba-bubba, mango and Monstera

https://www.smws.com/invigorating-and-in.description: The nose neat calmed our minds and immediately created a Zen like ambience. Descriptors of resins, cloves, musky, wood and the earthy scent of opening the door of an old fashioned dunnage warehouse drew us in and we took the first sip. Now very different; candied ginger spice to start then, surprisingly, snowballing to a chilli heat which left us all very much invigorated. Water released a bouquet of freesias; a combination of freshness and sweetness without being sickly and that slight hint of pepper. The taste was now all about being sweet and spicy in perfect harmony.
https://www.smws.com/invigorating-and-in.name: Invigorating and inspiring

https://www.smws.com/ivory-keys-exclusiv.description: The initial sweet, fruity and floral array of aromas reminded us of natural rosewater essence, pear drops and ripe bananas. But at the same time there was also the scent of clean wood finally described as opening the lid of a grand mahogany piano and lifting the fallboard after it had been expertly cleaned and tuned. If you have never experienced that, how about ‘sipping a tree’ – a ‘cedar infused’ Campari accompanied by ginger spiced marmalade on toasted rye bread. Diluted; apples in new wooden boxes and crates of limes before we finally relaxed with Viennese apple strudel and a Wiener Melange coffee.
https://www.smws.com/ivory-keys-exclusiv.drinking_tip: Listening to Mozart Piano Sonata No.11
https://www.smws.com/ivory-keys-exclusiv.name: Ivory keys

https://www.smws.com/jacobite-trip-to-th.description: The nose was a Three Chimneys experience – breakfast (buttered crumpets, bread basket, peach, brandy snaps, lemon tea) in the library (old leather books; herb garden through the window; vestigial peat smoke in the hearth). The palate was deeply satisfying, with an intriguing dark side – gooseberry bushes washed by peaty rain; a perfumed lady swathed in smoke from the Jacobite steam train; honey sweet and samphire salty. The reduced nose found beach bonfires (with heather and hessian chucked on) and mussels cooked in white wine. The palate gave us sherbet straws, lavender, lemon, capers and dry peat smoke – unusual, long-lasting and agreeable.
https://www.smws.com/jacobite-trip-to-th.drinking_tip: OK – The Three Chimneys is the wrong island – but taste this before bedtime and Hebridean dreams are guaranteed.
https://www.smws.com/jacobite-trip-to-th.name: Jacobite trip to the kitchen

https://www.smws.com/jazzed-up-banana-sp.description: Our inspired musings included sawdust sprinkled on soft fruits (plum, peach, pineapple), dried flowers in wicker baskets, crushed nettles and butter popcorn – interesting nose, enthused imaginings. The palate was sweet (butterscotch, caramel popcorn, vanilla, sweet liquorice), but we also found lively, warm wood tannins, chilli jam, fruit schnapps and perfume; hints of gentian and ginger in the finish. The reduced nose offered banana split (including maple syrup, chocolate sauce and ice-cream), but all jazzed up by menthol, eucalyptus, lavender oil, pot-pourri and wasabi. The reduced palate successfully integrated toffee, love hearts and sweetie necklaces with menthol vapour rub and tree bark bitterness.
https://www.smws.com/jazzed-up-banana-sp.drinking_tip: Slightly more vibrant at natural strength – a bit of a curiosity dram.
https://www.smws.com/jazzed-up-banana-sp.name: Jazzed up banana split

https://www.smws.com/juicy-fruit-and-per.description: The nose was exotically fruity (perfumed pear, aromatic strudel) with traces of paint and flowers; we also got sandalwood, beeswax, Dundee cake and leather – just really nice. The palate drew exclamations – ‘Exactly what old whisky should taste like!’ – ‘But so easy to drink!’ – brown sugar sweetness, tart, tropical fruity flavours, tongue-tingling spice, dried fruits, Russian caramels and walnuts. With water, the nose evoked pineapple cubes in a lady’s handbag, sherry and chocolates – rich and elegant. The reduced palate – sugar and spice and all things nice – how could this juicy, fruity essence of perfumed sweetness come from something as simple as barley?
https://www.smws.com/juicy-fruit-and-per.drinking_tip: When you fancy a treat (whether you’ve earned it or not).
https://www.smws.com/juicy-fruit-and-per.name: Juicy fruit and perfumed sweetness

https://www.smws.com/jumping-for-joy.description: Imagine the scene; you have just finished a little DIY and applied putty to replace a glass pane in a window and now you are sitting in a chair outside the cottage looking out to sea which is unusually calm, tranquil and serene - you feel good and take a sip. It was juicy, mouth-watering, the clouds broke and the sun came out and warmed your soul. You added a drop of water and an upcoming breeze carried the smell of drying seaweed on the rocks and the scent of delicate perfumed smoke – was there a mermaid just jumping for joy out of the water?
https://www.smws.com/jumping-for-joy.name: Jumping for joy

https://www.smws.com/lazing-on-a-summer-.description: Drift off to a late summer garden with the hum of bumblebees in the distance. The characters in our story nibbled on strawberries and cream, ripe peaches and pink sugared plums. They sipped champagne cocktails laced with elderflower, rhubarb and muddled mint while breathing in the heady scents of orange blossom and bruised apple from the nearby orchard. The taste delivered licorice stick, dark chocolate orange, coconut and toffee crunch. A sprinkle of water opened up white lilies, lavender, tarocco orange, eucalyptus and sage at dusk. A nightcap of hot ginger root beer and brandy snaps filled with Devonshire cream.
https://www.smws.com/lazing-on-a-summer-.name: Lazing on a summer afternoon

https://www.smws.com/lemon-posset-and-ch.description: A combination of fresh, sweet and fruity aromas greeted the Panel on the nose neat which everyone found very comforting. Freshly cut green apples, juicy white grapes, lemon bonbons, buttery pastry and icing sugar but also new wood and almonds were mentioned. On the taste very fresh, clean and citric like a frozen Italian Zabaglione tart with Marsala-lemon sauce. Water added a floral dimension with aromas of daffodils and roses as well as, turning sweeter, strawberry cupcakes with strawberry buttercream. An incredibly soft mouth-feel with flavours of lemon posset and sugared-almond shortbread as well as champagne truffles.
https://www.smws.com/lemon-posset-and-ch.name: Lemon posset and champagne truffles

https://www.smws.com/life-is-a-beach.description: The nose delivered beach huts, lobster pots, Cullen skink and scallops in their shells – also Pan Drops, black tea, hospital laundry and bread made from peated barley flour. The palate was a wonderful banquet of oysters with lemon and Tabasco, seared salmon and Islay seafood platters, all accompanied by attractive peat smoke, violet, menthol and mint – rich and rewarding. The reduced nose stayed on the beach – ozone, breakers, driftwood and tasty beach barbeques. The reduced palate still had a good chewy texture and that delightful interplay of sweetness and smoke with a cargo of citrus fruits bobbing in the surf.
https://www.smws.com/life-is-a-beach.drinking_tip: Order some oysters, put some of this in a spray bottle and let a mist of fine malt settle on the juicy fruits of the sea.
https://www.smws.com/life-is-a-beach.name: Life is a beach

https://www.smws.com/light-tickles-of-sp.description: The nose was pleasant, attractive, buttery, sweet and biscuity, with suggestions of marshmallow tea-cakes, syrup sponge, Mars bars, dates and marzipan; we also identified lemon, rhubarb, rose petals and waxed jackets. The palate had good weight, with sweetness (treacle tart, sticky toffee pudding and honeyed porridge), amusing light spices (cinnamon, ginger) orange zest and some lovely dry oak. That woodiness increased on the reduced nose, but the fudge, tablet and flapjack sweetness was undiminished. The palate, with water, was even more appealing – light tickles of spice and wood – pepper on fruit and dusty staves – the dry finish, now almost ashy.
https://www.smws.com/light-tickles-of-sp.name: Light tickles of spice and wood

https://www.smws.com/like-a-hot-coal-in-.description: The nose was richly sweet (figs, sherry, cough syrup, Liquorice Allsorts) – just enough to balance the Islay character of smouldering sticks, pine cones, creosoted wood, nicotine tar, leather and brine. The unreduced palate was lively and intense (‘Desperate Dan whisky’ according to one panellist) – peat, tar, ash, sherry and burnt sticks – ‘like putting a hot coal in your mouth’; we also got honey-glazed ham, cinder toffee, salted caramel and smoked chocolate. The reduced nose had salt-encrusted chicken wings, brown sauce and old sea chests. The palate was now rich, deep and treacly – a harmony of honeyed peat and salty smoked bacon.
https://www.smws.com/like-a-hot-coal-in-.drinking_tip: Perfect medicine for reviving ship-wrecked sailors.
https://www.smws.com/like-a-hot-coal-in-.name: Like a hot coal in the mouth

https://www.smws.com/liquorice-catherine.description: The nose neat was like the frenzied whizz of a Catherine Wheel with aromas constantly changing. Grape juice, icing sugar, lime marmalade, fresh roses, honey, all spice, musky perfume, do I need to go on? Before our heads started spinning we tried it; an explosion of cinnamon/liquorice spice and the sweet fruitiness of pineapples and lychees with a quinine like dry finish – it was certainly an experience! Water moved us to a sunny autumn day; leaves were falling like embers in an array of colours and the taste now had that creamy custard sweetness of poached pear in a silky vanilla crème anglaise.
https://www.smws.com/liquorice-catherine.name: Liquorice Catherine wheels

https://www.smws.com/live-life-on-the-ed.description: From the word go it became clear this was no ordinary dram. Imagine yourself opening a box of brand new leather riding boots, or squeezing a tube of double concentrate tomato puree or drinking a hot steaming mug of Bovril to which you have added Maggi seasoning sauce. The taste was sweet, thick and comforting like a steamed treacle sponge pudding and sherry soaked raisins in an almond cake. Adding water, and we were horse-riding across an empty beach on the Costa de la Luz during a short sharp shower and we ended up eating bacon-wrapped dates with a glass of Amontillado.
https://www.smws.com/live-life-on-the-ed.name: Live life on the edge!

https://www.smws.com/lost-in-the-dessert.description: After walking for days we were still not sure which dessert we were in. Was it the apricot tart, lemon curd or spiced apple pie we debated. The ground crunched beneath our feet, perhaps it was creme brulee or even honeycomb crunch. Small pods of vanilla sprouted out of the icing sugar around us. We continued to roam, passing dunes of desiccated coconut and Turkish delight. Then on the horizon… an oasis of scrumptious green apple trees with trunks of polished oak growing beside a lake of golden syrup or perhaps manuka honey and cream. Was this a mirage or pure heaven?
https://www.smws.com/lost-in-the-dessert.name: Lost in the dessert

https://www.smws.com/lovely-jubbly.description: Picture a thatched cottage nestling among fields filled with dusty hay bales after a brief shower of summer rain. Step through a doorway circled by nasturtiums and geraniums and be drawn to the inviting aromas of baking: hot scones, almond tart, cinnamon pastries and rich Battenberg cake. Nibble on white chocolate studded with white peppercorns, yellow jelly babies and juicy lychees in syrup. Our buxom hostess sets blowsy red roses on the table now set with rhubarb and apple pie with vanilla custard, buttered croissants with creamy coffee. She folds palmolive scented towels to air on the Aga. Idyllic!
https://www.smws.com/lovely-jubbly.name: Lovely jubbly!

https://www.smws.com/lubbly-jubbly.description: We found the nose fascinating and complex – some orange blossom and perfumed shrubberies; then cinnamon, cedar and old oak chests – all gift-wrapped in the over-riding sweetness of fudge, caramel, honey and Belgian waffles. The palate was impressive, rich and mouth-expanding – dark chocolate and flowers (romantic!) – cinder toffee, manuka, sultana loaf and Chinese five spice roast pork. We thought the reduced nose could provide hours of entertainment; honeysuckle and Haribos, apple pie, and brandy-soaked raisins – also cough syrup or Fisherman’s Friends in there somewhere. The palate – chocolate-coated toffee, sweet espresso, blackcurrant wine gums, teasing leather and light medicinal notes – lubbly jubbly!
https://www.smws.com/lubbly-jubbly.drinking_tip: Save this for a power cut – it could be more entertaining than the TV – especially if you can be open to its romantic powers.
https://www.smws.com/lubbly-jubbly.name: Lubbly jubbly!

https://www.smws.com/luxurious-afternoon.description: Lively, fresh and fruity on the nose, it presents biscotti and Battenburg cake, espresso coffee, buttered toast with marmalade, honey pancakes, Danish pastries and chocolate cake with butter icing. The texture is thick and buttery and curiously soapy; sweet then sour, with orange chocolate in the aftertaste, and a trace of rosemary in the finish. Water depresses the aroma but adds warm sandalwood and tablet, but now the taste is much reduced: musty with gentle caramel and rhubarb sweets. Best enjoyed straight. The distillery draws its water from the Black Burn in the grounds of Pluscarden Abbey, which once made ale so good ‘it filled the abbey with unutterable bliss’.
https://www.smws.com/luxurious-afternoon.drinking_tip: In a Continental café, after shopping
https://www.smws.com/luxurious-afternoon.name: Luxurious afternoon tea

https://www.smws.com/lychee-martini.description: This was a three course meal in a glass. The starter was a mixed green salad with pecan and honey mustard vinaigrette, followed by wild boar stew with dumplings and cranberries. The dessert was Comice pear with pineapple, quince and pear coulis. Not hungry yet? Wait until you try it! Smoky apple and salty honey glazed roasted ham and crispy pork belly crackling in your mouth. Diluted we got the side orders; chargrilled balsamic vegetable skewers, and sweet & savoury baked potato chips. To finish, how about a fragrant take on a classic cocktail, Lychee Martini - ‘shaken, not stirred’.
https://www.smws.com/lychee-martini.name: Lychee Martini

https://www.smws.com/magic-citrus-water-.description: A light, fresh and fruity aroma greeted the Panel at first; peaches, kiwis, green grapes and pink grapefruit before deeper notes of sweet and sour pork plum sauce, charred toast, vanilla pods and a freshly brewed honeysuckle tea. The taste neat was like a citrus water punch made with slices of lemon, lime, sugar and citric acid - sweet, tart and so very lemony. Adding a drop of water and the nose turned into creamy-thick toasted coconut and vanilla flavoured Greek yoghurt with dried fruits of banana, papaya and pineapple. To taste now smooth, light, refreshing and slightly fizzy like lemon sherbet.
https://www.smws.com/magic-citrus-water-.drinking_tip: Lying in the grass and watching clouds
https://www.smws.com/magic-citrus-water-.name: Magic citrus water punch - Available Online Only

https://www.smws.com/making-your-mind-tw.description: This was lively and fizzy like opening a bottle of sparkling pink lemonade on a beach where crashing breakers rolled in filling the air with salty sea spray, or popping the champagne and those bubbles tickle your nose, making your mind twitch. On the palate we sat in a tapas bar and enjoyed a cold glass of Manzanilla Sherry as sizzling gambas with garlic, chilli and olive oil were being served. With water we could smell the lilies and violet hyacinths in the glass vase on the table and the taste was now a pumpkin carrot cake with a cream cheese frosting.
https://www.smws.com/making-your-mind-tw.name: Making your mind twitch

https://www.smws.com/margarita-cocktail.description: We were greeted with sweet and malty aromas on the nose neat like a hot Ovaltine chocolate with vanilla flavoured soya milk over Weetabix cereal. Other descriptors were that of fresh sawn wood, burnt sugar and Scottish tablet. On the palate initially quite hot, salty and dry; ‘sucks in your cheeks!’ but then turning fruity; boozy cherry chocolate pie or a Peach Melba smoothie. With water, turning very fresh, herbal and botanical and in the taste an intriguing balance of saltiness and sweetness of a well prepared traditional margarita consisting of tequila, Cointreau and lime juice served in a salt rimmed glass.
https://www.smws.com/margarita-cocktail.name: Margarita cocktail

https://www.smws.com/medicine-for-the-so.description: The nose wafted gentle smoke from a summer garden bonfire - carrying aromas of vanilla, honey, grapefruit, herbal tea, first aid boxes and lots of flowers – we thought it harmonious, balanced and inviting. The palate was simply delicious – sweet perfumed peat smoke, parma violets and sherbet straws; honey-glazed gammon on the barbeque and a hospital laundry room –medicinal, healing and wholesome. The reduced nose had delectable floral smoke, citrus and lavender perfume, musk and clover honey, while the palate now had intensified floral sweetness and trailing tendrils of perfumed smoke; even more refreshing and healing than before – medicine for the soul.
https://www.smws.com/medicine-for-the-so.drinking_tip: Any time at all – but it would be a fab dram to share with someone special on Valentine’s Day – forget the champagne.
https://www.smws.com/medicine-for-the-so.name: Medicine for the soul

https://www.smws.com/mellow-and-alluring.description: The rich, inviting nose conjured up an age gone by – polished wood, pipe tobacco in a leather pouch and vanilla pods, with additional alluring sweetness of toffee, honey, Sugar Puffs and pink wafers. The palate also hinted at leather, tobacco and vanilla, with sweeter dimensions of Rich Tea, Garibaldis, toffee and banana loaf. The impression was of mellow understatement; a very appealing combination of venerable age with a lighter playful touch. Water brought mango, banana chips and bourbon-like wood spices to the nose – a blooming flower to be treated with care. The palate was now juicy, sweet and tropical – eminently quaffable.
https://www.smws.com/mellow-and-alluring.drinking_tip: An impressive start to any tasting or sampling session
https://www.smws.com/mellow-and-alluring.name: Mellow and alluring

https://www.smws.com/mellow-yellow.description: We imagined being in a log cabin roasting chestnut on an open fire. At the same time we were preparing soy ginger fried coucous and maple brown sugar crème brûlée. The taste neat was oily, sweet, spicy and herbal with a hint of pepper (even some peppermint) all in perfect balance, just like in a Sazerac cocktail using rye whiskey. With water we got out the paint brushes, not for some DIY but to start an oil painting. Sweeter notes of heather honey arrived whilst on the palate, the first brush strokes on the canvas were made - mellow yellow.
https://www.smws.com/mellow-yellow.drinking_tip: Snuggling up in front of an open fire
https://www.smws.com/mellow-yellow.name: Mellow yellow

https://www.smws.com/midnight-feast-at-p.description: Imagine the excitement, staying up late at night with your chums. The aroma of ponies in a stable mingled with damp hay bales. Snuggled in camphor scented blankets they munched on bacon flavoured crisps, chocolate salted caramel, Bourbon biscuits, butterscotch toffee and dried cranberries. They guzzled warm waffles thick with melting hazelnut and chocolate spread with lashings of ginger beer. One panelist explained it was like ‘licking a creosote fence’ and another found linseed hoof oil. Then a feast of beef Wellington (they were posh), nut loaf, date pudding and prunes, topped off with smoky grilled pork chop and humous.
https://www.smws.com/midnight-feast-at-p.name: Midnight feast at pony club camp

https://www.smws.com/mind-wandering.description: Oily, creamy and waxy aromas at first; linseed oil, coconut sun tan lotion, beeswax polish and hot candle wax. Slowly a picture emerged; a fresh sunny morning, a cottage in a field of heather with lavender scented fresh laundry drying on the washing line and a peat smoking chimney. We stepped into the cottage and for breakfast we were offered smoky maple sage sausages and slightly burnt toast with salted butter and honey. Water transported us into a lavender essence infused steam room with the taste now penetrating deep into the muscles and relaxing the body as well as the mind.
https://www.smws.com/mind-wandering.drinking_tip: Put your feet up, relax, and daydream
https://www.smws.com/mind-wandering.name: Mind-Wandering

https://www.smws.com/mojitos-in-a-librar.description: The nose had suggestions of pepper and chilli lightly sprinkled on exotic fruits (pineapple, mango, cherry) some chocolate, some nuts (hazelnut, cashew), old leather books and piles of cut grass. The palate was hot, fizzy and tangy, with pleasant mouth-coating waxiness – the flavours were reasonably true to the nose – pepper on strawberries, chilli and cinnamon, drinking chocolate, wine gums, poached pears and hay. The reduced nose developed soor plooms, lime jelly, pine and hints of mint – mojitos in a library, perhaps. The palate now combined sweet pastry notes (mandarin flan, vanilla slice) with gentle ginger and pepper on the finish.
https://www.smws.com/mojitos-in-a-librar.drinking_tip: An any-time dram that benefits from a drop of water.
https://www.smws.com/mojitos-in-a-librar.name: Mojitos in a library

https://www.smws.com/mountain-days-and-f.description: Our nose impressions ranged from mountain days (trees, flowers, airy, breezy) to a carpenter’s workshop (sawdust, polished wood) but we all got tangy fruits (sherbet, Tangfastics, lime marmalade, baked apple, duck a l’orange, flying saucers) and we all got leather. The palate had citric fizz and other textural delights, with plenty of interesting sweetness – maple syrup, marmalade on toast, cinnamon on melon, chocolate limes and shortbread. With water, the breezy nose shifted to a beach (beach balls, windbreaks, Cream Soda); the palate now balanced green leaf tartness with sweet, nutty, woody spices. Captain Hugh Munro built the distillery in 1817.
https://www.smws.com/mountain-days-and-f.drinking_tip: Surrounded by the beauties of nature – or to heighten pre-game anticipation.
https://www.smws.com/mountain-days-and-f.name: Mountain days and fun on the beach

https://www.smws.com/mouth-coating-and-m.description: On the nose The Panel found autumnal wood spice, plums, peaches and Portuguese flan. Light Softmints, sweetie necklaces, grapes, green melon and peppermint all sung in harmony. The texture was mouth coating and moreish. “Creamy as you like!” exclaimed one panellist through a mouthful of roasted peaches and coconut panna cotta. Rumbling in the finish there were damsons, melons, custard creams and a prune and Armagnac tart. Water released pink wafers and intense woody vanilla. Then, Garibaldi biscuits, crème brulee caramelised sugar and mushed up bananas. Simultaniously creamy and refreshing (a tart mango coulis on the panna cotta?). Absolutely awesome.
https://www.smws.com/mouth-coating-and-m.name: Mouth coating and moreish

https://www.smws.com/musky-floral-sweet-.description: The nose was old and complex, with musky floral, sweet perfumes, vanilla, blackcurrant, wine gums, honey on toast and quite a bit of apple (apple pie, oak-aged Calvados). The palate was very tasty indeed – flans and pastries bursting with apple, pear, blackcurrant, plum and almond, but with a nice balancing heat of ginger, cinnamon, clove and tobacco. The reduced nose was deliciously exotic – apple and plum orchards (fruits and blossoms), acacia honey and Anton Berg chocolates (plum, marzipan and dark chocolate). The reduced palate had similar flavours and an impressive range from juicy lychees to dry, spicy wood.
https://www.smws.com/musky-floral-sweet-.drinking_tip: Could accompany dessert, or just for reflective, contemplative moods.
https://www.smws.com/musky-floral-sweet-.name: Musky, floral, sweet perfumes

https://www.smws.com/nectar-of-the-gods.description: The nose was fathoms deep and alluringly sweet. Initial notes of cherries, almonds and honey mellowed into a simmering copper pot of strawberry jam, inexplicably situated in a dunnage warehouse. Also in the corner; an old apothecary chest and the polished bureau of an experienced calligrapher (beeswax polish and inkwells). Exotic notes came in time; pomegranate, dark cocoa, dried apricot and well-aged brandy. A sublime texture caresses the palate, with flavours of cherries soaked in a Manhattan cocktail, then guava, and deep brooding flavours of teriyaki sauce, Peking duck, cinnamon and honey. Truly exceptional, with almond, ginger and rye spice in the finish. Ambrosia…
https://www.smws.com/nectar-of-the-gods.name: Nectar of the Gods

https://www.smws.com/no-pussycat.description: After 17 years this whisky was moved to a second-fill Sauternes hogshead, expanding its complexity. The nose has an immediate fruitiness (pineapple, perfumed pear, apple snow, raspberry sauce on ice-cream), then a level of dark chocolate-dipped crystallised orange and lemon slices; thirdly, old-fashioned libraries (wooden shelves, leather-bound books). The palate has good mouth presence, with sweet and tart flavours (Haribo apple rings, raspberry coulis), leather and cumin and coriander – certainly no pussycat. The reduced nose – apple pie and a fruit bowl on a wooden table. The palate now holds exotic fruit-skins (orange, lime, mango) – the warm spices receding to the after-taste.
https://www.smws.com/no-pussycat.drinking_tip: To awaken the palate and the senses.
https://www.smws.com/no-pussycat.name: No pussycat

https://www.smws.com/nordic-nosh.description: We felt like filling our plate from the buffet at a garden party. Whilst some got smoked mackerel salad with beetroot, sweet potato and horseradish seasoned with red wine vinaigrette, others enjoyed sweet cured marinated herring and new potato salad with sour cream. The main course was sweet and slightly ashy, barbequed succulent herbal sausages, Swedish meatballs, dry-cured smoked ham and summertime sweet pickles. With water, the vegetarian option, grilled glazed kebab skewers with courgette, aubergine, cherry tomatoes and pepper in a honey mustard oil dressing and in the finish, slightly burnt with a hint of ash, marshmallows.
https://www.smws.com/nordic-nosh.name: Nordic nosh

https://www.smws.com/nougat-and-chocolat.description: A calm nose greeted the Panel with plenty of sweet notes like American-style pancakes with maple syrup, all-butter almond croissant filled with apricot cream, black bullets (those old fashioned mint flavoured sweets) and liquorice torpedoes. On the palate; comforting like a puff pastry caramel apple turnover with the sweetness of a nougat and chocolate semifreddo. Water added a sweet fruitiness, like a walk through a banana plantation in warm trade winds while the flavours were now those of a Peach Melba with sweet lightly whipped cream and a Virgin Peach Margarita, a cocktail using lime juice and agave syrup.
https://www.smws.com/nougat-and-chocolat.name: Nougat and chocolate semifreddo

https://www.smws.com/ode-to-grown-up-geo.description: Hearts were broken across the land when gorgeous George tied the knot. You can find him in a glass, with red lipstick on his collar. Luscious damson jam and red shiny apples, tropical lychee and ripe pineapple promise riches. Then, controlled, poised and classy, reclining in a battered leather Chesterfield with exotic figs, orange zest, habanero jam and tamarind paste. Softening with time like cashmere, to toffee coated marshmallow and nutty nougat but with the bite of mustard seeds. After 20 years in an ex-bourbon hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a port barrique for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/ode-to-grown-up-geo.name: Ode to Grown up George

https://www.smws.com/oh-how-joyfully.description: A gentle and soft aroma to start, almost shy, but it heightened our expectations of what was to come. Making baked apples with brown sugar, cinnamon, chopped pecans, currants, raisins and sultanas as well as anise-flavoured cookies, a smell of pine needles and wood sap from a fresh cut fir tree – happy childhood memories of the night before Christmas. It is a waxy, oily, honey mouth coating texture with flavours of sandalwood, resin and exotic spices. With water there is a hint of wood smoke followed by candied orange and lemon peel, dried fruits and cardamom. Now on the taste a pleasant light woodiness combined with fragrant spices and fresh mint - this makes a great Advent dram.
https://www.smws.com/oh-how-joyfully.drinking_tip: Whilst wrapping Christmas presents or decorating the tree
https://www.smws.com/oh-how-joyfully.name: Oh How Joyfully

https://www.smws.com/old-codger-with-a-j.description:
Offer Exclusive Bottle
An unusual old character brimming with rich honey, plums infused with cinnamon and saffron. The panel found wet wool along with earthy aromas. The taste neat was of Jammy Dodgers and melted stroopwafel, then slightly burned toast with sweet jam and hints of mint. The chair was reminded of the aromas of the shortbread factory in Aberlour High Street with bagfuls of vanilla pods, maple syrup and creme brulee. It remained lively with fig and peach giving out to toasted banana bread, and fruit scones. ‘Old Spice’ aftershave mingled in the finish, still plenty of pep in this pensioner.
https://www.smws.com/old-codger-with-a-j.name: Old Codger with a Jammy Dodger

https://www.smws.com/old-fashioned-manha.description: Initially we got musty old books and wet hay in the barn; but give this one time and you will be rewarded. Fresher notes arrived with cut grass and grapefruit juice but then also deeper aromas of preparing a new flower bed and even a spicy chorizo and rocket sandwich appeared. On the palate, two classic cocktails; Manhattan with brandy soaked cherries and an Old Fashioned with a twist of citrus rind garnished with an orange slice. Water brought out spicy, vanilla aromas as well as croissants with raspberry jam and on the palate, beer marinated moose steak with miso buttered sautéed potatoes.
https://www.smws.com/old-fashioned-manha.drinking_tip: When left with plenty to ponder
https://www.smws.com/old-fashioned-manha.name: Old Fashioned Manhattan

https://www.smws.com/once-you-pop.description: The aromas neat were all very attractive and popular with the panel members; raspberry ripple ice cream, brandy snaps, caramel wafers, Key lime pie, salted toffee sauce and sour pineapple refresher chew bars. The flavours were all very moreish; sweet and salty popcorn, beef noodle cup-a-soup, Maggi liquid seasoning and memories of those sachets containing flavoured powder to sprinkle over your crisps. Water transported us into a trendy hair salon; wet hair, wet towels, bleach, perfumed shampoo and plenty of hairspray serving fresh tangerine juice, Parma Violet Spritz cocktails and Margaritas in a salted rimmed glass with slice of lime.
https://www.smws.com/once-you-pop.drinking_tip: Getting ready for a beach party
https://www.smws.com/once-you-pop.name: Once you pop

https://www.smws.com/one-night-in-bangko.description: A fresh, crispy and fruity start like that of white grape juice or a mint cucumber lime cooler was followed by sweeter aromas of cranachan and Tunnocks milk chocolate teacakes. The taste neat had an intense sweetness but at the same time a minty mouth refreshing effect like a sweet strawberry and lime mojito. With water, surprisingly herbal and floral, a rocky spiral herb garden and an aromatic potpourri with dried flowers. With time hot buttered pancakes emerged. The flavour was now that of a Thai vegetable curry with fragrant rice using coconut milk, coriander, chillies and lemon grass.
https://www.smws.com/one-night-in-bangko.name: One night in Bangkok

https://www.smws.com/orange-exposition.description: The rich and fruity depths to this whisky instantly intrigued. Orange oil, Bird’s custard on baked apples and a touch of noble rot displayed maturity and complexity. On tasting, we were introduced to the sweetness of Iced Gems, Dolly Mixtures, hazelnuts and honey. Spearmint chewing gum freshness appeared with water, whilst pleasant solvent notes danced in the background. Acteone, airfix glue, linseed oil and tart black cherries lay behind layers of honey, apricot yoghurt and buttery pastry. These themes continued in the reduced palate, intensely sweet and biscuity notes, orange oil, orange muscat, emulsion paint and aniseed to taste. Raisins, hot crossed buns, spiced honey and Chocolate Oranges linger in the finish. Sublime!
https://www.smws.com/orange-exposition.name: Orange exposition

https://www.smws.com/outdoor-masculine-d.description: The nose was complex and interesting – sweet and spicy with some cosmetics and light struck match, plus an array of outdoor impressions (earthy, grassy, ripe fruits, wood sap, twigs and riverbanks). It seemed fresher with water (peach melba yoghurt, leaf mould, washing blowing in the breeze) though one panellist got a rugby player’s kit-bag. The palate however had massive, intense sweetness and mouth-scorching peppery, ginger heat – panellists reported Vimto concentrate and rhubarb dipped in brown sugar. With water, we found toffee, butterscotch, Old English spangles and ice-cream soda, with a few more masculine hints of mint tic-tacs, old wood and allotments.
https://www.smws.com/outdoor-masculine-d.drinking_tip: Benefits from water and the attraction is mostly in the taste – a drinker’s, rather than a sniffer’s, dram.
https://www.smws.com/outdoor-masculine-d.name: Outdoor, masculine dram

https://www.smws.com/party-on-a-paddle-s.description: The nose took one panellist to a public bar with a coal fire; another was supping oysters by rock-pools and a third enjoyed salt and chilli-rubbed ribs, crab and toasted marshmallows on a beach fire. We all agreed the palate was great – intense, salty, smoky, sweet and slightly acidic – tropical fruit and flying saucers, charred prawns, Barbour jackets and campfire smoke. The reduced nose, with coal, ash, lady’s perfume, manly musk and an engine room, could have been a party on a paddle steamer. The reduced palate – sweet and ashy with good savoury notes, recalled breezy summer days on Islay beaches.
https://www.smws.com/party-on-a-paddle-s.drinking_tip: Would work with food - or to accompany dreams
https://www.smws.com/party-on-a-paddle-s.name: Party on a paddle steamer

https://www.smws.com/perfumed-and-comple.description: This complex nose started with Yorkshire puddings and donuts, then quickly morphed into Moroccan spice markets, dunnage warehouses, old roses, boxwood, Chanel No 5, rum mojitos and spiced pear – a remarkable transformation. The palate retained the perfumes but found new sweetness (maple Danish, waffles, caramel) and fruit (chocolate limes, baked apple, toffee apple, rhubarb). The reduced nose had pot-pourri, marmalade, rose Turkish Delight and the ladies changing room at the swimming pool (apple shampoo, talc). The palate was deliciously tasty, sophisticated and complex, with lime marmalade, lemongrass, jasmine, rose and various feminine aromatics, from Clinique hand lotion to Miss Dior parfum.
https://www.smws.com/perfumed-and-comple.drinking_tip: A bit of a boudoir dram – maybe while dressing to attend the theatre or the Queen’s garden party.
https://www.smws.com/perfumed-and-comple.name: Perfumed and complex

https://www.smws.com/perfumed-elegance.description: The first thing we noticed as we eagerly filled our glasses was the unusually dark colour. We knew we were in for something out of the ordinary. The nose did not disappoint. The fruity, perfumed elegance reminded one panellist of whisky matured in Mizunara oak. There were delicate scents of beeswax and blossom and some fragrant woody notes (cedar, sandalwood). A full bodied leathery note underpinned everything. To taste, we found an array of ripe autumn fruits (plums, pears, damson, blackberries). There was a sweet, fatty flavour like clotted cream. Water brought raspberry coulis, icing sugar and a bouquet of exotic flowers.
https://www.smws.com/perfumed-elegance.drinking_tip: One to really take your time over
https://www.smws.com/perfumed-elegance.name: Perfumed elegance

https://www.smws.com/pile-driver-punch-w.description: The nose hinted at paint and glue – water shifted this to fresh linen and warm photocopies; we didn’t find that in the taste. The rest of the nose had herbal, grassy notes (hay, thyme, cucumber) and fruity sweetness (brandy snaps, orange zest, peach stones, golden syrup, chilli marmalade). The palate had a pile-driver punch of spirity heat (even with water) but after a couple of sips we learned to take it on the chin – nice grassy, cereal notes, including popcorn, riverbank reeds and mint, then more of that fruity sweetness (mandarin, rhubarb and pineapple, with spun sugar, vanilla and pink Chewits).
https://www.smws.com/pile-driver-punch-w.drinking_tip: A good one to sip while watching action movies.
https://www.smws.com/pile-driver-punch-w.name: Pile-driver punch whisky

https://www.smws.com/pink-peppercorn.description: We found a rich, engaging and multi-faceted spectrum of aromas. Perfume and incense derived from sandalwood, thick set Manuka honey, creamy orange scones, plum pudding as well as cherry and spiced orange marmalade. The taste did not disappoint; well-balanced and well integrated, with exotic spices, pink peppercorns, candied blood orange slices as well as banana bread and sultana cake. Even with the slightest drop of water the nose became fairly simple and straight forward, but at the same time still very pleasant indeed - honeycomb cinder toffee. The flavour was now spiced cupcakes with an orange filling and a cream cheese frosting.
https://www.smws.com/pink-peppercorn.name: Pink Peppercorn

https://www.smws.com/pink-wafers-in-a-la.description: On the nose, pencil shavings, linoleum and sawmills underlaid sweet pastry, Black Forest gateau and some more perfumed aromas (cigarette packets, geranium, purple Chewits, apples, make-up). To taste, light perfume, leather and pepper could not intimidate the sweetness of Terry’s chocolate orange, Turkish Delight, toffee, sultana cake, Newberry Fruits and raspberry sauce on ice-cream. Even better with water, the nose gave us Fry’s Chocolate Cream, pink wafers and marshmallows in a lady’s hat shop; the palate ran light leather tingles over sweet delicacies (chocolate cake, candy floss, heather honey) along with spice, fruit and flowers. Inver House owns this Cromdale distillery.
https://www.smws.com/pink-wafers-in-a-la.drinking_tip: Water and time improve it – so make sure you give it time and space to settle and breathe.
https://www.smws.com/pink-wafers-in-a-la.name: Pink wafers in a lady’s hat shop

https://www.smws.com/piri-piri-and-teriy.description: We all were enticed by a pleasant, sweet array of aromas reminding us of a cake shop. Iced buns are next to vanilla slices and Eccles cakes; apple strudel is just coming out of the oven, as are peach tartlets, and a hot cup of nettle and lemon herb tea. The taste did not conform; we got spiced chicken, Japanese teriyaki and Portuguese piri-piri style as well as oysters with lemon and tabasco sauce. Water added aromas of a lady’s handbag; perfume, lipstick, cigarette packet and soft mints, whereas the taste was sweet and sour with a minerallic rock salt finish.
https://www.smws.com/piri-piri-and-teriy.name: Piri-Piri and Teriyaki chicken

https://www.smws.com/pizza-on-the-beach.description: Imagine sitting around a beach campfire on a cool windy evening making pizzas. We had quite a selection of them on the go; seafood with chopped clams, shrimp and squid, Hawaiian with ham and pineapple and Greek with caramelized onions, olives and feta. While we were waiting for them to be ready we dipped crusty walnut bread into olive oil and tucked into scrummy rosemary and thyme sausage pie. Diluted, we got even hungrier, cola ham with maple & mustard glaze on the nose whilst on the palate sweet peat smoked black pepper and sea salt pork cracklings.
https://www.smws.com/pizza-on-the-beach.name: Pizza on the beach

https://www.smws.com/playful-popping-in-.description: The nose context was a fruit market (pear, orange, lemon, lychee, cherry) but we also found a leather handbag containing fag packets and nail varnish and paper bags of assorted fudge (vanilla, rum and raisin, ginger). The neat palate was quite an experience – apple pie, vanilla ice-cream, puff candy and honey sweetness, with menthol cigarette, aniseed and cardamom depth, while fizzy Vimto, soor plooms and white pepper popped playfully on the tongue. The reduced nose developed pleasantly – Battenberg, Bounty Bars and champagne sorbet. The palate continued to tingle and enervate – Lucozade, lemongrass and lollipop sticks. From the first distillery in Rothes.
https://www.smws.com/playful-popping-in-.name: Playful popping in a fruit market

https://www.smws.com/pleasing-teasing-an.description: Aromas of Black Forest gateau, honeycomb, toffee, caramel, apple, pear and candied orange and lemon led to comments such as ‘Enticing’, ‘Pampering’, ‘Silky soft’ and ‘Luxurious’. The palate lived up to expectations – pleasing, teasing and comforting – sensually sweet honey shimmied in the mouth with seductive splashes of exotic citrus, all embraced by fine undertones of avuncular oak. The reduced nose turned more tropical – tinned pineapple, mango, peach, candied angelica and marmalade balanced the milk chocolate and Danish pastry sweetness. The extraordinary palate, with hints of nutmeg, baked apple and sophisticated citric peel left us all feeling calmed and delighted.
https://www.smws.com/pleasing-teasing-an.drinking_tip: When you need a haven in a heartless world.
https://www.smws.com/pleasing-teasing-an.name: Pleasing, teasing and comforting

https://www.smws.com/ploughman-s-on-the-.description: Maritime, mineralic, salty, slightly smoky - the adjectives used to describe lobster pods, wet rope on a sandy beach, seaweed but also Iberico ham and old fashioned dentist’s mouthwash. The palate neat was all about food on a beach barbeque; scampi, crab meat, salted prawns, smoky fish chowder and spiced lamb sausages. With water at first aromas of smouldering tractor tyres which then developed into a tribe of goats arriving on the beach with the goat herder eating fish and chips. By then we started to enjoy a Ploughman’s platter with blue cheese, plum chutney and a celery stick.
https://www.smws.com/ploughman-s-on-the-.name: Ploughman’s on the beach

https://www.smws.com/pocket-rocket.description: Have you ever wondered how to make the perfect ‘Sex on the Beach’ … cocktail? You have most ingredients for it on the nose neat; peach schnapps, vodka, cranberry, orange and pineapple juice, finally place a maraschino cherry on the rim of the glass and enjoy. It was sweet, hot and spicy with a truly remarkable chewy mouthfeel like a hot Thai green coconut curry. With water, less intense but a more intriguing sweetness; fresh pineapple cubes, caramelised sugar, gooseberry fool and blueberry muffins and the taste, a luscious Indian dessert made of rose syrup, kulfi, basil seeds and vermicelli called Falooda.
https://www.smws.com/pocket-rocket.name: Pocket rocket

https://www.smws.com/popping-candy-in-fl.description: The nose was sweet, fresh and bright – lemon puffs, lemon drizzle cake, flower meadows, iced gems, polished pine and perfumed handkerchiefs. The palate had an attractive mouth-feel and soft, sweet flavours of coconut fondant, porridge, honey and syrup, but with a noticeable spicy heat (liquorice, ginger, cinnamon) and some light citric bitterness in the finish. The reduced nose was still gentle (dried tropical fruits, lemon cup cakes) but the wood seemed to shine through more definitely – clean straw, autumn leaves, peanut brittle. The reduced palate was delicate and attractive, with suggestions of tart fruits, popping candy, dried apricots and new wood.
https://www.smws.com/popping-candy-in-fl.drinking_tip: Could be a light and delicate aperitif.
https://www.smws.com/popping-candy-in-fl.name: Popping candy in flower meadows

https://www.smws.com/port-poached-pear-o.description: A fresh succulent sweet and fruity aroma greeted us, like a boozy fresh fruit flan with strawberries, blueberries and kiwis, a raspberry Sherry trifle or brandy-soaked baked apples with cranberry compote. On the taste we enjoyed seriously filled chocolates with coffee and Italian walnut liqueur, calvados and cherry brandy. Drop of water and Sicilian style cannoli with plenty of sweet Marsala wine and on the palate, red wine and port poached pears with Mascarpone - absolutely delicious! After 24 years in an ex-bourbon refill barrel, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/port-poached-pear-o.drinking_tip: Sweet boozy dreams are made of this
https://www.smws.com/port-poached-pear-o.name: Port poached pear

https://www.smws.com/pretty-but-gritty.description: The nose had sweet, floral perfumes and clean, gentle smoke; we found parma violets and sherbet straws, strawberry jam, coal-tar soap, candles, laundry and magazines in a dentist’s waiting room. Perfumed incense smoke continued on the palate, along with wood ash, soot, tar and coal – strangely pretty and gritty at the same time. The reduced nose was also two-faced – salt-water over bonfire embers and seared lamb with rosemary co-existed with bright citric, floral sweetness. It all came magically together on the reduced palate – perfumed, sweet, juicy and satisfying – violets, lavender and smoke on the water – must be a Deep Purple dram!
https://www.smws.com/pretty-but-gritty.drinking_tip: In a flower garden at dusk.
https://www.smws.com/pretty-but-gritty.name: Pretty but gritty

https://www.smws.com/punch-with-a-punch.description: This sample deserves your time and full attention, therefore whatever you are doing, stop! Pears poached in Sauternes, chocolate roulade with Kirsch-soaked cherries, moist and boozy fruitcake with rum and Sherry as well as Madeira soaked prunes. Wait for the taste; deep, rumbling and sturdy! Dark Jamaican gingerbread, dark chocolate covered spiced orange slices, plum wine chocolate truffles as well as Crema Catalana with caramelised figs. With a drop of water we were served an original Sachertorte and a complete transformation on the palate; juicy, spicy, fruity like a tropical punch with the additional excitement of hot red chili peppers added – Tantalizing!
https://www.smws.com/punch-with-a-punch.drinking_tip: Please, can I have some more?
https://www.smws.com/punch-with-a-punch.name: Punch with a punch

https://www.smws.com/punchy-spice-explos.description: “Wow! This is punchy” exclaimed one panellist. We marvelled at the strong bourbon spice and exotic heat. Ginger nuts, young rum and bananas gave way to a whisky sour cocktail and some melted brown sugar. One stirred porridge and honey on the stove whilst another discovered the more savoury edge of sauteed mushrooms. Water brought explosions of sweetness and the ginger took on a candied feel. The texture was almost chewy. Further exploration brought chai tea with condensed milk, buttery shortbread and Thai spices simmering in coconut milk. Lovely lemongrass, ginger and then some banana bread. Espresso dregs with brown sugar to finish.
https://www.smws.com/punchy-spice-explos.drinking_tip: Really open up with a splash of water
https://www.smws.com/punchy-spice-explos.name: Punchy spice explosion

https://www.smws.com/pure-indulgence.description: This one made its presence known straight away. A rich and flavourful punch like dark thick cut Seville orange marmalade on spongy crumpets and black currant jam sweetened with honey on buttered burnt toast. The taste was that of seared duck breast with red wine and orange sauce. With water; cinnamon roasted pineapples and cinder toffee and the never ending finish was a dark chocolate cake flavoured with Barolo Chinato and served with whipped cream and raspberries – pure indulgence. After 24 years in an ex-bourbon refill hogshead, we transferred this whisky directly into a Sauternes cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/pure-indulgence.name: Pure Indulgence

https://www.smws.com/purple-relaxation.description: Delicate perfumed lavender smoke made us feel calm, relaxed and all the tension fell away as we imagined wandering through a field of purple flowers on our way home where a freshly brewed cup of Lapsang souchong tea was waiting for us. The taste was almost identical to the nose; peaceful, sweet, slightly herbal, lavender smoke. Diluted even more delicate, if that is possible, sweet smoked iced gems and a blueberry lavender fizz cocktail with a slice of lime. On the palate, delicious, subtle flavours and the texture was that of lavender honeycomb apricot ice cream with a suggestion of purple smoke.
https://www.smws.com/purple-relaxation.name: Purple Relaxation

https://www.smws.com/ready-steady-bake.description: The kitchen windows steamed up with the heady aromas seeping from the hot ovens. Rosy cheeked bakers toiled over trays of warm brioche buns studded with ginger and nutmeg and glossily iced buns decorated with marron glace and crystalised orange. The bakers downed their tools and fortified themselves with mugs of mead laced with orange zest and traces of chilli. They nibbled at soft, sweet nougat with crushed hazelnuts while reading glossy expensive magazines. Back to work! They drew hot loaves from the ovens: dark rye bread and toasted spelt rolls, ready to be enjoyed with thick cut grapefruit marmalade.
https://www.smws.com/ready-steady-bake.name: Ready…steady...bake!

https://www.smws.com/record-shop-at-the-.description: Heather and lavender buttonholes on crisply starched shirts mingled with blackcurrant sweets and parma violets. Aromas of vinyl, plastic sleeves, new carpet tiles, fake leather jackets, hairspray and cider reminded one panelist of record hunting. Another found distinctive pit lanes at Le Mons: motor oil, rubber, fumes, overalls and leather car seats. Collectively they discovered truffled honey on toasted pine nuts, melted toy soldiers and smoked ham studded with wild garlic. Water released tobacco, damp tweed, scorched heather and dried lavender. A burnt twig used a dipstick and new wellington boots. Red vinyl records stored in a mahogany chest of drawers.
https://www.smws.com/record-shop-at-the-.drinking_tip: It’ll take you back in time
https://www.smws.com/record-shop-at-the-.name: Record shop at the races

https://www.smws.com/refined-and-gentle-.description: The nose, somewhat subdued at the start, suggested grappa and light fruitiness (blackcurrant pastilles, orange barley water) before arriving at sweet marzipan, icing sugar and chocolate hazelnuts, with pepper, liquorice, ginger and humbugs to finish.
