The palate had tart fruits (damson, plum, crème de cassis, Kir Royal) with marmalade on toast, honey and a late kick of pepper, clove and ginger-nuts. The reduced nose wandered to a saw-mill by a swimming pool – the palate’s liquorice and blackcurrant and Turkish Delight, was refined and gentle, but with sustaining warmth and attractive qualities. This make has long been very popular in Italy.
https://www.smws.com/refined-and-gentle-.drinking_tip: A wee contemplative dram or to lift you up when down in the dumps.
https://www.smws.com/refined-and-gentle-.name: Refined and gentle, with a little kick

https://www.smws.com/refreshing-and-rela.description: A sweet malty aroma greeted the Panel at first with hints of dustiness like Weetabix baked in golden syrup. With time a sweet and sour sauce with orange juice and ginger develops as well as homemade sweet custard cream. The taste neat initially was fresh, sharp and sweet like freshly pressed apple juice but this was soon followed by a creamy and sweet perfectly made New York style cheesecake. Water released aromas of lemon curd on toast, a poppy-seed roll fresh out of the oven and slow roasted balsamic tomatoes. The taste now like celery sticks with a Mediterranean dip and cucumber in sour cream.
https://www.smws.com/refreshing-and-rela.drinking_tip: For a calm and soothing warm afternoon
https://www.smws.com/refreshing-and-rela.name: Refreshing and relaxing

https://www.smws.com/refreshing-elderflo.description: The fruity notes are dominating to start; peaches, ripe melons and pineapples but very soon sweeter aromas appear with white chocolate ice cream, limoncello and a refreshing elderflower fizz with a delicate minty note. The taste neat is still fruity but with a drying, slightly chalky mouth-feel. Pear biscuits, cooked pineapples, grapefruits - all with a dusting of icing sugar. With water, crystallized fruits in Tutti Frutti ice cream, lavender and lily of the valley, reminding some of a lady’s powder compact. The taste is now very floral with an elegant perfume scent; a chic and sophisticated example from this distillery 3 miles south of Elgin still using worm tubs to cool the distilled vapours.
https://www.smws.com/refreshing-elderflo.drinking_tip: Whilst playing croquet on a sunny afternoon
https://www.smws.com/refreshing-elderflo.name: Refreshing Elderflower Fizz

https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-quiet.description: We imagined a study – leather writing pad on an old desk – sherbet lemons, apple Chewits, lemon bonbons and mint humbugs lay on the desk, while a vase of freesias sat on a newly unwrapped Casio keyboard. Water turned the sweets into Moffat toffees, mint éclairs and vanilla fairy cakes in Tupperware boxes – lemon candles replaced the freesias. The palate tasted extremely sweet (nougat, candy cigarettes, marshmallows, burnt toffee, Christmas cake icing), but with an interesting woody, spicy heat. The reduced palate retained golden syrup and Victoria sponge sweetness, but seemed fruitier – lemon zest, apple sours, peaches and raspberry Creamola Foam.
https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-quiet.drinking_tip: Before dinner; before dancing – or just relaxing in the study – it’s versatile.
https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-quiet.name: Relaxing in a quiet study

https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-tropi.description: We were greeted with the deep rich aroma of an India tea chest, very old leather armchairs and an ancient pouch for pipe tobacco. Behind those heavy aromas light and floral notes make an appearance; honeysuckle, orchids and jasmine blossoms all giving the impression of being in a flower garden during summer. Exciting to taste neat, despite its age, big with some heat and spice, but at the same time soft and smooth like a coconut lip balm or a tropical sun cream. With water fresher, aromatic moist air after a tropical downpour or like a walk-in humidor. The taste now soft, mellow, creamy - a shammy leather with a very long coconut finish. A fascinating make from the distillery close to Sandend.
https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-tropi.drinking_tip: Sitting in a tropical garden with a good book
https://www.smws.com/relaxing-in-a-tropi.name: Relaxing in a tropical garden

https://www.smws.com/remarkable-freshnes.description: The nose had remarkable freshness to it – lemon, laundry, pine, menthol, pan drops and anise – it also had Battenberg cake, buttery toffee, toasted marshmallows and coca-cola. Adding water, we found Lady Grey tea, orange, elderflower, marzipan, ginger cake and ‘a eucalyptus forest in Madeira’. The neat palate had beguiling sweetness – toffee, honey, shortbread, Eccles cake, chocolate and coconut, but with gingerbread, liquorice, sandalwood, marmite, tarragon and mint to balance it. The reduced palate was certainly tasty – tutti-frutti ice-cream, spun sugar, rum and raisin, raspberry, pineapple and vanilla flavours and more; underneath that – menthol, nutmeg and tobacco hints swirled and twirled.(101 words)
https://www.smws.com/remarkable-freshnes.name: Remarkable freshness, beguiling sweetness

https://www.smws.com/rich-treacly-and-su.description: We found a nose that was rich and treacly, with brandy snaps, cinder toffee, stroop waffles, dates, black tea, HP sauce, balsamic reduction, lavender perfume and unlit cigars. The unreduced palate was substantial and mouth-filling – flavours of sherry, leather, burnt sticks, creosote, marmite, ‘fly cemeteries’ and pain au chocolat, with some smoky bacon and dry-rub ribs as well. The reduced nose found rum baba, honeyed figs, aromatic duck, gingerbread, hibiscus tea and dark cherries in chocolate. The palate was now toasted coconut flapjacks, liquorice and prunes – dark and sumptuous, with good chewy textures; brown sugar sweetness nicely balancing the dry oak.
https://www.smws.com/rich-treacly-and-su.drinking_tip: Your favourite armchair, by the fire, wind howling outside – nothing can touch you.
https://www.smws.com/rich-treacly-and-su.name: Rich, treacly, and sumptuous

https://www.smws.com/salt-water-taffy.description: The aromas were all over the place; earthy grow bag, surgical spirit, melted salted butter, creamy mushroom soup as well as a grilled cheese and ham sandwich. The flavours neat started with hot chilli peppers followed by chewing a burnt twig, to salted peanuts and ended up in a butterscotch sundae. Water tamed the nose somewhat and a salty theme emerged; preserved lemons, salt water taffy and warm sourdough bread with, no surprise, salted butter. The taste was that of sweet and salted popcorn, warm salted caramel sauce over vanilla ice cream and a green tea with a twist of lemon in the finish.
https://www.smws.com/salt-water-taffy.drinking_tip: Are you up for a challenge?
https://www.smws.com/salt-water-taffy.name: Salt Water Taffy

https://www.smws.com/scandinavian-garden.description: On the nose we got various intimations of gardens and greenhouses (grass, hedgerows, mint, tomato vines, tree bark, earthy) some appealing fruit (peach melba, raspberry, honeyed apricots, lime) and a good blast of Scandinavian sauna wood. Fruit was also present on the palate – peach cobbler, lemon custard, stewed plums and grapes, with a bit of mouth-drawing woodiness and a curious black olive and manzanilla salty tang. Water brought lemon puffs and blackcurrants to the nose, while the reduced palate was an interesting combination of honey and marron glacé sweetness with some salty and savoury hints towards anchovy and olive bread.
https://www.smws.com/scandinavian-garden.drinking_tip: The salty tang gives a thirst, so drink it with a beer chaser.
https://www.smws.com/scandinavian-garden.name: Scandinavian garden sauna

https://www.smws.com/sea-breezes-over-th.description: The nose had vanilla ice-cream, apple, honey and milk chews, but what caught our attention were floral fragrances of heather, lavender and elderflower, gardens after rain and sea breezes over the vernal machair. The neat taste was intense, sharp and mouth-drawing, but clean – with flavours of light smoke, lots of citrus, rock-pools and parma violets – nice! The reduced nose ranged from sherbet straws to salted sweet potato fries – but the landscape evoked was gentle smoke drifting over the machair (thyme, bog myrtle, wild flowers) and sun on granite outcrops. The palate was lovely, fresh and sharp – smoke, salt, apple and lime.
https://www.smws.com/sea-breezes-over-th.drinking_tip: Best enjoyed in the company of seagulls on a cliff top somewhere, looking out to sea.
https://www.smws.com/sea-breezes-over-th.name: Sea breezes over the vernal machair

https://www.smws.com/shaken-not-stirred.colour: Gold fountain pen (that’s really a poison pen)
https://www.smws.com/shaken-not-stirred.description: Young Bond prepared the ingredients for his cocktail: bruised mint, Gomme syrup, pink peppercorn and aromatic cherry and violet. As he mixed his ingredients for this Old Fashioned together he scanned the scene, it was a bit of a mystery. A large arrangement of flowers was the first observation. A table set with a curious collection: Fox Glacier mints, chocolate chip ice cream, Jolly Jammers and salted limes. He sipped his cocktail and enjoyed it’s sprightly kick. The perfumed scent of some exotic beauty lingered. He investigated further finding cream soda, marshmallow and Kendal Mint Cake. What did it all mean?
https://www.smws.com/shaken-not-stirred.name: Shaken not stirred

https://www.smws.com/sharing-caring-lovi.description: On the nose, woody perfumes (furniture polish, pine) mingled with aromatic fruits (pineapple, mango, sangria, mojito) against a sweet background of brown sugar, toffee, honey and marzipan. The palate was full-flavoured and delicious – mainly sweet (crème brûlée, puff candy, caramel, flapjacks) but with black pepper and sandalwood interest. The reduced nose continued this magical combo of sweetness and wood –chocolate, toffees and cakes on a polished wooden board; combined with aromatherapy oils this seemed to present a gesture of sharing and caring love. The palate had mixed dried fruit and moist cinnamon and ginger cake – sweet, spicy, fragrant and ‘fabby-dabby-doo’.
https://www.smws.com/sharing-caring-lovi.drinking_tip: When you have plenty of time to appreciate it – ideal for sharing with someone you care for and love.
https://www.smws.com/sharing-caring-lovi.name: Sharing, caring loving dram

https://www.smws.com/sinbad-preparing-fo.description: The invigorating nose gave us cinder toffee, crème brûlée, burnt sugar, maple syrup, smoky bacon crisps, pork crackling and patchouli; also something between an old-fashioned boat-builder’s yard and an Eastern rug shop – we thought of Sinbad preparing for a journey. Adding water brought Dairy Milk chocolate in a steamroller cab and an Asian dish of prunes and roast pork. The palate was big, tasty and dark – treacle cake, pancakes and bacon with maple syrup, caramel pop-corn, vanilla ice-cream, chilli chocolate, caramelized apples with pork; beef jerky and leather. In reduction – sweeter and more pleasant –tarte tatin, bacon, custard and cigars.
https://www.smws.com/sinbad-preparing-fo.drinking_tip: Not an all night drinking dram – but could be very useful after chopping logs in the snow.
https://www.smws.com/sinbad-preparing-fo.name: Sinbad preparing for a journey

https://www.smws.com/slightly-wicked-swe.description: The nose hinted at slightly wicked sweet treats (cinnamon swirl, treacle toffee, iced ginger cake) with further interesting aromatics complicating the script – pot-pourri, eucalyptus, pine sawdust and leather tobacco pouches. The palate was also toothsomely sweet (plum syrup, sultanas, walnut cake, toffee apples, honey-glazed pork) with a faintly earthy, woody finish (tobacco, tea-leaves, floorboards). The reduced nose had something redolent of autumnal forests, hazelnuts, maple syrup over walnuts, oat and raisin biscuits and butterscotch. The palate now delivered an attractive melange of citrus, woody spice, crushed ginger nuts, buttery tablet, toffee and honey sweetness and pork pies in a pine forest.
https://www.smws.com/slightly-wicked-swe.drinking_tip: To accompany an indulgent picnic on the edge of a forest
https://www.smws.com/slightly-wicked-swe.name: Slightly wicked sweet treats

https://www.smws.com/smoke-and-mirrors-e.description: Smoky, fruity and meaty aromas were interestingly entwined; balsamic roasted strawberries with dark chocolate, tea smoked duck with lime hoisin and smoked orange marmalade. The taste was like honey soy ginger roast pork belly with molasses roasted onions. As soon as you added water the smoke almost disappeared replaced by a waxy, oily and salty scent like eating fish and chips wrapped in greaseproof paper on a pebble beach and in the finish, creamy vanilla porridge with brown sugar apples. After 23 years in an ex-bourbon refill barrel, we transferred this whisky directly into a white wine cask for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/smoke-and-mirrors-e.name: Smoke and Mirrors

https://www.smws.com/smoke-without-fire.description: There was a lot of smoke but without the fire; smoked bacon, smoked sea salt, hot and cold smoked salmon, smoked mackerel pate, smoked scallops and smoked brown sugar. The taste neat had some chilli heat, some sweet fruity sangria and, what should not be coming as a surprise, plenty of big, deep and penetrating smoke with some crackling homemade pork scratchings in the finish. Water released smoked plum lemonade (grilling the lemons before adding them), smoked apple chutney as well as Arbroath smokies with cream and mustard, while on the palate a never ending sweet smoke and savoury chilli heat sensation.
https://www.smws.com/smoke-without-fire.name: Smoke without fire

https://www.smws.com/smoked-aged-rieslin.description: This nosed like an aged Riesling wine, off-dry with a balance of fruity, crunchy green apple, pears and citrus, and earthy mineral aromas with that typical hint of petrol in the background. Plenty of pure ocean salt and briny Greek olives on the palate neat but at the same time; sweet and fruity like a lemon pie, salted caramels and ‘smoked’ jelly beans. Water released a fruity peat smoke, more pears but also peaches poached in Riesling wine with tarragon and salted sour cream. The taste was now peat smoked grilled sardines in sweet and sour lemon-pepper vinaigrette with Dijon mustard toasted bread.
https://www.smws.com/smoked-aged-rieslin.drinking_tip: Perfect match with smoked fish and/or salted cheese
https://www.smws.com/smoked-aged-rieslin.name: Smoked ‘aged’ Riesling - Exclusive to August Peaty Trio

https://www.smws.com/smoked-beer.description: Lovely sweet, yeasty and malty aromas neat. It might be a mug of hot Ovaltine or indeed a stein of cool Rauchbier from Germany – take your pick. With it you will eat either a hot dog in a sweet poppy seed bun topped with yellow spicy mustard, chopped fried onions, and sweet pickle relish or a Pancetta-wrapped pork roll. With water, a salty and fishy dimension was added on the nose, seaweed, a timber groyne, salty bacon and sweet pickled herring. In the taste, burnt salted butter, sweet ‘n’ salted popcorn and we washed it all down with a Benedictine herbal liqueur.
https://www.smws.com/smoked-beer.drinking_tip: Has there ever been a better way of ending the day?
https://www.smws.com/smoked-beer.name: Smoked beer

https://www.smws.com/sniffing-a-bee-s-kn.description: The nose was sweetly seductive – toffee, caramel, Flumps, Tunnock’s Snowballs and carrot cake, but far from one-dimensional – it also had hessian, coconut, macadamias and insinuations of citrus. The palate offered fantastic, mouth-watering sweet acidity, like Moffat toffees; plus exotic fruits, flowers and strawberry jam tarts – and the finish – teasingly dry with woody tannins, coconut and clove. Floral notes increased on the reduced nose – parma violets, lavender (someone imagined sniffing a bee’s knees) – not to forget pineapple, sherbet and granola. The palate now danced on our tongues – lively as lollipops and cream soda, with lots of interesting back-flavours (cardamom, anise, angostura) – engaging.
https://www.smws.com/sniffing-a-bee-s-kn.drinking_tip: Sweetly seductive, tongue-dancing and engaging – must be a dram for a hot date!
https://www.smws.com/sniffing-a-bee-s-kn.name: Sniffing a bee’s knees

https://www.smws.com/so-many-colours-in-.description: As soon as we had this sample in the glass we were all in a sweet shop for adults only. Let’s start with the sweeties; jelly babies, dolly mixtures, black liquorice bootlaces, strawberry whips and aniseed balls but then we also got chocolate rum truffles, peach schnapps gummy bears and apricots in brandy. It was all fiery red hot on the palate neat; sun, shoelaces, cherries, chilli and atomic fireballs. Water released blue jelly snakes and green gummy sharks as well as white Sangria on the nose and a Blue Mountain Jamaican coffee with a liberal dash of white high-ester over- proof spiced rum.
https://www.smws.com/so-many-colours-in-.drinking_tip: Perks you up when feeling blue
https://www.smws.com/so-many-colours-in-.name: So many colours in the rainbow - Available Online Only

https://www.smws.com/soft-easy-sweet-and.description: Soft and easy, sweet and attractive – the nose offered chocolate caramels, Tunnock’s snowballs, toffee apples, butterscotch and vanilla ice-cream, with perry, cherry and gooseberry fruitiness and oak shavings tucked in behind. The palate also had lovely sweetness (toffee, chocolate, strawberry Chewits, rum and raisin ice-cream) – finely balanced by light, warm woody spice, fresh oak and lino cuts. The reduced nose discovered tropical fruits (lemon, lime, mango, passion fruit, tangerine) and pleasing woody notes (eucalyptus, pine forest, balsa). The reduced palate found ripe pear, barley sugars, golden syrup and bran flakes – sweetly attractive with a wooden sub-structure and interesting intrusions of fruit.
https://www.smws.com/soft-easy-sweet-and.drinking_tip: An easy-drinking dram – could be served as an aperitif but really would please any time at all.
https://www.smws.com/soft-easy-sweet-and.name: Soft, easy, sweet and attractive

https://www.smws.com/soft-elegant-and-in.description: This sample changed every time we went back to it and from the variety of descriptors the following aromas were the most prominent; black currant preserve, mango chutney, Turkish Delight, rose flavoured white chocolate and a ‘scratch and sniff’ perfume out of a Vogue magazine. The taste was juicy, fruity and sweet like wine gums (banana, pineapple, coconut – do theses exist!), chocolate Swiss roll and whipped lemon/ vanilla mousse. Water brought out Dolly Mixtures as well as sticky date pudding in caramel sauce. The taste was now like a spoonful of ‘Dreamy Coconut’ Activia yoghurt; soft, elegant and intensely creamy.
https://www.smws.com/soft-elegant-and-in.name: Soft, elegant and intensely creamy

https://www.smws.com/soft-fruit-nougat.description: We were served a soup of herbs and greens, sorrel, arugula and nettles with a handful of parsley and watercress topped with a generous dollop of crème fraiche. To drink we had fresh coconut water as well as sparkling mint lemonade. The initial taste was surprisingly hot; maybe some fresh hot green chillies somewhere in the soup and the beverage now a mulled white wine. Water released ripe apples, possibly in the Glühwein with cinnamon, cardamom pods and cloves. Much more approachable on the palate now, sweet and fruity like fine Belgian soft fruit nougat with sliced pieces of glace pineapple.
https://www.smws.com/soft-fruit-nougat.name: Soft fruit nougat

https://www.smws.com/sophisticated-and-g.description: A very interesting, inviting nose – brown sugar on pear and apple crumble, lemongrass, incense oil and vanilla candles, along with fresh sea-breezes carrying heather flower perfume. The palate had a definite backbone of comforting, warm pepper and sweet peat but the overall impression was of a refined, sophisticated, genteel dram – Demerara crunch on rhubarb crumble with lashings of custard. The reduced nose – clean and relaxing (‘walking through orchards’), with chocolate and flowers suggesting the hopeful pleasures of a first date. The reduced palate – tiny threads of perfumed smoke, pink peppercorns, incense ash and fruits of the forest – dreamy and delightful.
https://www.smws.com/sophisticated-and-g.name: Sophisticated and genteel

https://www.smws.com/spinning-honey.description: The nose neat had a wonderful raw, strong, vibrant and intense scent which did lead different Panel members in different directions. From the freshly varnished wooden deck of a yacht, painting in oil to drying herbs in a rustic country kitchen and finally extracting honey the old fashioned way whilst spinning that centrifugal wheel. Wonderful intensity as well on the palate; coconut palm sugar, black treacle, rum spiced with vanilla, cinnamon and nutmeg and chewing on a sugar cane stick. Water released more vanilla aromas as well as caramel sauce and butter icing and in the finish, a creamy egg custard pie
https://www.smws.com/spinning-honey.name: Spinning honey

https://www.smws.com/splashing-about-in-.description:
SOLD OUT 
A trip down memory lane with sandwiches in plastic boxes, hard green sweets and mints in waxed wrappers. Damp bottoms sitting on sea soaked wood with Germolene on scratched knees. Prawns on a clean barbeque fueled with fresh oak chips and sooty scorched heather. Salt sprayed blackcurrant and lemons in a polytunnel. Intense burnt lavender wafting over wasabi oysters and grapefruit bitters. A quick rain shower freshened everything becoming more mentholic and minty. Waves going over the top of your wellies. Eating rollmop herring and pickled mackerel with sandy fingers. Clean wood smoke and fragrant heath blowing over the sands.
https://www.smws.com/splashing-about-in-.drinking_tip: It will take you to a good place
https://www.smws.com/splashing-about-in-.name: Splashing about in rockpools

https://www.smws.com/stave-new-world.description: The wood hit our noses as oak shavings, fresh-cut pine and furniture stores; then we detected eucalyptus, ginger and new leather shoes; but it was also sweet (Oreos, syrup, plum sauce on sponge) and floral. The palate’s deeper regions gave us liquorice root, black tea, cinnamon and dry oak, while its lighter face had figs, guava, raspberry jam and fruit cake. Water brought sauna wood and clove-studded ham to the nose; cough syrup, rich toffee and Chupa Chups to the palate. After 13 years in an ex-bourbon hogshead, we transferred this into a sherry butt for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/stave-new-world.drinking_tip: After dinner, with a cigar, at the snooker table.
https://www.smws.com/stave-new-world.name: Stave New World

https://www.smws.com/straight-up-and-dow.description: A village green cricket ground; fresh air, grass cuttings and a slight dustiness as the groundsmen prepared the pitch using a heavy roller. Aromas of last minute bat preparations with linseed oil and sweet creamy porridge reached us from the pavilion. ‘Play’ - first ball; slog-swept over square leg for 6! That tasted fairly spiky, spicy with a sour fruitiness. Fast forward. Rain stopped play and we enjoyed early tea; lemon meringue pie, macadamia nut cookies and Battenberg cake. Once play resumed, a corker of a delivery was met by a smooth, sweetly timed, delightful back foot cover drive finding the boundary.
https://www.smws.com/straight-up-and-dow.name: Straight up-and-down

https://www.smws.com/strictly-whisky.description: The nose neat transported us to a deeply polished, real wood oak parquet dance floor watching a Rumba dance competition. All those sensual moves, tropical, fruity, perfumed aromas engaged our senses and we each drifted off into our own little world. We carried on daydreaming as the taste had a wonderful juicy and fruity mouthfeel with flavours of a classic summer berry Pavlova (named after a Russian prima ballerina) using fresh strawberries and raspberries. Water added bouquets of flowers handed out at the end of the competition and we all felt that this precocious example of a whisky was well worth exploring.
https://www.smws.com/strictly-whisky.drinking_tip: Taking a break in between dances
https://www.smws.com/strictly-whisky.name: Strictly whisky

https://www.smws.com/sugar-and-spice.description: Sweet notes to begin; toffee cake with sugar syrup and melting milk chocolate. Porridge with cranberries came next alongside apricots, marzipan and Cherry Ripe bars. Our noses then unearthed some old leather, plastic pipes and copper coins. The palate had a sweet chilli spice and hints of charcoal, then a refreshing mint julep arrived leaving a long, vibrant finish. The reduced nose appeared lighter at first but soon livened up with toasted herbs, cherries, Greek salad, caramelised ginger and old Indian rugs. There were now cardamon pods and toasted sesame seeds to taste, then yogurt, hints of peach and spicy toffee to finish.
https://www.smws.com/sugar-and-spice.name: Sugar and spice

https://www.smws.com/summer-celebration-.description: The nose was sweet (Victoria sponge, Turkish Delight, Demerara, strawberries and cream) and perfumed (pot-pourri, freesias, roses, prosecco) reminding us of old-fashioned ice-cream parlours, or summer-time garden celebrations; tiny hints of grapefruit and wasabi to finish. The palate seemed gentle, silky and intriguing – a bitter-sweet evocation of long years in good wood – fruity (pineapple, raspberry Chewits, pick n mix) with powder puff, champagne mousse and ‘blowing up balloons’. The reduced nose took us to summer parks with flowers, sun lotion and ice-cream vans. The palate had tropical fruits, ice-lollies and pink wafers – given time it became a rewarding, even emotional experience.
https://www.smws.com/summer-celebration-.drinking_tip: Summer time – special occasions – and it really doesn’t need water.
https://www.smws.com/summer-celebration-.name: Summer celebration dram

https://www.smws.com/summer-fete-and-flo.description: Memories of summer fetes flooded back with heady aromas of peach jam, freshly baked toffee cookies, banana bread and ripe golden plums. A hint of airfix paint from the handicrafts, and crisp florals from the flower arranging table. The taste was as sweet and short as a Scottish summer with pings of flavour bursting on the tongue. Afternoon tea delivered pink wafers, warm scones, homemade chocolate truffles and caramel coffee cake. Cut flowers, and the dry earth of the greenhouse mingled with the warm wood of an old deck chair. A slice of gingerbread with a sip of mead completed the picture.
https://www.smws.com/summer-fete-and-flo.drinking_tip: So delicate - it whispers in your ear
https://www.smws.com/summer-fete-and-flo.name: Summer Fete and Flower Shows

https://www.smws.com/summertime-and-the-.description: On a cold winters night the panel dreamed of warmer days bathed in sunshine. They fancied drinking cold, fizzy lime stretched out on clover and sorrel. They found waxed crayon, macadamia and stewed apple sauce with honey roast ham on the nose. They preferred it at full strength with tangy gooseberry, spritzy elderflower and strawberry vanilla shake. It was as fresh as a summer meadow and described as ‘too easy to drink’. A sprinkle of water coaxed out madeira sponge with butter icing and mint choc chip ice cream. It retained coconut oil, lemongrass and spearmint. Delightful and charming.
https://www.smws.com/summertime-and-the-.name: Summertime and the whisky is easy

https://www.smws.com/sunshine-motherhood.description: The nose held very pleasant fruity sweetness (sherbet lemons, red lips, Turkish Delight, Edinburgh Rock), while pears, apples, straw and wood, somehow suggested Autumn orchards. The palate was immediately warmly attractive – all summer sunshine, motherhood and apple pie – like relaxing in a farmhouse kitchen with Victoria sponge and caramel apple granny cake. The reduced nose took us to gardens (wooden trellis, bougainvillea, wisteria, grass, vines) where we were supping cloudy lemonade and cider. The palate was now easy and indulgent – the apple dessert wonderfully balancing sweet and tart flavours; the wood was now as tasty as an ice-lolly stick.
https://www.smws.com/sunshine-motherhood.drinking_tip: One to enjoy in the garden, while the apple pie is cooling on a windowsill
https://www.smws.com/sunshine-motherhood.name: Sunshine motherhood and apple pie

https://www.smws.com/sweet-and-astringen.description: The nose was clean and creamy (dragon fruit, milk chews), with plentiful fruit (candied orange, stewed apple, bitter lemon) freshly cut wood, beeswax, vanilla and hinted mint. The palate (with good viscosity and decent weight) was attractively sweet (brown sugar, honey, tinned mandarins, vanilla yoghurt) with a counter-balancing lively astringency of wood, crystallised ginger, red chilli and menthol. On the reduced nose, fruit salad chews and strawberry laces sat beside leather, pine, thyme and tiger balm. The palate retained some menthol and tannins, but vanilla slices, pineapple cake and flying saucers brought the whole thing to a satisfying balance and conclusion.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-and-astringen.drinking_tip: To liven up otherwise dreary chores
https://www.smws.com/sweet-and-astringen.name: Sweet and astringent balance

https://www.smws.com/sweet-but-dangerous.description: The nose took us to a beach bonfire – peat smoke, heather, gorse, salty sea air and moules marinières – but one panellist had his own barbeque in a hospital car-park. With water, we imagined coal-tar, liquorice and teriyaki-glazed ribs, an Islay High Street in winter and Dick Van Dyke’s chimney-sweep cap. The neat palate was enormous – deep smoke, chewy dark toffee, mechanics overalls, a disinfected operating theatre, hints of farmyard and pork and apple sausages roasting on a smoky barbeque. The reduced palate – liquorice and clove confectionery – sweet but dangerous (like Mary Poppins!) – and all enjoyed down-wind of an Islay pagoda.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-but-dangerous.drinking_tip: At a beach bonfire – or while watching a certain movie.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-but-dangerous.name: Sweet but dangerous

https://www.smws.com/sweet-couscous-with.description: This was initially a very ‘clean’ nose with aromas of coconut soap, liquid beeswax with pure turpentine and a silver polish dip. Deeper notes arrived quickly and descriptors of creamy rice pudding, rum and raisin ice cream as well as sweet porridge with almonds. The taste neat reminded some of clove panna cotta with fresh figs whilst others of sweet Moroccan couscous with raisins, almonds and Argan oil. Careful when adding water; aromas of a nutmeg spiced flavoured coffee, banana milk shake and elderflower juice are rounded off by almond milk and crème brulee with citrus, cardamom and star anise.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-couscous-with.drinking_tip: We all agreed best enjoyed neat
https://www.smws.com/sweet-couscous-with.name: Sweet couscous with Argan oil

https://www.smws.com/sweet-day-dreams.description: On the nose neat we found ourselves in a greenhouse with overwintered geraniums and tomato vines. We were sitting in a Rattan armchair eating honey apple cake and drinking hot Ribena when a lady stepped in wearing Fuzzy Peach perfume oil. Immediately the scene changed; intense, thrilling, prickly, sweet and juicy heat on the tongue whilst shaking Apricot Anise Collins using carbonated water and stirring lightly. Now the aromas became much more herbal and we were miraculously transported to an alpine chalet enjoying après-ski, drinking Jagertee and eating a Rachel sandwich using pastrami, Swiss cheese and coleslaw on rye bread.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-day-dreams.name: Sweet day dreams

https://www.smws.com/sweet-floral-perfum.description: The nose had light peat smoke, stony beaches, balsa wood, first aid boxes, lavender soap and flowers on a bonfire; plus some sweeter aspects of cup-cakes, pineapple turnover and jelly beans. The palate, at natural strength, had lots of sweet floral perfumes (yes – the usual lavender and violet), surgical gloves and magic balloons – interesting and fun – a bit of a party dram. The nose with water was sweetly buttery, with light smoke drifting over flower meadows, but clean, like a disinfected waiting room. The palate became smooth and creamy with perfectly balanced sweet, floral smoke – very nice stuff from Islay’s capital.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-floral-perfum.drinking_tip: Flowers, cup cakes, jelly beans and balloons! Definitely a party dram.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-floral-perfum.name: Sweet, floral, perfumed smoke

https://www.smws.com/sweet-memories.description: The initial nose was quite sharp, prickly and comments like acetone nail polish remover and unripe gooseberries were mentioned. This however changed quickly into a wildflower meadow, parkland golf course and the fragrant aroma of sweet peas, finally raspberry ripple ice cream with a Garibaldi biscuit. The taste was sweet, fizzy and refreshingly tangy like sparkling strawberry lemonade and a gooseberry yoghurt fool. Adding some water the entire nose turned into the colour pink; wafers, mice, candy floss, and ‘Funny Feet’ ice cream. Fresh, light and sweet on the palate like Aero mint chocolate biscuits and sherbet flying saucers.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-memories.drinking_tip: A warm day on a Victorian pier
https://www.smws.com/sweet-memories.name: Sweet memories

https://www.smws.com/sweet-peat-carolina.description: Aromas of peat smoked wine gums came immediately to mind as we walked barefoot on a hot board walk along the beach to a jetty waiting for a paddle steamer to arrive. The scent of salty warm air was mingling with aromas of tarry ropes and lobster pots. The taste initially was hot! Bloody Mary pepper prawns. In time, now on the steamer heading downstream in the Deep South, we enjoyed true creole cooking. Water added the salty humidity of the Mississippi river delta marshland in Louisiana and we still had some of those sweet peat smoked wine gums left to enjoy.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-peat-carolina.drinking_tip: When in the need of heat
https://www.smws.com/sweet-peat-carolina.name: Sweet Peat Carolina

https://www.smws.com/sweet-salty-seaweed.description: We were greeted by a fresh coastal sea breeze reminding some of us of walking the dog on a bright early morning along a pebble beach with scattered crab baskets and the enticing aroma of salty and sweet seaweed in the air. Salty and sweet it was on the palate too, like scallops and sweet chilli garnished with rocket leaves drizzled generously with balsamic vinegar. With a drop of water we carried on walking, passing a fisherman giving a new lick of paint to his upside down boat. The taste now like smoked haddock chowder with leeks and sweetcorn.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-salty-seaweed.name: Sweet & salty seaweed

https://www.smws.com/sweet-salty-smoky.description: On the nose neat a lot of foodie aromas made us all very hungry indeed; spicy sausage casserole, honeyed pork loin with plum and lavender relish but also simple old fashioned mincemeat pie and chips wrapped in newspaper served with salt and vinegar. It tasted as it smelled – fabulous! Sweet, salty, smoky like a broiled tuna steak (centre has remained pink) with a zingy herb sauce. Water turned it into a grilled pork cutlet with a maple chipotle glaze as well as dried seaweed and Japanese sweet omelette. The never-ending finish was peat smoke entwined with fresh salty sea air.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-salty-smoky.name: Sweet, salty & smoky

https://www.smws.com/sweet-seduction-in-.description: The nose reminded some panellists of car-wash day – polished leather and wood, chamois cloths, wax and T-cut – but sweetness rewarded their labours – marmalade on toast, caramel sauce, dark toffee, raisins, Demerara and Danish pastries – fruit salad, peppercorns and pine lent complexity. The neat palate was casked in spicy wood (pepper, chilli, charred oak) – but finely balanced by mysterious sweet seductions – oloroso sherry, dark chocolate, spun sugar and cinder toffee. The reduced nose discovered hoisin duck, teriyaki stir-fry and incense smoke. On the palate, chocolate fudge and tablet countered salted but juicy seared steak – complex and delicious stuff from Ayrshire’s grain distillery.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-seduction-in-.drinking_tip: When you want something different – or a delightful puzzle to fox your friends
https://www.smws.com/sweet-seduction-in-.name: Sweet seduction in a car-wash

https://www.smws.com/sweet-sensuous-indu.description: This will be a ‘rocking chair dram’ was the first comment following the initial impression on the nose neat. It slowed us right down; it was gentle, sweet with a hint of spice like sticky rhubarb and ginger crumble or gooey vanilla cherry pie - ultimately speaking of comfort and contentment. The taste had a gentle spicy intensity to start with but then it was like a relaxing soothing long soak in a hot bath. A drop of water and sensuous sweet scents of iced wine and rum baba with Chantilly cream emerged leading to an experience of perfect harmony.
https://www.smws.com/sweet-sensuous-indu.drinking_tip: When God made time he made plenty of it
https://www.smws.com/sweet-sensuous-indu.name: Sweet sensuous indulgence

https://www.smws.com/sweetness-gently-ti.description: The nose had a sweet centre-piece (caramel chocolate biscuits, marzipan, marshmallows) around which lay scattered floral perfumes, sharp fruits, cherry-scented tobacco, polished furniture, sherbet dib-dabs and spicy lamb tagines – pleasant and complex. Water turned it more floral for a while, eventually resolving in fruity pleasures (marmalade, Demerara on grapefruit) – really rather seductive. The neat palate’s definite oaky spice (chorizo, leather, pepper, nutmeg, coconut) was balanced by fruit, flowers and sweetness – Green & Black’s Maya Gold came to mind. With water – vanilla, star-fruit, shortbread – the wood gently tickling the sweetness to make it happy. This distillery was completely re-built in 2004.
https://www.smws.com/sweetness-gently-ti.drinking_tip: Settling down in an armchair in front of a fire with a good book
https://www.smws.com/sweetness-gently-ti.name: Sweetness gently tickled by oak

https://www.smws.com/takes-you-to-anothe.description: This one took different people to different places. Some had honey glazed gammon with French Dijon mustard, others had lime marmalade on toast, plum candied fruit gelee from Umbria Italy and Russian pickled watermelons whilst others found themselves in a hawker centre in Singapore. The taste neat was big, bouncy and beautiful; heather honey fudge, lightly toasted marshmallows, lemon cheese cake, creamy chicken soup and yes, we were back queuing at many different stalls in the Asian food market. A drop of water and the wok released hot oily aromas as Teriyaki chicken with clear honey, sesame oil and soy sauce was being prepared.
https://www.smws.com/takes-you-to-anothe.name: Takes you to another place

https://www.smws.com/tea-time-treat.description: The nose neat was a real potpourri of aromas ranching from cedar wood shavings over lemon oil to dried roses. There was also some kind of tangy and sweet fruitiness, like that of a green apple smoothie or a gooseberry Bellini. On the taste neat it was that tanginess and sweetness of rhubarb and custard bonbons at first, before custard creams arrived. Water helped releasing more complex aromas of baked custard rice pudding, cinnamon vanilla toasted oats and brown sugar apple cobbler. The mouthfeel was now smooth with a good texture of, iced fairy cakes, jammie dodgers and bourbon cream biscuits.
https://www.smws.com/tea-time-treat.name: Tea time treat

https://www.smws.com/teddy-boys-at-the-b.description: Rock (pool) and roll! Bad boys set an old boat alight with a splash of diesel, clean smoke puffing into the sky. They drink pisco sours and eat pork rolls with gherkin pickle, followed by baked corn pudding. Splashing sea water fizzes on the fire and sparks of pickled ginger and salted lemon fly. Hints of oregano and roll-ups waft together with an oily slick on the shore. They kick an old rubber tyre around and flick each other with a tarry rope. Olive oil cake with lemon icing, pickled onions with cream cheese and mackerel complete the beastie.
https://www.smws.com/teddy-boys-at-the-b.name: Teddy Boys at the beach

https://www.smws.com/thank-you-and-goodn.description: Big licks of maple bacon, sticky pulled pork over hickory smoke morphing into gooey treacle toffee, liquorice and violet. Crispy skinned fish with barbeque sauce and tropical fruit kebabs roasted over white hot coals. ‘Properly good smoke!’ one declared, he was right. Chargrilled pepper and sweet potato muddled gracefully with sundried tomatoes and garden canes. Water brought out a delicious feast of charred pork crackling and Frazzles served with a Bloody Mary. The morning after cure theme continued with more bacon, blood orange, BBQ sauce and red pesto all served in a smoky greenhouse. Wicked but very good.
https://www.smws.com/thank-you-and-goodn.name: Thank you and goodnight!

https://www.smws.com/the-bee-s-knees.description: A fascinating combination of aromas ranging from sweet to salt and smoke kept us all very much engaged and interested; sea salt caramels, a salted chocolate tart using smoked sea salt and churros with salty peanut sugar and bitter chocolate. It tastes exactly how it noses. It was big in every sense; sweet, salty, smoky – simply stunning and best described by the following remarks; ‘dog’s bollocks’ and ‘bee’s knees’! Reluctantly we added a drop of water, however we still enjoyed that very unusual combination we experienced neat but now, admittedly, a little tamer but still tantalizing every nook and cranny of our tongue.
https://www.smws.com/the-bee-s-knees.drinking_tip: Life begins at the end of your comfort zone
https://www.smws.com/the-bee-s-knees.name: The bee’s knees…

https://www.smws.com/the-cinderella-cott.description: Our travellers arrived at the chilly coastal cottage, it had been lying empty with damp plaster walls and sea salt encrusted windows. Old cinders lay in the grate so the weary crew lit the fire with heather and peat. They speared sausages with rosemary sticks and grilled them, skin splitting, on the open flames with green tomatoes. From their provisions they cobbled together a makeshift feast of prawn crackers, dimsum and tempura shrimps with sesame seeds. They baked apples in the embers,crispy skinned, and finished their pudding with dough balls. Warm and fed - what a transformation!
https://www.smws.com/the-cinderella-cott.drinking_tip: Friday night session dram in a cold climate(or cold climate dram)
https://www.smws.com/the-cinderella-cott.name: The Cinderella cottage

https://www.smws.com/the-curious-apothec.description: The panel found a veritable hotchpotch of aromas, soap on a rope aromatic with lemon and lime then grilled bacon with mango chutney. Our ageing hippie wandered through a market, the air laced with patchouli and lavender. An ashy grill yielded blackened green chilli, lemongrass marinade, holy basil and smoky lychee. He wore an old patched cashmere jumper and well worn leather flip flops, with a notebook tucked under his arm. He supped on Rooibos tea while thoughtfully chewing baccy and sooking pear and blackberry pastilles. Satisfied with his work, he dipped his toes into a warm rock pool.
https://www.smws.com/the-curious-apothec.name: The Curious Apothecary

https://www.smws.com/the-days-catch.description: A mixture of salty, stony, earthy and slightly smoky aromas mingled in the air nosing this one neat. A picture of fishing boats unloading the day’s catch, mainly shellfish; clams, cockles, crabs and mussels. Wisps of freshly prepared Moules Marinieres, smoked fish and grilled ricotta sandwiches reached the trawlers and before heading home the fishermen had a bite to eat, a drink and shared a laugh. With a drop of water much fresher on the nose; salty sea spray, eucalyptus and a hint of antiseptic whilst the taste was that of menthol chewing tobacco and crab cakes with seaweed salad.
https://www.smws.com/the-days-catch.drinking_tip: Watching boats unloading the day’s catch
https://www.smws.com/the-days-catch.name: The day's catch

https://www.smws.com/the-freshness-of-ci.description: The kitchen windows steamed up with the heady aromas seeping from the hot ovens. Rosy cheeked bakers toiled over trays of warm brioche buns studded with ginger and nutmeg and glossily iced buns decorated with marron glace and crystalised orange. The bakers downed their tools and fortified themselves with mugs of mead laced with orange zest and traces of chilli. They nibbled at soft, sweet nougat with crushed hazelnuts while reading glossy expensive magazines. Back to work! They drew hot loaves from the ovens: dark rye bread and toasted spelt rolls, ready to be enjoyed with thick cut grapefruit marmalade
https://www.smws.com/the-freshness-of-ci.name: The freshness of citrus!

https://www.smws.com/the-gifts-of-the-se.description: Some prickle, then coal dust, coal cellar, foostie; roasted peanuts and sun-dried cardboard, then back to maritime notes: dry pebble beach, wooden pier, faded creosote – you get the idea? At natural strength the panel noted: brown paper towels, ‘cleansing antiseptic (Savlon)’, a hint of cloves; with ‘end of barbeque’ and ‘bandages’ in the finish. With water the aroma becomes drier: more lint bandages, dry shellfish shells, ‘a bowl of mussels’, tarry rope, rock pools. Now the texture is smooth and soft; dusty and cooling, with a sweetish start, a salty middle and a spicy/smoky finish.
https://www.smws.com/the-gifts-of-the-se.drinking_tip: Catching sprats on the end of the pier
https://www.smws.com/the-gifts-of-the-se.name: The gifts of the sea

https://www.smws.com/the-great-easter-ba.description: The panel felt they were preparing for an Easter baking session gathering ginger, molasses, soaked sultanas in tea, hot crossed buns. Rich chocolate with mint and orange, lemon zest and a hint of warm earth into the mixing bowl. An astounding toasting of cinnamon and ginger soothed by a soft mohair mouthfeel. With water cedar hand soap emerged, dried tobacco and a refined herbal finish of elderflower, mint and rosemary. The taste evoked a rocking chair moment of apples ripening in an old tea chest made of sandalwood. This is a great example from distillery known for experimenting with exciting casks.
https://www.smws.com/the-great-easter-ba.name: The Great Easter Bake Off

https://www.smws.com/the-joy-of-jelly.description: At the outset an intense spicy, gingery aroma greeted the Panel. With time, fruity notes of stewed apples and rhubarb appeared followed by sweet lime jelly. The taste neat had initially the citric acidity of a crisp green apple and then we were back to the lime jelly with plenty of cane sugar added and some mint for freshness. Sweet was the theme diluted; icing sugar, coconut milk and flavours of a sponge cake with raspberry jam and buttercream. This whisky, after 14 years in an ex-bourbon hogshead was transferred directly into a Sherry butt for the remainder of its maturation.
https://www.smws.com/the-joy-of-jelly.name: The joy of jelly

https://www.smws.com/the-spicy-cake-cabi.description: The polished antique cabinet opened to reveal a plethora of soft fruit desserts including baked apricot tart, chocolate cheesecake, cinnamon and apple pie and stewed plums with brown sugar and cloves. However we began by tasting brandy snaps with pudding wine and a little pickled ginger to provide gentle warmth. It was only then that we noticed the honey roast parsnips and sweet potato served with cashew nuts, fruit chutney and a mysterious packet of tobacco. We closed the cabinet again and walked away to get a rich cup of tea, our polished leather shoes squeaking on the old sports hall floor.
https://www.smws.com/the-spicy-cake-cabi.name: The spicy cake cabinet

https://www.smws.com/the-sultan-s-treasu.description: The panel were transported by magic carpet to an exotic land. It was like opening a old cedar treasure chest filled with aromas of manuka honeycomb, sweet spices, orange and creamy custard. The chest revealed a lovely waxiness of vanilla candle and macadamia nut. Chocolate orange, and bramble crumble flavours created a luxuriously rich velvety mouthfeel. Heavily perfumed camphor and jasmine mingled with exotic spices like star anise and cardamom. Creme caramel and baked apples soothed the tongue. One panel member was so swept away he forgot to scribe his thoughts. It was declared ‘a joy!’ and all concurred.
https://www.smws.com/the-sultan-s-treasu.drinking_tip: Sit back, and make a wish!
https://www.smws.com/the-sultan-s-treasu.name: The Sultan’s Treasure Chest

https://www.smws.com/the-whole-is-greate.description: A gentle, soft and sweet note greeted the Panel which led to the first, more unusual, comment ‘feels like using a quality badger hair shaving brush for the very first time’. Then fresh aromas of a lavender based aftershave followed quickly alongside chocolate orange brownies and coconut ice-cream. The taste was so soft, creamy and waxy with the addition of lavender essential oil – a natural stress relief. A drop of water and fruity sweet aromas of entering a French patisserie arrived and the taste was even softer, like a mixed melon salad of cantaloupe, honeydew and watermelon with a honey-lime dressing.
https://www.smws.com/the-whole-is-greate.drinking_tip: Be very careful when adding water
https://www.smws.com/the-whole-is-greate.name: The whole is greater than...

https://www.smws.com/through-a-pine-fore.description: The panel founds themselves ponderous and lowered their voices to a whisper so as not to disturb this sleepy beauty. They found sultry Moroccan tagine spice and exotic puddings with marzipan and kewra water (rose) One imagined sitting on old rugs surrounded by varnished treasure boxes filled with potpourri. Another fancied delicate jasmine and rock rose root with blood orange. They dreamed of eating Turkish Delight while toasting marshmallows and nibbling mandarins studded with cloves. Water teased out expensive lavender scented candles then eucalyptus and Tiger balm. It remained ethereal and enigmatic while secretly whispering sweet nothings in your ear.
https://www.smws.com/through-a-pine-fore.drinking_tip: Tuck you up in bed whisky
https://www.smws.com/through-a-pine-fore.name: Through a pine forest in fluffy slippers

https://www.smws.com/to-sit-by-the-samov.description: This sample was showing extreme complexity and sophistication albeit from a fairly quiet start. Aromas appeared of an earthy forest floor following a spring shower, new cardboard boxes to Manuca honey, maple syrup, Turkish delight and an old fashioned tea chest finishing with blaeberry sorbet. The taste opens up a whole array of sweet Moroccan spices as well as fresh apricots and plums, juicy sultanas and in the finish dark chocolate. A drop of water revealed a sweet unlit cigar and damp tea leaves prepared in the traditional Russian samovar way and flavours of kumquat, sea buckthorn berries and pistachio nuts.
https://www.smws.com/to-sit-by-the-samov.drinking_tip: Playing chess (waiting on your opponent’s next move)
https://www.smws.com/to-sit-by-the-samov.name: To sit by the samovar

https://www.smws.com/toffee-and-sunny-ru.description: The nose found feverfew, camomile and grass, but the main event was fruity sweetness, like jam tarts, rhubarb and custard sweets, Danish pastries, vanilla slices and stewed fruits. The sweetness was less fruity on the palate – we got barley sugars, buttery tablet, pastries and McCowan’s Highland toffee – then a late spice kick of ginger, chilli and pink peppercorns. The reduced nose was young and fresh (flower meadows, laundry, lemon, pencils) but still sweet – this time sunny runny honey, Hobnobs, ice-cream wafers and dark chocolate. The reduced palate had less heat and seemed tastier – dried papaya, Granola bars and chocolate milk-shake.
https://www.smws.com/toffee-and-sunny-ru.name: Toffee and sunny, runny honey

https://www.smws.com/tongue-tingling-tre.description: Different people were transported to different places. Some were in an enchanted forest, the home of fairies and boggarts with magical woodland aromas of Scots pine, gorse, hawthorn, honeysuckle and angelica. Others were on the deck of an old wooden clipper bringing tea and exotic spices back from China. In the taste, like an old secret treasure chest but at the same time an unexpected agility. With a drop of water we were riding Route 66 on a Harley Davidson and at the end of the day enjoyed a bottle of vintage Champagne with this fine balance between excitement and finesse.
https://www.smws.com/tongue-tingling-tre.drinking_tip: With plenty of time and without interruption
https://www.smws.com/tongue-tingling-tre.name: Tongue tingling treasure

https://www.smws.com/totally-tropical-ma.description: Close your eyes, and picture the scene: lying on a beach in the Caribbean, frozen coconut daiquiri in hand, waves lapping against your feet, the aromatic scent of tropical blossom and ripe pineapples in the air. You sip, and lychee and lime sorbet melts on your tongue; sweet vanilla and new oak, ginger nuts and rum and raisin ice-cream to follow. White horses splash your glass and release waxy lemon skins and orange blossom; someone’s fanning you with a palm leaf and added more lime to your daiquiri – it’s a hard life! Like any good dream it has to end, but this one does with a tropical sweetness.
https://www.smws.com/totally-tropical-ma.drinking_tip: To be enjoyed on a Caribbean beach
https://www.smws.com/totally-tropical-ma.name: Totally tropical, man!

https://www.smws.com/tutti-frutti.description: This was a real sweet and fruity treat of soft peaches, strawberries, in fact all types of summer fruits, a cream soda float, pink grapefruit squash and a Tutti Frutti frozen yoghurt. The taste neat reminded us of green apples, green grapes, watermelons and the refreshing sip of tonic water with a twist of lime. Water changed the aromas to kiwis, lime and strawberry flavoured cider and a mango, pineapple, banana smoothie. The taste is now very refreshing; mint leaf ice cream and a Piscine cocktail prepared with orange liqueur, lemon juice, Prosecco, strawberries, raspberries and a slice of orange.
https://www.smws.com/tutti-frutti.drinking_tip: At a garden party by the pool
https://www.smws.com/tutti-frutti.name: Tutti Frutti

https://www.smws.com/up-all-night-editor.description: The editor of a glossy cookery magazine is putting the issue to bed. Her desk is in chaos, scattered with stacks of dusty magazines, scribbled notes and paper glue. A post photo shoot table is strewn with lemon drizzle cake, bitter marmalade, spiced banana bread and peach juice. She absently mindedly chews on lemon bon bons and aniseed balls while fiddling with her henna hair. The woody perfume on her wrists is beginning to fade along with energy so she nibbles Smarties, chocolate buttons and tablet. Dawn creeps over the horizon so she celebrates with hot, buttered toast and freshly iced buns.
https://www.smws.com/up-all-night-editor.drinking_tip: When you don’t need any more challenges, soft and simple
https://www.smws.com/up-all-night-editor.name: Up all night editorial

https://www.smws.com/warm-joyous-and-gra.description: The nose started off fresh as sea breezes, peaceful, soft and summery, with yellow flowers and tree sap – then waves of sweetness engulfed us (Crunchie bars, crème brûlée, honey flapjacks, millionaires’ shortbread, Danish pastries) – the finish found depth in cigar boxes and After Eights. Orange and chocolate (matchmakers) dominated the palate; also chocolate-coated raisins, vanilla latte and some pleasant old wood flavours – the whole experience was chewy and flavour-packed. The reduced nose – warm, end-of-summer hayfields, barley sugars and old bookshops. The palate – honey cake, toffee and sherbet dabs with hints of leather and tobacco at the end – warm, joyous and gratifying.
https://www.smws.com/warm-joyous-and-gra.drinking_tip: Versatile enough to work as an outdoors dram – but also great fun to explore – give it time and no distractions and accept its gift of total relaxation.
https://www.smws.com/warm-joyous-and-gra.name: Warm, joyous and gratifying

https://www.smws.com/warming-and-delight.description: Seventeen years in a refill hoggie, then finished in a Sauternes cask – the nose started with syrupy flapjacks and honey and butter on digestives – developing into butterscotch, toffee and white chocolate; polished oak and black pepper never far away. The palate had toffee, chocolate and soft dried fruits but pepper and wood created a warm contented glow. The reduced nose found honey on oak, a chocolate stash in a wooden drawer, dried cranberries and raspberry jam on buttered toasted crumpets. The palate was described by one panellist as ‘sweet, warming and delightful’ – yoghurt-coated raspberries, Crunchie bars, shortbread and dark chocolate.
https://www.smws.com/warming-and-delight.drinking_tip: Sweetly indulgent – something for the adults at a children’s’ party, perhaps.
https://www.smws.com/warming-and-delight.name: Warming and delightful

https://www.smws.com/what-a-wonderful-wo.description: First comments were; luscious, elegant and sophisticated. We got carried away back in time to the 1930s and found ourselves in the Art Deco designed American Bar in the Savoy. It is the afternoon and ladies, filling the air with conversation and aromas of expensive perfume, face cream and rich leather from quality gloves, enjoy a cucumber sandwich from the pyramid of treats. The taste is like a sip from a very expensive China cup of Lapsang Souchong tea with a spoonful of sugar, slightly smoky, slightly sweet and the hint of pine wood. With water the afternoon turns into evening. The Jazz pianist is playing in the corner and the air is now filled with ash and smoke from ladies using long cigarette holders, and the cucumber slice is now in a Gin & Tonic.
https://www.smws.com/what-a-wonderful-wo.drinking_tip: Lying on a chaslon and listening to Satchmo
https://www.smws.com/what-a-wonderful-wo.name: What a wonderful world

https://www.smws.com/what-afternoons-are.description: We felt we’d been being invited to an afternoon garden party when on arrival we were served a Buck’s Fizz. On to the spread; gingery buttermilk scones, iced buns, toasted teacakes with apricot compote, mini eclairs and little lemon meringue pies. We finally decided to eat; lemon and lavender fondant fancies, vanilla custard slices and blood orange muffins. With a drop of water we walked across to walled rose garden with a glass of refreshing Campari Bitter Lemon in our hands and then finally left enjoying, on our way home, a cone with a scoop of key lime ice-cream
https://www.smws.com/what-afternoons-are.name: What afternoons are made for!

https://www.smws.com/whipped-with-happin.description: This was a full Scottish Breakfast served in a leather armchair in front of a peat fire with aromas of fried eggs and bacon, grilled tomato, tatties, bangers, baked beans, sautéed mushrooms and black pudding. Wait until you try it. A sweet, smoky and savoury sensation! It has it all, everything you ever wanted in the right amount and in the right balance – just throw away the cork. If you want to add water; we were handed a vihta – a bunch of fresh birch branches to get whipped with in a Finnish sauna and the taste was bittersweet chocolate, mouth-watering and to die for.
https://www.smws.com/whipped-with-happin.name: Whipped with Happiness

https://www.smws.com/whisky-smash.description: Different Panel members had different pictures nosing neat; one had just finished trimming the privet hedge, whilst another was looking at a plethora of leftover paint in the garage to decide the next DIY project and yet another inspecting an old upturned boat on a pebble beach. An intense icy fresh mouth-feel like a ‘Whisky Smash’ with a subtle sweet peat smoke infusion. Water added an intriguing mixture of sweet, salty, herbal and phenolic aromas; cloves, rosemary, burnt brown sugar, mint, and seaweed. The taste was an iceberg wedge salad with red peppers, black olives and roasted pine nuts with an olive oil dressing.
https://www.smws.com/whisky-smash.drinking_tip: Having a break at the ceilidh dance
https://www.smws.com/whisky-smash.name: Whisky Smash

https://www.smws.com/young-spirited.description: The sharp initial impact – one panel member referred to it as an ‘eye burner’ – mellows as it breathes in the glass. Lightly fruity, ‘the makings of a mohito’, rosewater, traces of plastic raincoat, then macaroon bars in spades. Unreduced, the taste is initially sharp (over infused lemon tea), though pleasant, with some white pepper and a coconut/whin flower finish. It benefits from a dash of water, raising scented candles, ‘Fuzzy Peach’ soap from Bodyshop, then acid drops and Fry’s Chocolate Cream fondant, before reverting to macaroon bars. A soft texture, and a dusty, sweet, warming taste; mouth-cooling (‘clove-flavoured Edinburgh rock’), with dessicated coconut in the aftertaste.
https://www.smws.com/young-spirited.name: Young & spirited

https://www.smws.com/zingy-blackcurrant-.description: The nose neat was sweet and fruity but at the same time we noticed a little kick like that of zingy lime and blackcurrant cheesecake, spiced caramel apple upside-down cake or apple and walnut brioche with a cider brandy custard. The taste was very much along the same lines; plum tarts with honey and black pepper as well as apple and sour cherry pie. With water, turning a touch sweeter; butter cakes with honeyed pears and waffles with hot strawberry jam and we all could not resist the temptation of having a maple-sweetened chocolate cupcake topped with a honey cream cheese frosting.
https://www.smws.com/zingy-blackcurrant-.drinking_tip: In the afternoon with or without high tea
https://www.smws.com/zingy-blackcurrant-.name: Zingy blackcurrant cheesecake
